column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/02/germany-dependence-russian-energy-gas-oil-nord-stream;2022-06-02;NA;Germany has been forced to admit it was a terrible mistake to become so dependent on Russian oil and gas. So why did it happen?
On Sunday 1 February 1970
column2: senior politicians and gas executives from Russia and Germany gathered at the upmarket Hotel Kaiserhof in Essen. They were there to celebrate the signing of a contract for the first major Russia-Germany gas pipeline
column3: which was to run from Siberia to the West German border at Marktredwitz in Bavaria. The contract was the result of nine months of intense bargaining over the price of the gas
column4: the cost of 1.2m tonnes of German pipes to be sold to Russia
column5: and the credit terms offered to Moscow by a consortium of 17 German banks. Aware of the risk of Russia defaulting
column6: the German banks’ chief financial negotiator
column7: Friedrich Wilhelm Christians
column8: took the precaution of asking for a loan from the federal government
column9: explaining: “I don’t do any somersaults without a net
column10: especially not on a trapeze.”

column1: The relationship would benefit both sides: Germany would supply the machines and high-quality industrial goods; Russia would provide the raw material to fuel German industry. High-pressure pipelines and their supporting infrastructure hold the potential to bind countries together
column2: since they require trust
column3: cooperation and mutual dependence. But this was not just a commercial deal
column4: as the presence at the hotel of the German economic minister Karl Schiller showed. For the advocates of Ostpolitik – the new “eastern policy” of rapprochement towards the Soviet Union and its allies including East Germany
column5: launched the previous year under chancellor Willy Brandt – this was a moment of supreme political consequence. Schiller
column6: an economist by training
column7: was to describe it as part of an effort at “political and human normalisation with our Eastern neighbours”.

column1: The sentiment was laudable
column2: but for some observers it was a potentially dangerous move. Before the signing
column3: Nato had discreetly written to the German economics ministry to inquire about the security implications. Norbert Plesser
column4: head of the gas department at the ministry
column5: had assured Nato that there was no cause for alarm: Germany would never rely on Russia for even 10% of its gas supplies.

column1: Half a century later
column3: Russia would supply more than half of Germany’s natural gas and about a third of all the oil that Germans burned to heat homes
column4: power factories and fuel vehicles. Roughly half of Germany’s coal imports
column5: which are essential to its steel manufacturing
column6: came from Russia.

column1: An arrangement that began as a peacetime opening to a former foe has turned into an instrument of aggression. Germany is now funding Russia’s war. In the first two months after the start of Russia’s assault on Ukraine
column2: Germany is estimated to have paid nearly €8.3bn for Russian energy – money used by Moscow to prop up the rouble and buy the artillery shells firing at Ukrainian positions in Donetsk. In that time
column3: EU countries are estimated to have paid a total of €39bn for Russian energy
column4: more than double the sum they have given to help Ukraine defend itself. The irony is painful. “For thirty years
column5: Germans lectured Ukrainians about fascism
column6: ” the historian Timothy Snyder wrote recently. “When fascism actually arrived
column7: Germans funded it
column8: and Ukrainians died fighting it.”

column1: When Putin invaded Ukraine in February
column2: Germany faced a particular problem. Its rejection of nuclear power and its transition away from coal meant that Germany had very few alternatives to Russian gas. Berlin has been forced to accept that it was a cataclysmic error to have made itself so dependent on Russian energy – whatever the motives behind it. The foreign minister
column3: Annalena Baerbock
column4: says Germany failed to listen to the warnings from countries that had once suffered under Russia’s occupation
column5: such as Poland and the Baltic states. For Norbert Röttgen
column6: a former environment minister and member of Angela Merkel’s Christian Democrat Union (CDU)
column7: the German government bowed to industry forces pressing for cheap gas “all too easily”
column8: while “completely ignoring the geopolitical risks”.

column1: In February this year
column2: German Green economic affairs and climate action minister Robert Habeck said that gas storage facilities owned by Gazprom in Germany had been “systematically emptied” over the winter
column3: to drive up prices and exert political pressure. It was a staggering admission of Russia’s power to disrupt energy supplies.

column1: “I was wrong
column2: ” the former German finance minister
column3: Wolfgang Schäuble
column4: says
column5: simply. “We were all wrong.”

column1: In recent weeks even Frank-Walter Steinmeier
column2: the German president
column3: a totemic figure of the Social Democrats and greatest German advocate of the trade “bridge” between east and west
column4: has recanted. He admits he misread Russia’s intentions as he pursued the construction of a new undersea gas pipeline. “My adherence to Nord Stream 2 was clearly a mistake
column5: ” he told German media in April. “We held on to bridges that Russia no longer believed in
column6: and that our partners warned us about.” This is an extraordinary admission for a man who acted as chief of staff to Gerhard Schröder
column7: the Social Democratic chancellor from 1998 to 2005 and thereafter a lavishly rewarded
column8: and much reviled
column9: lobbyist for Vladimir Putin. Steinmeier was also foreign minister under Chancellor Merkel
column10: and a great evangelist for Wandel durch Handel
column11: the concept that trade and dialogue can bring about social and political change.

column1: How did Germany end up making such a blunder? Some argue that Merkel should have seen that Putin was taking Russia in an authoritarian direction when he announced his return to the presidency in 2011. After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in 2014
column2: Germany made no move to stop importing Russian gas
column3: and although Merkel threatened to introduce crippling trade sanctions
column4: German industry convinced her to hold back. But some blame a more persistent misjudgment stretching back 50 years
column5: based on a fallacy that authoritarian countries can be transformed through trade.

column1: The Social Democrats have now set up a review into whether the policy of Ostpolitik
column2: first laid out in a landmark speech in July 1963 by Egon Bahr
column3: then chancellor Willy Brandt’s closest adviser
column4: became deformed over time – especially after securing its great achievement
column5: the fall of the Berlin Wall.

column1: What is extraordinary
column2: retracing the history through memoirs and contemporary records
column3: is how frequently and determinedly Germany was warned
column4: by everyone from Henry Kissinger onwards
column5: that it was making a pact it might live to regret. Kissinger wrote to Richard Nixon on 9 April 1970: “Few people
column6: either inside Germany or abroad
column7: see Brandt as selling out to the East; what worries people is whether he can control what he has started.” Over 50 years
column8: Germany fought numerous battles with a series of US presidents over its growing dependence on Russian energy. In the process
column9: Germany’s foreign office developed a view of American anti-communism as naive
column10: and a belief that only Germany truly understood the Soviet Union.

column1: From the late 1960s
column2: the Federal Republic of Germany tried to open its own direct line of communication with the Soviet leadership
column3: even though its interest in reunification created tensions with the US. When it faced criticism from the US
column4: Germany was wont to cite its unique status. “I cannot imagine there is anyone more interested in being allowed to continue working for detente and balance in Europe than the German people who are forced to live in two states
column5: ” Hans-Dietrich Genscher
column6: then the foreign minister
column7: told the German Bundestag in January 1980
column8: to great applause.

column1: But after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989
column2: why was Germany still so reluctant to listen to others? A sense of guilt for the atrocities committed against the Soviet Union during the second world war may have played a role. Pride
column3: too
column4: that – through Ostpolitik – it had mended its relations with Moscow. Germany
column5: in a sense
column6: became a double prisoner of its past – bound both to the horrors it had committed
column7: and to its belief that its response to those horrors was correct.

column1: The conflicts between Germany and the US in the 70s and 80s
column2: involving two very different presidents
column3: Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan
column4: were some of the most rancorous transatlantic battles since the second world war. “The disputes were all part of West Germany showing independence in foreign policy during the cold war
column5: and that became uncomfortable for some American leaders
column6: ” the historian Mary Elise Sarotte said to me.

column1: Carter and the German chancellor Helmut Schmidt had little respect for each other. Carter found Schmidt moody
column2: while the chancellor
column3: in his autobiography
column4: dismissed Carter as an idealistic preacher
column5: who knew nothing of Europe and was “just not big enough for the game”. The two leaders did not just grate personally
column6: they disagreed on issues of substance – including how to protect human rights in Russia. In 1979 Schmidt and Carter came together to jointly adopt the so-called dual track decision
column7: by which Nato would upgrade its nuclear weapons based in Europe
column8: while actively seeking an arms control agreement with Russia. But in other ways their approach was very different.

column1: Schmidt never lacked self-confidence
column2: but like many Germans of that era he carried a deep sense of shame arising from painful war memories. He also believed that the stability of the eastern bloc was in the interest of West Germany
column3: given Russia’s nuclear capability. In his autobiography he wrote that he had wanted to develop trading relations with Russia
column4: in order to foster “a greater Soviet dependence upon European supplies”
column5: in turn leading to “more European influence” on Moscow’s policies. And following the 1973 oil crisis
column6: Schmidt became convinced that the Soviet Union represented a more reliable supplier of energy for Germany than the Gulf states.

column1: Carter
column2: by contrast
column3: saw withholding trade as the better way to influence the Soviets. In July 1978
column4: responding to Moscow’s imprisonment of two Soviet dissidents
column5: Aleksandr Ginzburg and Anatoly Shcharansky
column6: Carter restricted US exports of technology for the exploration and development of the Soviet oil and natural-gas industries.

column1: Yet
column2: collectively
column3: European business went in the opposite direction. Even after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979
column4: a large German business delegation went ahead with a visit to Moscow. The Soviets (Soyuzgazexport) and western Europeans (chiefly Ruhrgas and Gaz de France) completed negotiations on a new giant gas project
column5: a 4
column6: 500km dedicated pipeline from the giant Urengoy field in West Siberia in late 1980. This deal was projected to increase Germany’s dependence on Russian gas from 15% to 30%. When German ministers reviewed the security implications
column7: they concluded there was no danger of Russia misusing its potential stranglehold. Their reasoning was simple. “Long-term disruption would be against the self-interest of the Soviet Union
column8: ” the ministry decided.

column1: In a phone call with Carter on 5 March
column2: Schmidt explained his support for the pipeline by telling the US president
column3: “Those engaging in trade with each other do not shoot at one another.” It was a restatement of Norman Angell’s famous pre-first world war theory that the new interdependence of economies made war unprofitable and thus irrational. According to a note in his diary
column4: Carter responded: “It is not beneficial for the Europeans to expect us to provide the stick and for them to compete with one another about providing the biggest carrot.”

column2: Schmidt wrote: “To speak of the Federal Republic’s economic dependence on Moscow to a degree large enough to affect foreign policy indicates ignorance or malice.” Given Germany’s plight now
column3: those words look hopelessly misjudged.

column1: Schmidt faced a more challenging opponent in Carter’s successor
column2: the traditional anti-communist Ronald Reagan. In Reagan’s eyes
column3: German trade with Russia was in direct conflict with western security. Reagan’s view was informed by a CIA assessment submitted in July 1981
column4: which noted a clear trend: from 1970 to 1980
column5: Soviet gas exports to western Europe had risen from 1 billion cubic metres (bcm) a year to 26.5bcm annually. The CIA warned Reagan that the Urengoy gas project would not only accelerate Soviet economic growth
column6: but provide the Soviets with $8bn in hard currency
column7: facilitating a further military buildup. Far from giving Germany sway over Soviet thinking
column8: “it would provide the Soviets one additional pressure point they could use as part of a broader diplomatic offensive to persuade the West Europeans to accept their viewpoint on East-West issues”.

column1: In arguments that echo today’s debates
column2: the US ambassador to the UN
column3: Jeane Kirkpatrick
column4: complained: “We consistently find in our talks the allies are already significantly dependent: France for 15% [of its] gas
column5: Germany for 30%.” Schmidt assured the Americans that Germany “can go six months in the event of a Soviet cut-off”. The forecast now is that
column6: in such an eventuality
column7: Germany would have to go straight to a form of energy rationing.

column1: Despite various US efforts to persuade Europe to adopt a voluntary ban
column2: including offering alternative sources of energy
column3: in 1981 Ruhrgas AG and Soyusgazexport went ahead and signed a contract for annual imports of 10.5bcm of Soviet gas over a 25-year period. Unemployment in Europe was close to 9% at the time
column4: and European industry needed to boost its energy supplies. At the same time
column5: the US argument about security was dismissed as a veiled way of promoting the US oil industry.

column1: When Moscow backed the imposition of martial law in Poland on 13 December 1981
column2: Reagan thought such a shocking event might persuade Germany to put the pipeline on hold. In a private note to Margaret Thatcher
column3: sent on 19 December 1981
column4: he urged her to back tough sanctions against the Soviets
column5: stating that “this may well be a watershed in the history of mankind. A challenge to tyranny from within.” Unusually for her
column6: Thatcher vacillated
column7: advising Reagan that the Germans “cannot and will not give up the gas pipeline project”.

column1: The US responded to the Soviet intervention by banning US companies from helping with the pipeline. In the summer of 1982 Reagan tried to force European firms to stop working on the pipeline by imposing secondary sanctions on them. Such sanctions are now a commonplace in the US foreign policy armoury
column2: particularly over Iran
column3: but then
column4: they were seen as an incursion into European sovereignty. Thatcher bridled
column5: telling the Commons “it is wrong” for “one very powerful nation [to] prevent existing contracts being fulfilled”.

column1: By November
column2: Reagan had abandoned the attempt to impose sanctions. In a trial of strength in which Europe sided with Germany
column3: the world’s superpower had lost. The new pipeline started pumping on 1 January 1984.

column1: The German advocates of change through trade had won. The US position on Russia was further weakened when the Berlin Wall fell in 1989. The peaceful collapse of communism was trumpeted as a vindication for those that had championed dialogue
column2: and engagement through trade. In a speech to the Brandt Foundation in March 2008
column3: Steinmeier gave full vent to this view: “What Ostpolitik in fact achieved – as is now recognised also by those who criticised it at the time
column4: ” he said
column5: “was to make peace in Europe
column6: despite the difficulties
column7: a degree more secure. For the democracy movements in eastern Europe it created new possibilities
column8: new scope for action. It was a key factor
column9: too
column10: in finally ending the confrontation between the two blocs.”

column1: Olaf Scholz
column2: Germany’s current chancellor
column3: remains an adherent of this view
column4: arguing last year that it contributed to the fall of the Soviet Union and laid the basis for democracy and EU membership for much of eastern Europe. The SPD co-leader
column5: Lars Klingbeil
column6: has also insisted that Ostpolitik “was the basis for reunification and the end of the cold war. As a result
column7: there has been a consensus in the federal republic for decades that conflicts can be defused through dialogue. We won’t let that be bad-mouthed.”

column1: Yet a number of historians and writers believe that this rosy picture of Ostpolitik is misleading. “The idea that Willy Brandt’s policy of detente towards Moscow led in a straight line to the fall of the iron curtain and German unity is at least an over-simplification
column2: ” says the historian Jan Behrends. German journalist Thomas Urban
column3: author of a new book critiquing Ostpolitik
column4: believes its role in the fall of the wall and German reunification has been exaggerated: “It was military buildup by Reagan and the flooding of the market with cheap oil that led to the collapse of the Soviet Union
column5: ” he told me. The Russian government budget had grown so dependent on energy for its revenue
column6: he said
column7: that when the price of oil plummeted in the mid-1980s
column8: Russia’s lifeline to external capital dried up. “Gorbachev could no longer fund the overseas wars and the Soviet Republics
column9: ” he said. “But this argument was entirely missing in the German debate
column10: especially on the left.”

column1: Urban argued that Ostpolitik’s theory of change suffered from two basic misconceptions: the belief that political change in eastern Europe could only come from engaging with the elite in power
column2: rather than from civilian movements
column3: and second
column4: that “security must be the key to everything”.

column1: By the turn of the century
column2: the advocates of change through trade were in their pomp. Chancellor Schröder
column3: with growing confidence
column4: promoted the idea of a strategic partnership with Russia. He invited the new Russian president
column5: Vladimir Putin
column6: to address the Bundestag in 2001
column7: where he won over his audience by giving the speech in fluent German and declaring “the cold war is over”.

column1: Schröder
column2: at the time of Putin’s address
column3: saw a perfect confluence of interests between Europe
column4: Germany and Russia: peace
column5: stability
column6: multilateralism and economic growth. Putin
column7: Schröder was convinced
column8: “wants to transform Russia into a democracy”.

column1: In this favourable political climate
column2: pro-Russian German lobbyists such as Klaus Mangold
column3: chairman of the powerful German Committee on Eastern European Economic Relations
column4: pursued the construction of yet another gas pipeline
column5: this time taking gas from Vyborg under the Baltic Sea to Germany – the first Nord Stream. The scheme was especially controversial since it would bypass Poland
column6: Belarus and Ukraine
column7: reducing those countries’ incomes
column8: weakening their bargaining power and depriving them of badly needed transit fees. The €7.4bn pipeline construction costs were to be borne by the private German companies BASF and E.ON
column9: and the majority Russian state-owned Gazprom.

column1: This time
column2: protests against the pipeline did not just come from the US
column3: but from the states that had recently emerged from Soviet rule
column4: such as Poland and Lithuania. Radosław Sikorski
column5: then Poland’s defence minister
column6: notoriously compared the plan to the 1939 Molotov-Ribbentrop non-aggression pact between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union
column7: which paved the way for the invasion of Poland.

column1: Yet on 8 September 2005
column2: 10 days before the election in which Schröder’s Social Democrats lost to Angela Merkel’s conservatives
column3: the Nord Stream 1 contract was signed in Berlin by representatives of Gazprom
column4: E.ON and BASF. Putin stood alongside Schröder at the signing ceremony.

column1: Schröder has since been singled out for his role in creating Germany’s dependence on Russian energy
column2: and getting very rich in the process. But the distinguished former German diplomat Wolfgang Ischinger recently argued that Schröder should not take the blame for giving the go-ahead to Nord Stream 20 years ago: most German politicians
column3: he told the New York Times in April
column4: did not question whether they were getting into an unhealthy dependence on Russian energy. In the article
column5: Schröder made the same case: “It never occurred to anyone that this could become a problem. It was just a way of procuring gas for Germans
column6: for Germany’s heavy industry
column7: and also for the chemical industry
column8: with fewer problems and disruptions.”

column1: Thereafter it seemed
column2: whatever the setbacks in German-Russian relations
column3: nothing could shift the faith in trade – not Russia’s “peace enforcement operation” in Georgia in August 2008
column4: not the Russian disruption of the gas pipelines in a dispute with Ukraine in January 2009
column5: nor the news that Putin was planning to return to the presidency in 2012
column6: replacing Dmitry Medvedev
column7: in whom Frank-Walter Steinmeier had placed his faith. In 2011
column8: the year Nord Stream finally opened
column9: German total trade exports to Russia rose 34% to €27bn.

column1: Then came the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2014. Initially
column2: Russia’s incursion seemed to mark a turning point. Merkel’s condemnation was clear: the annexation of Crimea was contrary to international law. Sanctions were duly imposed
column3: and German exports to Russia fell.

column1: Following the 2014 invasion
column2: serious German media such as Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung published lengthy articles looking at the options for how Germany could wean itself off its dangerous dependency on Russian energy. Many of the proposals
column3: such as new liquid gas terminals to allow Germany to import gas from other countries such as Qatar and the US
column4: are the same ones under discussion now
column5: which shows how little actual diversification was achieved. When I spoke to a Qatari energy official last month
column6: he recounted how they spent five years trying to break into the German energy market
column7: only to find their route blocked at every turn.

column1: Some German sanctions on Russia continued for many years
column2: but the advocates of change through trade gradually re-established their ground. It seemed nothing Russia could do would shake their confidence. On 4 September 2015
column3: at the Vladivostok economic forum
column4: with Putin in attendance
column5: an agreement was signed for the construction of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline on the Baltic seabed
column6: which would vastly increase Germany’s reliance on Russian natural gas. Gazprom would also take over Germany’s gas storage business
column7: thereby handing control of German energy reserves to a foreign power.

column1: Various theories – some grubby
column2: some metaphysical – have been proposed to explain Germany’s dogged refusal to see the dangers in its dependency on Russia. One argument places the blame on SPD politicians and civil servants who were allowed to move seamlessly between public office and Putin’s employment
column3: and worked hard to manipulate the EU and German regulatory environment to suit Gazprom.

column1: Then there is the question of the German-Russian industrial lobby
column2: as symbolised by the German-Russian Forum
column3: which was closely linked with
column4: and partly funded by
column5: German companies active in Russia. (The Forum was suspended after the invasion of Ukraine.) Its board of trustees consisted mainly of business people
column6: often with economic interests in Russia. Its chairman
column7: Matthias Platzeck
column8: the former SPD minister president of Brandenburg
column9: seemed genuinely shocked by Putin’s invasion: “I was wrong because until recently I thought what happened was unthinkable.”

column1: The historian Sarotte said there is no clear evidence that business had exerted greater influence in politics in Germany than in other countries. Nevertheless
column2: over the years
column3: Russia showed an ability to suborn
column4: and in some cases corrupt
column5: the German political class. The Polish foreign minister
column6: Zbigniew Rau
column7: on a visit to Berlin in late May
column8: called German Ostpolitik a “fiasco”. German rhetoric around the political value of interdependence
column9: he said
column10: crudely boiled down to gaining a competitive advantage through cheap energy.

column1: Thomas Urban
column2: examining the psychological roots of Ostpolitik
column3: pinpoints two emotions in Germany’s relationship with Russia: nostalgia and guilt. He described to me “the memory of Bismarck
column4: who saw the alliance with Russia as an anchor of stability in Europe. But then there was also the feeling of guilt because of the German attack on the Soviet Union in 1941
column5: with millions of dead. It meant it was difficult to criticise the Red Army or the Soviet repression since to do so means you do not recognise the greatest crimes in history. It makes Germany blind to the black side of the Soviet Union. It also permits Putin’s propaganda by talking only of the Russian war dead
column6: and not those that were killed in Ukraine and Belarus.”

column1: Much of Germany’s belief in trade with Russia was born of wishful thinking. It led Steinmeier as foreign minister
column2: for instance
column3: to look constantly for signs of reform
column4: ignoring foreign office advice that he needed a plan B in case Germany’s faith in Russia turned out to be ill-founded. In 2016
column5: Steinmeier gave a deeply sincere
column6: almost elegiac speech at Yekaterinburg University asking whether Germany and Russia were still capable of listening to one another. He admitted the annexation of Ukraine had been a low point
column7: but hoped dialogue was still possible
column8: urging both sides not to turn their backs on one another.

column1: It was the speech of a man who sensed the tide was going out
column2: and who feared his belief in dialogue no longer matched the spirit of harsher times: “In political discussions
column3: we sometimes hear opinions expressed by people who are not interested in the slightest in understanding others; people who have already made up their minds about the other side; people who don’t even bother reading because they think they already know the answer.” What he described as the “supposed antagonism” between the west and Russia
column4: he feared was becoming entrenched and ideologically driven
column5: running counter to the pursuit of diplomacy and peace.

column1: Now
column2: as Germany’s president and head of state
column3: Steinmeier has been told by Ukrainian officials that his record as the promoter of Russian interests in Germany means he is not welcome in Kyiv at this time. It seems a shame. There would be no need for him to fall to his knees – as Willy Brandt did in Warsaw in 1970
column4: apologising for his nation’s wartime crimes – but he could give a sober reflection on what precisely went wrong with Germany’s eastern policy for so long. For
column5: one way or another
column6: a reckoning is still needed.

column2: listen to our podcasts here and sign up to the long read weekly email here."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/02/russia-and-the-west-compete-to-secure-safe-passage-for-ukraines-grain;2022-06-02;Russia and the west compete to secure safe passage for Ukraine’s grain;"Analysis: both sides agree grain must reach world markets soon but each wants to decide how
In a game of diplomatic cat and mouse
column2: Russia and the west are coming up with similar if sometimes competing ideas for how Ukraine’s badly needed grain can be given safe passage through the Black Sea and on to the world markets. They are also competing to win the battle for world opinion if the plans collapse.

column1: Both sides are busy diplomatically across Africa and the Middle East trying to portray their adversary as the culprit for spiralling food and fertiliser prices. Russia and Ukraine export more than a quarter of the world’s wheat
column2: while Russia is the world’s top fertiliser exporter. The World Bank’s Fertiliser Price Index rose nearly 10% in the first quarter of 2022
column3: to an all-time high in nominal terms.

column1: Ukraine’s backlog of 20m tonnes of grain needs to be exported quickly to avoid a further explosion of food prices
column2: and also to preserve the next Ukrainian harvest that currently cannot be sent to already full storage facilities.

column1: That is not possible due to the Russian naval blockade of the Black Sea port of Odesa
column2: and Ukrainian floating mines planted to block the port from Russian attack. Russia
column3: in return for lifting the blockade
column4: wants any sanctions on its shipping and fertiliser products lifted. At issue is whether there is a deal to be done.

column1: In what is beginning to look like the main plan
column2: the Russian foreign minister
column3: Sergei Lavrov
column4: has agreed to meet the Turkish president
column5: Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
column6: but not until 8 June
column7: over proposals for Turkey to de-mine Odesa and then escort grain ships through to the Bosphorous along a naval corridor. Erdoğan spoke with Vladimir Putin about the proposal on Monday
column8: and according to the Turkish read-out
column9: Putin was willing to cooperate
column10: on conditions.

column1: Turkey
column2: through the 1936 Montreux convention
column3: is arbiter of sea traffic in and out of the Black Sea
column4: and justifies its refusal as a Nato member to impose sanctions on Russia by pointing to this unique role. The Turkish foreign minister
column5: Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu
column6: said on Tuesday that food security was the most important question: “We are focusing on this. We are planning to establish a centre in Istanbul to observe the corridor.”

column1: Within Europe
column2: the Italian prime minister
column3: Mario Draghi
column4: has taken the practical initiative
column5: discussing the issue first with Joe Biden a fortnight ago then last week holding talks with the Ukrainian president
column6: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column7: then Putin and then Zelenskiy again.

column1: The Ukrainians have said they are willing to see Odesa de-mined
column2: but conditions would have to be set on how the Russian navy would not use the clearance of mines as an opportunity for its warships to move closer to the port. Ukraine’s foreign minister
column3: Dmytro Kuleba
column4: said: “We must be very careful
column5: because a unilateral guarantee from the Kremlin is not enough. We need third countries to take responsibility for enforcing the agreement.”

column1: Italy and the UK have offered to undertake the de-mining operation
column2: something that could take a fortnight
column3: but Turkey may be Russia’s preferred choice to complete this perilous task.

column1: According to Draghi
column2: Putin has indicated that he would open access to Odesa provided valid checks could be made to ensure the grain ships were not carrying weapons for use by Ukraine. Unresolved issues also exist about the nationality of the ships escorting the convoy
column3: and their terms of engagement if threatened by Russia.

column1: According to Moscow
column2: Putin noted the “readiness of the Russian side” to facilitate the unhindered sea transit of goods in coordination with Turkish partners.

column1: But Russia also wants in return the lifting of western sanctions on Russian fertilisers
column2: something Draghi says is also being urged on the EU by Africa and warrants a second look.

column1: The US is also showing some flexibility. Its ambassador to the UN
column2: Linda Thomas-Greenfield
column3: said the US was prepared to give “comfort letters” to shipping and insurance companies to help facilitate exports of Russian grain and fertiliser.

column1: She insisted that Russian grain and fertiliser were not under US Treasury sanctions but that “companies are a little nervous and we’re prepared to give them comfort letters if that will help to encourage them”. column1: Joe Biden has announced the US will send advanced missile systems to Ukraine. The new weapon is the Himars multiple launch rocket system
column2: or MLRS: a mobile unit that can simultaneously launch multiple precision-guided missiles.

column1: Both Ukraine and Russia already operate MLRS
column2: but Himars has superior range and precision.

column1: The M142 Himars system (High Mobility Artillery Rocket System) is a modernised
column2: lighter and more agile wheel-mounted version of the track-mounted M270 MLRS developed in the 1970s for US and allied forces.

column1: The Himars that Washington is providing to Ukraine will have a range of about 50 miles (80km)
column2: a US official told reporters.

column1: Himars units carry one preloaded pod of six 227mm guided missiles (the M270 carries two pods)
column2: or one large pod loaded with an Army Tactical Missile System (ATACMS) tactical missile. The US will not supply Ukraine with the ATACMS
column3: which has a range of 300km.

column1: With a small crew
column2: the Himars can remove a spent pod and load a fresh one in minutes
column3: without other vehicles helping. The crews will require some training.

column1: The US military already has Himars units in Europe; and Nato allies Poland and Romania have acquired the systems.
Himars will give Ukraine’s forces the ability to strike further behind Russian lines
column2: and at distances better protected from Russia’s own long-range weaponry.

column1: The GPS-guided missiles the Himars shoots have a range about double that of the M777 howitzers that the US recently supplied to Ukraine forces.

column2: while placing the Russian batteries at risk.

column1: The partial embargo on Russian oil imports agreed at the summit on Monday night constitutes a significant
column2: if belated
column3: ratcheting up of economic pressure on Vladimir Putin’s regime. After a month of negotiations between member states
column4: objections from Hungary were finally overcome through a temporary exemption for oil transported through a Soviet-era pipeline to central Europe. Given that Germany and Poland will forgo imports from this source
column5: by the end of the year the embargo should cover over 90% of Russian oil supplies to Europe. The effect of the ban over time
column6: and combined with other sanctions
column7: will be to deprive Moscow of funds and means to prosecute a prolonged war of attrition that it did not anticipate having to fight.

column2: Josep Borrell
column3: was therefore justified in describing the oil embargo as a show of unity and a “landmark” agreement. An announcement of €9bn in economic aid to Ukraine was also welcome
column4: although it should only be seen as a start. The Kyiv School of Economics has calculated that the war is causing about $4.5bn worth of damage to civilian infrastructure every week. The costs of postwar reconstruction could run into hundreds of billions of dollars.

column1: However
column2: financing that colossal challenge is tomorrow’s task. In the shorter term – as it attempts to intensify the financial squeeze on Mr Putin – the west must give Ukraine the military assistance it needs to resist Russian forces
column3: while continuing to avoid moves that risk escalating and widening the war. In May
column4: Washington committed to a $40bn package to aid Ukraine’s war effort
column5: and the supply of US weapons is accelerating – including vital artillery capability. European countries need to up the pace of their own contributions
column6: as the Kremlin attempts to concentrate overwhelming force in the east and annexe new territory. But the US president
column7: Joe Biden
column8: was right this week to rule out sending long-range missile systems to Ukraine which could be deployed to hit targets inside Russia. Moscow’s nuclear capability – and the threatening rhetoric intermittently deployed in relation to it – must necessarily inform the west’s strategic calculations
column9: however enraging that may be.

column1: The goal
column2: as Mr Putin’s appalling war of choice continues
column3: must be that President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and the Ukrainian people are enabled to negotiate its end from a position of strength and dignity. If this is to be achieved
column4: it will be through a combination of economic pressure on Moscow and military resistance. Russia’s armed forces are being steadily and damagingly depleted
column5: even as incremental territorial gains are made. Around 1
column6: 000 tanks may have been lost on the battlefield
column7: while two of Russia’s tank manufacturers have reportedly ceased production due to a lack of parts.

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/plea-for-heavy-weapons-ukraine-frontline-mykolaiv;2022-05-31;‘The west can change the outcome’: plea for heavy weapons on Ukraine frontline;"People under constant fire in southern city of Mykolaiv say they can beat Russia with more help

A stack of deadly weapons line the corridor next to Roman Kostenko’s office in the southern Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv. Giant tube-like Javelin missiles and a powerful-looking green cylinder. “That’s an NLAW anti-tank weapon supplied by Britain
column2: ” Kostenko – a member of Ukraine’s parliament and a special forces commander – explained. “We’ve used it.”

column1: When Russia invaded on 24 February
column2: Kostenko was in Kyiv. He swapped his politician’s outfit of suit and tie for a uniform and hurried to Mykolaiv on the southern frontline. By this point Russian troops had practically encircled the city and its port on the Bug River. They had seized Mykolaiv’s airport and were advancing from the north-east. “I was the last car in
column3: ” he said.

column1: Citizens were piling up tyres and making molotov cocktails in preparation for street-to-street fighting. The Ukrainian army
column2: however
column3: managed to push the Russians back. Kostenko showed off a video he took of a Russian position on Mykolaiv’s outskirts. There were bodies of enemy soldiers killed in a Ukrainian artillery strike
column4: as well as abandoned field guns and vehicles.

column1: Since this failed incursion the fighting has turned into a “war of rockets and artillery”
column2: Kostenko said. The frontline in the south runs approximately along the administrative border between Russian-occupied Kherson oblast and Mykolaiv
column3: 12 miles (20km) to the north. It is a shimmering landscape of green wheat fields and steppe villages
column4: now under constant fire.

column1: Russian howitzers are able to target Mykolaiv with ease. On Saturday a missile smashed into a residential block in the city
column2: killing one person and injuring seven. The Ukrainians lack long-range rocket systems that would enable them to fire back
column3: as well as defensive anti-aircraft batteries
column4: Kostenko said. In the meantime they sit in makeshift trenches under fire.

column1: “To survive artillery hitting you 24/7 is very hard
column2: ” Kostenko added. The Javelins sent by the US were ineffective because the Russians hid their armoured vehicles in a network of Soviet-era irrigation canals
column3: he explained. “Our anti-tank weapons don’t see them. If our partners give us heavy artillery and advanced systems like MRLS [multiple-launch rocket systems] we can win and take back occupied territory.”

column1: For now
column2: Ukrainian soldiers are only able to make local tactical gains. On Monday they retook a village in north-east Kherson. Kostenko said Russia had plenty of tanks and supplies of ammunition left. The fighting in the south
column3: and in the east where a battle is raging for the city of Sievierodonetsk
column4: resembled the second world war with modern weapons
column5: he said. The Russians
column6: he admitted
column7: had the advantage.

column1: The MP
column2: secretary of the national security
column3: defence and intelligence committee
column4: spent 15 years as a soldier. He was wounded twice in late 2014 while fighting at the airport in Donetsk against the Russians and their separatist proxies. He grew up in a village outside Kherson now controlled by Moscow
column5: where Russian soldiers broke into his parents’ house
column6: looted his parade uniform and took away all of the furniture

column1: Kostenko suggested Vladimir Putin’s goal was to seize the Donbas and annex Ukraine’s Black Sea coast
column2: making it a “non-sea country”

column4: not just Ukraine.”

column1: He was less enthusiastic about Germany and France. “Some of our partners are behaving very cautiously. It’s inexplicable. They are not calling out the enemy. We are fighting totalitarianism
column2: ” an exasperated Kostenko said.

column1: Mykolaiv’s inhabitants
column2: meanwhile
column3: have got used to thunderous booms
column4: which shake the city on an hourly basis. For more than a month there was no water after a pipeline was destroyed. Last week a supply for washing was finally reconnected. There is no drinking water. It is delivered to the city
column5: a major shipbuilding centre in USSR times
column6: in large plastic bottles. About 40% of its population have left.

column1: A humanitarian aid point has been set up in a crumbling 200-year-old theatre and concert hall once used by naval officers. There are supplies of clothes
column2: shoes and medicines. Residents fill in a form explaining what they need. Viktoria Veselovska
column3: a journalist working in a pop-up basement pharmacy
column4: said she had no mosquito repellant. “Insects are a big problem for our soldiers
column5: ” she said.

column1: Morale among those who have decided to remain in shell-battered Mykolaiv appears high. Olga Pidsosonna
column2: a volunteer and major in the port’s customs department
column3: described the war as “one very long bad day”. “Russia is trying to eat us. But it will break its teeth. We are a very strong nation. I’m proud to be Ukrainian and I’m proud of our army and our volunteers
column4: ” she said.

column1: In peacetime 10 cargo ships a day would leave Mykolaiv’s harbour
column2: she said. Most exported grain. Russia’s naval blockade of the Black Sea meant the port was inoperative. A Ukrainian victory should include Crimea
column3: “stolen by the Kremlin in 2014”
column4: Pidsosonna said
column5: adding: “I have relatives in Crimea. They want to be back with Ukraine. They can’t say this openly
column6: of course. They are afraid.”

column1: Few people in this city of half a million expected to find themselves living in an old-school war zone. One person not surprised by how 2022 turned out was Makar Kostiuk
column2: a student from Vladivostok. Kostiuk volunteered in the local office of the Russian opposition leader
column3: Alexei Navalny. He left the country for Ukraine before Navalny was arrested and jailed.

column1: “When the bombs started falling I was working on my second novel. The explosions made me type faster
column2: ” Kostiuk said. Shrapnel landed in his courtyard
column3: punching a hole in the glass on the stairwell. Kostiuk said he had not encountered any anti-Russian prejudice. But his bank cards had been blocked and he was likely to have to leave Ukraine in the summer when his residency permit ran out.

column1: Many shops on Mykolaiv’s main street
column2: Sobornaya
column3: were boarded up. Tinned music played from loudspeakers attached to maple trees. A few people were out shopping and a man in Lycra rode past on his mountain bike. A lot of destruction was visible. An airdropped bomb had flattened the Ingul hotel. In March the Russians fired a cruise missile at the regional administration building
column4: killing 12 and wounding 33.

column1: Nobody knows when the Ukrainian army will be able to take back Kherson
column2: which was overrun in the first days of the invasion. The Kremlin says the area now belongs to Russia. Plans to hold a “referendum” on joining Moscow have been put on hold because of a lack of public support. “Ninety-nine per cent of the country does not want Russia
column3: ” the MP said.

column1: Kostenko gave the Guardian a souvenir: a jagged fragment from a Russian Kalibr warhead
column2: which he wrapped up carefully in kitchen roll. “Victory now depends on our international friends
column3: ” he said. “We have plenty of kalashnikovs and machine guns. If we get enough heavy arms Russia will not be able to go any further.” He stressed: “The west can change the outcome of this war.”"

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/whats-next-for-ukraine-after-russias-donbas-offensive;2022-05-31;What’s next for Ukraine after Russia’s Donbas offensive?;"Analysis: Indiscriminate tactics of Russia’s grinding progress in east could characterise next phase of war

With reports of large numbers of troops
column2: artillery and rocket launchers mustering across the border near the Russian city of Kursk – in an area that borders Ukraine’s Sumy province – it is an urgent issue.

column1: While much has been made of the painfully slow and grinding pace of Russia’s recent offensive in the Donbas

column1: While other parts of the 300-mile frontline in Ukraine’s east lack some of the same vulnerabilities that existed around Sievierodonetsk – which sat in the midst of a Ukrainian salient that Russia exploited – in any future offensive the Kremlin is likely to offer Kyiv the same hard choices

column1: Even though the song was released over a year after the fall of the Berlin Wall
column2: in December 1990
column3: it is widely remembered as the soundtrack to the era of economic and social changes in the former Soviet Union that heralded the end of the cold war.

column1: Scorpions performed Wind of Change at the Brandenburg Gate on the 10th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1999
column2: and it was voted song of the 20th century by viewers of the public broadcaster ZDF in 2005.

column1: Meine
column2: who wrote the music and lyrics for the hard rock band’s uncharacteristic ballad
column3: said he composed the words on 3 and 4 September 1989
column4: after Scorpions had performed at the Moscow Music Peace festival in mid-August.

column1: More recently
column2: Wind of Change was the subject of a playful eight-part podcast series in which the investigative journalist Patrick Radden Keefe tried to chase down a rumour that the anthem had in fact been written by the CIA
column3: without unearthing any substantial evidence for the theory. In his interview with Die Zeit
column4: Meine again denied that his most successful song had been written by US propaganda officers.

column1: Since the start of the war in Ukraine
column2: Germany’s political establishment has faced criticism that it has spent too long buying into the implicit premise of Scorpions’ chart-topper
column3: of a Russia ever ushered down a road of democratisation as it opened routes of trade and diplomatic exchange with the west. The threats an increasingly aggressive Kremlin continued to pose to the states that once made up its empire
column4: critics allege
column5: were overlooked in Berlin for decades.

column1: In his interview with Die Zeit
column2: Meine denied that his band
column3: too
column4: had overlooked Ukraine’s plight
column5: pointing out Scorpions had played concerts in Donetsk
column6: Kharkiv and Odesa.

column1: “But as a musician you hold on to the thought that people in wildly different countries
column2: some of whom may look on each other as enemies
column3: react to music in the same way. That was also the case in Ukraine and Russia.”

column1: Hailing from Hanover
column2: the state capital of Lower Saxony in north-west Germany
column3: the band used to be seen as part of the friendship circle of the Hanoverian ex-chancellor turned Russian gas lobbyist Gerhard Schröder
column4: whose fifth wedding party Meine attended in 2018.

column1: “I haven’t spoken with Gerhard Schröder for a while
column2: ” Meine told Die Zeit. “But his behaviour really is hard to understand.” The Social Democrat politician held on to his boardroom post with Rosneft for the first three months of the war before the Russian state-owned oil company announced his stepping down on 20 May.

column1: “If he now gives up this post on the supervisory board
column2: then that is a genuine step in the right direction after a long time
column3: ” Meine said."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/mass-civil-legal-action-to-seek-compensation-for-ukrainian-war-victims;2022-05-31;Mass civil legal action to seek compensation for Ukrainian war victims;"Exclusive: Lawyers to target assets of Russian state
column2: military contractors and affiliated business figures across globe

column1: A consortium of Ukrainian and international lawyers is preparing to launch a mass civil legal action against the Russian state
column2: as well as private military contractors and businesspeople backing the Russian war effort
column3: in an attempt to gain financial compensation for millions of Ukrainian victims of the war
column4: the Guardian can reveal.

column1: The team
column2: made up of hundreds of lawyers and several major law firms
column3: plans to bring “multiple actions in different jurisdictions against different targets”
column4: including the UK and the US
column5: said Jason McCue
column6: a London-based lawyer who is coordinating the initiative
column7: in an interview in Kyiv.

column1: The plan is to use UK and US judgments to seize Russian assets across the globe.
Targets are likely to include the Russian state and private military contractors such as the Wagner Group
column2: which is believed to have been active in Ukraine. But McCue said they would also include business figures linked to these contractors
column3: and to the Russian war effort more broadly. He believes that it will be possible to go after assets that have already been hit by sanctions as well as those that have not.

column1: The class action will be a private case
column2: independent of the Ukrainian state. But according to McCue
column3: they will need access to Ukraine’s evidence and intelligence.

column1: The Ukrainian MP and businessman Serhiy Taruta is supporting the initiative by facilitating meetings for the lawyers and investigators with Ukrainian officials.
Taruta
column2: who is from Mariupol and had investments in the city
column3: lost a large chunk of his business when Russia and its proxy forces took more than half of the Donbas region in 2014. This time he lost friends
column4: colleagues and a cousin as Russia destroyed Mariupol while attempting to occupy it.

column1: “Ukrainians have waited 20 years for the prosecution of [Pavlo] Lazarenko
column2: and now eight for MH17
column3: ” said Taruta
column4: referring to a case against Ukraine’s former prime minister who embezzled millions
column5: and to an ongoing case in The Hague over the downing of a Malaysian Airlines flight in 2014.

column1: “We need to develop a quicker mechanism [for compensation]
column2: ” said Taruta. “The normal routes are too slow.”

column1: Ukraine has already begun prosecuting captured Russian soldiers for war crimes in criminal cases
column2: and other war crime cases may later be tried in international courts. But claims for reparations for the war damage are trickier
column3: and McCue said part of the idea behind speedily launching the case was because reparations on a state-to-state level are rarely possible.

column1: “Often when it gets to the negotiations
column2: the issue of reparations is put to one side to focus on the sustainability of peace
column3: ” he said.

column1: According to Taruta
column2: individuals who have suffered the loss of a loved one or property or who have been injured will be the primary recipients of the compensation
column3: followed by state and local institutions
column4: and only then businesses. He estimated the total potential claim could be no less than $1tn (£793.9bn).

column1: A number of teams of investigators have come on board to help the team find assets of businesspeople they believe to be complicit in Russia’s war effort. They include Bellingcat
column2: which has been investigating the activities of the Wagner Group and other Russian private military contractors for some years.

column1: “We are closely monitoring the activity of Russia’s mercenary units in Ukraine
column2: ” said Christo Grozev
column3: Bellingcat’s executive director.

column1: “We believe that a deep dive into the [Wagner Group’s] chain of command and its links to official Russian authorities would not only help bring justice for the victims and their families
column2: but also will bring more public awareness and transparency on how Russia is conducting this war
column3: ” said Grozev.

column1: A key part of the case will involve pleading that Russia’s invasion is not just an aggressive war but also falls at least partially under the legal definition of terrorism
column2: which would make it easier to go after assets.

column1: “All the legal teams from different countries are satisfied that we have what we need
column2: ” said McCue. “It’s very solid.”

column1: McCue has extensive experience in similar cases on a smaller scale
column2: the first of which was won on behalf of victims of the 1998 Omagh bombing
column3: in which four men were found liable for the bombing and ordered to pay compensation to families of the victims.

column1: “The evidence was with the police but nobody was prosecuting because of the peace process
column2: ” said McCue
column3: who described how the families approached him. “So
column4: we did a civil action
column5: and we won
column6: and we managed to take houses off two of them.”

column1: The Ukraine case
column2: which is much bigger in scale
column3: is likely to operate on similar principles
column4: though it will be more focused on winning financial compensation for people who have suffered the loss of their loved ones
column5: property or businesses.

column1: “The Omagh case wasn’t about money
column2: it was about proving who did it. This case is about money
column3: ” said McCue.

column1: He conceded that there would be enormous work ahead to verify and rank cases and create a “victim hierarchy”
column2: and that targeted figures were likely to work hard to move or cover up their assets. However
column3: he said he believed the case had a good chance of succeeding.

column1: “What we know is that if we don’t do this
column2: people are less likely to get something. This increases the chances
column3: ” he said."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/mongolia-under-pressure-to-align-with-russia-and-china;2022-05-31;Mongolia under pressure to align with Russia and China;"Landlocked state is pursuing neutrality despite neighbours’ efforts to create triangle of anti-western cooperation
Mongolia
column2: a squeezed outpost of democracy in north-east Asia
column3: is under renewed pressure from its authoritarian neighbours
column4: Russia and China
column5: to shed its independence and form a triangle of anti-western cooperation in the wake of the war in Ukraine.

column1: The country is doggedly pursuing a path of neutrality
column2: coupled with a policy of economic diversification designed to keep its unique culture and still relatively recent independence alive
column3: according to Nomin Chinbat
column4: its culture secretary.

column1: A Soviet satellite state until 1990
column2: and heavily dependent on China as a market and conduit for its copper and coal exports
column3: Mongolia has to tread carefully. It is three times the size of France but has a population of only 3.5 million
column4: half of whom live in the capital
column5: Ulaanbaatar.

column1: So far it has dodged a definitive position on Ukraine by abstaining in major UN votes. However
column2: its governing Mongolian People’s party is attending briefings given by United Russia
column3: the biggest party in Russia – which has been interpreted in Russia as support for the war.

column1: Doubtless all this is a disappointment to Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column2: the Ukrainian president
column3: who spent four of his childhood years in the Mongolian town of Erdenet as the son of a Soviet mining specialist.

column1: Chinbat
column2: a graduate of the University of East Anglia
column3: is a model of diplomacy when she points out the term ambassador was invented in Mongolia. “Abstaining was a decision that our country had to make because of our geopolitical location
column4: ” she said. “We have had very healthy and manageable relationships with our two neighbours
column5: but we also have a third neighbour policy that allows us to develop a multi-pillar international relationships with other countries.

column1: “We have survived where we are
column2: and our sovereignty has been respected by our neighbours. But democracy is what will keep us developing further.”

column1: Chinbat
column2: who has been tasked with attracting foreign investment to her country – whether from film-makers
column3: industrialists or tourists – said there had been a generational shift among Mongolians
column4: over 60% of whom are under 35. The outlook of younger people
column5: she said
column6: is less defined by relations with the country’s neighbours and more by Mongolia’s own development.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: if there is a prolonged war Mongolia’s ultimate political orientation may once again be up for grabs
column3: especially if China and Russia genuinely form the long-discussed anti-western alliance
column4: making it harder for Mongolia to play its two powerful neighbours off one another.

column1: One path for the country is to form the third part of a Russian-Chinese triangle
column2: largely becoming a transport hub between the two superpowers
column3: and supplier of raw materials
column4: while the other option is to try to acknowledge the two countries’ economic importance
column5: while exploiting Mongolia’s own mineral resources to diversify the economy and modernise. The visit in May of the UK Asia minister
column6: Amanda Milling
column7: is a sign that Britain and the US will try to coax it along the latter course.

column1: Some claim Mongolia in reality has already chosen the Sino-Russian option
column2: since four days after the invasion it signed a memorandum of understanding to press ahead with the long-planned trans-Mongolian gas pipeline deal. This pipeline would increase Mongolia’s dependence on Russia by taking gas from Siberia’s Yamal fields and allowing Russia to transport gas originally destined for Europe to find a new market in China.

column1: As a landlocked country
column2: its vulnerability to China has been exposed by the prolonged Chinese border closures caused by Covid
column3: slowing a planned rise in Mongolian energy exports to Chinese ports due to be enabled by a network of new freight lines that will cut journey times by a third.

column1: Chinbat said the government had invested heavily in a wider economic policy of privatisation
column2: tourism
column3: climate and rural development policies
column4: which will allow it to diversify its economy over the next 20 years. The plan needs to succeed: in April
column5: young people took to the streets to protest against the impact of inflation on their lives.

column1: Once in charge of one of her country’s largest independent broadcasters
column2: Chinbat said Mongolia would not backslide from democracy. “We have free media and democracy. It is one of the beauties of Mongolia: that we have this ability to have so much different media
column3: from black and white to middle ground.”

column1: Chinbat acknowledged that Mongolia’s culture of ubiquitous citizen journalists operating in a society that is not particularly media literate could be frustrating
column2: but said: “Media should be challenging – that is what I fought for in my period in the media industry. Democracy and freedom of speech keeps our society lively and upright.”

column1: A bigger problem Chinbat identified was keeping younger people committed to the nomadic lifestyle
column2: when parents sometimes want to send their children to be educated in the city.

column1: Chinbat said that at the heart of the nomad mentality was a respect for nature
column2: a skill to survive in extreme weathers and a neighbourliness that means doors are left open in case herdsmen get lost. Mongolian politicians will require all that tact and resourcefulness in the years ahead."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/what-does-eu-partial-oil-ban-mean-for-russia-and-rest-of-europe;2022-05-31;What does EU’s partial oil ban mean for Russia and rest of Europe?;"Ban on seaborne oil aims to cut off funds for Kremlin war machine
column2: but some warn it could help Moscow in short term

column1: After nearly a month of wrangling
column2: the European Union has agreed to a partial ban on Russian oil
column3: with the aim of cutting off funding to the Kremlin’s war machine. According to the European Council president
column4: Charles Michel
column5: three-quarters of Russian oil imports will be immediately affected
column6: rising to 90% by the end of the year.

column1: The EU is banning seaborne oil immediately
column2: which covers about two-thirds of Russian imports to the EU. Oil transported through the critical Druzhba (“friendship”) pipeline will be exempt from the ban
column3: a key concession to Hungary
column4: which is heavily dependent on Russian oil.

column1: The EU is confident most Russian oil flows will cease by the end of the year
column2: because Germany and Poland
column3: countries on the northern branch of Druzhba
column4: have promised to forgo its supplies. Countries on the southern branch of the Soviet-era pipeline – Hungary
column5: Slovakia and the Czech Republic – will benefit from the temporary exemption.

column1: That is not clear. Ursula von der Leyen
column2: the European Commission president who has been driving sanctions policy
column3: promised the EU would discuss how to close the loophole “as soon as possible”. Hungary is seeking EU cash to retool its oil refineries that can only take Russian crude. Croatia also needs time to boost supplies to its northern neighbour through the Adria pipeline. EU leaders have avoided giving details on the end date of the exemption for central Europe.

column1: The EU is paying Russia about €1bn (£850m) a day for oil and gas
column2: an invaluable source of hard currency for the Kremlin in funding its war against Ukraine. A sharp cut in those financial flows deepens Russia’s economic problems in the long term. Some economists have warned
column3: however
column4: that it could have the perverse effect of helping Moscow in the short term
column5: as Russia benefits from high prices. The EU’s lengthy discussions have also given Russia time to find alternative buyers.

column1: Motorists and businesses will see higher prices at the pumps
column2: as the embargo feeds into higher oil prices. Governments will find it even harder to manage the already soaring cost of living. After the announcement of the EU oil embargo
column3: the price of a barrel of Brent crude hit $124.10 (£98.59)
column4: its highest level since March
column5: although it dropped back a little in later trading. Oil prices have already risen more than 55% this year and are at their highest levels since 2008.

column1: Before the EU had even agreed on the oil embargo
column2: some countries were already considering further sanctions against Russia’s biggest export: gas. Before the war
column3: Russia supplied 40% of EU gas but EU leaders have promised to gradually phase this out. However
column4: Ukraine’s most outspoken allies in the EU
column5: Poland and the Baltic states
column6: think the EU should now put an end date on Russian gas. That step is far from assured and will be even harder than talks on the unfinished oil embargo."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/may/31/im-russian-what-that-means-language-passport-invasion-of-ukraine#comments;2022-05-31;What does it mean to be Russian? For many of us
column2: it’s no longer a simple question;"Like others ashamed by the invasion of Ukraine
column3: I have left Russia
column4: my home. We feel like leaves
column5: scattered by a hurricane

column1: “Ukrainians don’t have to pay!” I am trying to buy three shawarmas in a market in Tbilisi
column2: Georgia
column3: but the street vendor emphatically refuses to take my money. I try to explain
column4: even though I was warned not to say this: “I am sorry
column5: I am not Ukrainian
column6: I am Russian.” The vendor looks at the Ukrainian flag pin on my lapel; he doesn’t believe me.

column1: Before 24 February
column2: I never thought about what it means to be Russian. Now it’s all I think about.

column1: I was born in Moscow and
column2: until recently
column3: lived there all my life. But “I am Russian” would literally be the last thing I would answer to the question
column4: “Who are you?” I am a father
column5: I am a creative executive at a film company
column6: a writer
column7: a journalist
column8: a podcaster
column9: a friend … a Russian? Well
column10: yes
column11: but it’s just the name on a passport that I have

column1: I grew up in the 1990s and 2000s
column2: when people of my generation – or at least the people I knew – thought of themselves as citizens of the world. After my first year at university I hitchhiked across Europe. The only time I thought about my nationality was when I was had to apply for visas. I know
column3: however
column4: that this was ultimately down to privilege. Unlike my friends from Dagestan
column5: Buryatia
column6: Yakutia or North Osetia
column7: I could afford not to think about my Russian identity. With a Slavic face and a Slavic name
column8: I was not subject to the everyday chauvinism that saturates Russian society.

column1: I loved my country
column2: but I never waved a Russian flag at a demonstration or publicly expressed my patriotism – it was just not something that people like me did. We thought about patriotism in terms of politics – if you care for your country you try to make it better. So I tried. For over a decade I went to all the opposition rallies
column3: I protested against injustice. Like-minded people and I tried our best to make our country a better place. But I never fell for the patriotic mantras about how great Russia is or how great it used to be and should be again.

column1: Why should I be proud that the Soviet Union was the first country to launch a man into space? Yuri Gagarin or Sergei Korolev should be proud of that
column2: it was their achievement
column3: not mine. Why should I be proud that the Soviet Union won the great patriotic war? My grandfathers fought in it. The war broke them
column4: but they won: they should be proud of that. I know they were. These achievements were certainly never part of my identity in the same way that they are for the “Putin majority”
column5: my compatriots who build their sense of self on past victories to which they are associated only by an accident of birth.

column1: But now these questions do feel important to me. “I am Russian
column2: ” I repeat to the street vendor. “But you are with them?” he asks
column3: nodding in the direction of my companions. Maria Belkina and Kirill Zhivoi are the people who run Tbilisi Volunteers – a movement that has already helped thousands of Ukrainian refugees in Georgia. Yes
column4: I am with them. We had just finished buying a car full of supplies – food and hygiene products to be distributed among refugees in one of the Tbilisi Volunteers help centres. “I am with them – but I am Russian.”

column1: The day of the invasion – 24 February – is a day that will be forever seared into my memory. The enormity and the irrationality of the war was like a physical blow. In my carefully constructed social bubble
column2: there wasn’t a single person who supported the war. We felt like leaves
column3: scattered by a hurricane. We still feel like this.

column1: Some of us left Russia and some stayed. I left with the film director Kantemir Balagov. It was past midnight when we were sitting in the deserted food court of Istanbul airport
column2: waiting for our flight to Yerevan
column3: Armenia. Nursing a glass of water
column4: Kantemir asked me: do you think we should stop speaking in Russian? Do we have to be ashamed of our language? That is probably the only question to which I have an unequivocal answer: “No!”

column1: Let me try to explain. Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskiy both speak Russian
column2: but their languages could not be more different. Zelenskiy’s Russian is passionate
column3: emotional and vibrant – alive. The language of Russian propaganda is dead: a senseless pile-up of obscure bureaucratese. The great Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev made a powerful film
column4: Loveless
column5: about an absence of love in everyday Russian life. The Russian that Putin and his cronies speak reflects this – it is deliberately un-alive. So no
column6: we will never be ashamed of Russian: we speak a different language.

column1: It’s not quite the same with our passports. In the line to the border control in Istanbul
column2: I overheard a conversation between a Ukrainian mother and daughter. They were standing right behind me – they were trying to fly back home to Kyiv. They left for a holiday in Turkey before the war and now they were going back to a world in which their grandmother was hiding in a bomb shelter and their father and brother had joined the territorial defence forces. I listened to their conversation and felt an overpowering sense of shame. My Russian passport burned like hot coal in my pocket.

column1: I don’t think I will be able to read any of my favourite Russian books or watch Russian films or TV shows that I loved any time soon. They all have has the same ending now: 24 February and the robotic voice of President Putin announcing his “limited military operation”. Bucha
column2: Irpen
column3: Hostomel
column4: Mariupol … We will have to write new books and make new films. And
column5: step by step
column6: we will figure out what it means to be Russian now.

column1: Back in Tbilisi
column2: I finally convince the vendor to take my money. “You don’t support the war
column3: do you?” he asks me suspiciously. No
column4: of course I don’t. How can anyone support this bloody madness? But while I am very much against the war and against Putin
column5: I am Russian. For some reason
column6: it is important for me to say that. As I am about to leave
column7: he gives me an extra kebab for free.

column1: Ivan Philippov is a writer and former journalist. He is currently a creative executive at AR Content"

column1: “Ukrainians don’t have to pay!” I am trying to buy three shawarmas in a market in Tbilisi
column2: Georgia
column3: but the street vendor emphatically refuses to take my money. I try to explain
column4: even though I was warned not to say this: “I am sorry
column5: I am not Ukrainian
column6: I am Russian.” The vendor looks at the Ukrainian flag pin on my lapel; he doesn’t believe me.

column1: Before 24 February
column2: I never thought about what it means to be Russian. Now it’s all I think about.

column1: I was born in Moscow and
column2: until recently
column3: lived there all my life. But “I am Russian” would literally be the last thing I would answer to the question
column4: “Who are you?” I am a father
column5: I am a creative executive at a film company
column6: a writer
column7: a journalist
column8: a podcaster
column9: a friend … a Russian? Well
column10: yes
column11: but it’s just the name on a passport that I have

column1: I grew up in the 1990s and 2000s
column2: when people of my generation – or at least the people I knew – thought of themselves as citizens of the world. After my first year at university I hitchhiked across Europe. The only time I thought about my nationality was when I was had to apply for visas. I know
column3: however
column4: that this was ultimately down to privilege. Unlike my friends from Dagestan
column5: Buryatia
column6: Yakutia or North Osetia
column7: I could afford not to think about my Russian identity. With a Slavic face and a Slavic name
column8: I was not subject to the everyday chauvinism that saturates Russian society.

column1: I loved my country
column2: but I never waved a Russian flag at a demonstration or publicly expressed my patriotism – it was just not something that people like me did. We thought about patriotism in terms of politics – if you care for your country you try to make it better. So I tried. For over a decade I went to all the opposition rallies
column3: I protested against injustice. Like-minded people and I tried our best to make our country a better place. But I never fell for the patriotic mantras about how great Russia is or how great it used to be and should be again.

column1: Why should I be proud that the Soviet Union was the first country to launch a man into space? Yuri Gagarin or Sergei Korolev should be proud of that
column2: it was their achievement
column3: not mine. Why should I be proud that the Soviet Union won the great patriotic war? My grandfathers fought in it. The war broke them
column4: but they won: they should be proud of that. I know they were. These achievements were certainly never part of my identity in the same way that they are for the “Putin majority”
column5: my compatriots who build their sense of self on past victories to which they are associated only by an accident of birth.

column1: But now these questions do feel important to me. “I am Russian
column2: ” I repeat to the street vendor. “But you are with them?” he asks
column3: nodding in the direction of my companions. Maria Belkina and Kirill Zhivoi are the people who run Tbilisi Volunteers – a movement that has already helped thousands of Ukrainian refugees in Georgia. Yes
column4: I am with them. We had just finished buying a car full of supplies – food and hygiene products to be distributed among refugees in one of the Tbilisi Volunteers help centres. “I am with them – but I am Russian.”

column1: The day of the invasion – 24 February – is a day that will be forever seared into my memory. The enormity and the irrationality of the war was like a physical blow. In my carefully constructed social bubble
column2: there wasn’t a single person who supported the war. We felt like leaves
column3: scattered by a hurricane. We still feel like this.

column1: Some of us left Russia and some stayed. I left with the film director Kantemir Balagov. It was past midnight when we were sitting in the deserted food court of Istanbul airport
column2: waiting for our flight to Yerevan
column3: Armenia. Nursing a glass of water
column4: Kantemir asked me: do you think we should stop speaking in Russian? Do we have to be ashamed of our language? That is probably the only question to which I have an unequivocal answer: “No!”

column1: Let me try to explain. Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskiy both speak Russian
column2: but their languages could not be more different. Zelenskiy’s Russian is passionate
column3: emotional and vibrant – alive. The language of Russian propaganda is dead: a senseless pile-up of obscure bureaucratese. The great Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev made a powerful film
column4: Loveless
column5: about an absence of love in everyday Russian life. The Russian that Putin and his cronies speak reflects this – it is deliberately un-alive. So no
column6: we will never be ashamed of Russian: we speak a different language.

column1: It’s not quite the same with our passports. In the line to the border control in Istanbul
column2: I overheard a conversation between a Ukrainian mother and daughter. They were standing right behind me – they were trying to fly back home to Kyiv. They left for a holiday in Turkey before the war and now they were going back to a world in which their grandmother was hiding in a bomb shelter and their father and brother had joined the territorial defence forces. I listened to their conversation and felt an overpowering sense of shame. My Russian passport burned like hot coal in my pocket.

column1: I don’t think I will be able to read any of my favourite Russian books or watch Russian films or TV shows that I loved any time soon. They all have has the same ending now: 24 February and the robotic voice of President Putin announcing his “limited military operation”. Bucha
column2: Irpen
column3: Hostomel
column4: Mariupol … We will have to write new books and make new films. And
column5: step by step
column6: we will figure out what it means to be Russian now.

column1: Back in Tbilisi
column2: I finally convince the vendor to take my money. “You don’t support the war
column3: do you?” he asks me suspiciously. No
column4: of course I don’t. How can anyone support this bloody madness? But while I am very much against the war and against Putin
column5: I am Russian. For some reason
column6: it is important for me to say that. As I am about to leave
column7: he gives me an extra kebab for free.
