https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/tuesday-briefing-russian-tanks-ukraine;2022-05-31;Tuesday briefing: What Russia’s failing tanks tell us about how war is changing;"In today’s newsletter: Russian heavy armour is struggling to gain ground in Ukraine. Military expert Phillips O’Brien explains to Archie Bland why that matters – for this war and for future conflicts
Good morning. On Monday
column2: Russian troops began to advance into Sievierodonetsk
column3: the largest city in Donbas still held in Ukrainian hands. The city is important to the control of Luhansk
column4: one of two provinces in Donbas. If it falls
column5: that success – achieved at the cost of the city’s ruination and 1
column6: 500 civilian lives – will be viewed as grim vindication for Vladimir Putin’s decision to consolidate Russian forces in the region and bombard targets with artillery fire.

column1: There’s something else about the battle for Sievierodonetsk
column2: though: while Russian tanks are moving into the centre of the city
column3: they were not able to encircle it first. Cutting a city off from its supply lines to soften it up is brutally effective
column4: as the siege of Mariupol indicated. So why hasn’t that happened here?

column1: For today’s newsletter
column2: I spoke to Phillips O’Brien
column3: professor of strategic studies at the University of St Andrews
column4: about a compelling explanation that could have much bigger consequences: Russia may be running out of tanks. That’s after the headlines.

column2: hailed as a “remarkable achievement”
column3: will immediately impact 75% of Russian oil imports

column1: Few assets of conventional warfare are more intimidating than the tank
column2: and when Russia attacked Ukraine
column3: its invasion force of around 1
column4: 500 (out of a total of about 2
column5: 800) was often judged to be among the most formidable in the world. Phillips O’Brien was never especially convinced by that analysis
column6: and given the accuracy of his earlier assessments of Russian might – in January
column7: he wrote that Russia “lacks the ability to mount sustained military operations and deploy a wide range of military forces at the same time” – it’s worth paying attention to his view of the current situation.

column1: So
column2: what should we expect next in Ukraine? O’Brien believes that Russian advances have largely stalled because the country’s forces are running very short of tanks
column3: and other armoured vehicles. It’s a view he laid out in a Twitter thread on Sunday
column4: and which built on a piece for the Atlantic last week
column5: based on evidence from the eastern Donbas region. I asked him how he reached that conclusion
column6: and what it might mean.

column1: What are tanks supposed to do?
Tanks are powerful
column2: well-armoured
column3: and move fast in open country. “They’re usually used to seize the land between cities quickly and surround an enemy
column4: ” O’Brien told me. “In Russian doctrine
column5: you have these battalion tactical groups which are supposed to have maybe 10 tanks alongside 30 armoured personnel carriers (APCs) carrying the infantry.”

column1: The theory – dating back to the second world war – is that tanks allow you to punch a hole in the enemy lines and cut forces or a strategic target like a city off from supplies
column2: softening them up before a final assault. All of that relies on effective air support to neuter the threat that enemy jets and drones pose to the progress of the armour on the ground.

column1: What’s happened in reality?
Nothing which Vladimir Putin will be pleased to hear about. “When I look at Donbas
column2: I don’t see the kind of breakthroughs which you would want to see in modern armoured warfare
column3: ” O’Brien said. “You want to get through the line and then exploit the situation by quickly encircling the enemy. What we’re seeing is that the Russians may make a hole in the line
column4: but then they are stopped.”

column1: He points to the failure to encircle Sieverodonetsk
column2: and declining numbers in Ukrainian claims of Russian tanks being destroyed. That could mean a change in Russian deployment or in Ukraine’s ability to attack them. But since at the same time the Russian machine has failed to break through after its artillery has softened the Ukrainian forces up
column3: it is more likely to indicate that there are simply fewer tanks in the fight in the first place.

column1: While exact measures of the scale of the damage to Russian armour are hard to come by
column2: Ukraine has claimed more than 1
column3: 300 Russian tanks have been destroyed. The lowest independent assessments are more than 700 destroyed or captured. The Pentagon
column4: which does not appear to have made unrealistically high estimates so far
column5: puts it at about 1
column6: 000 – a number which O’Brien thinks is “probably a safe bet”.

column1: “Those are vast losses
column2: ” O’Brien said. In its usually reliable defence intelligence update on Friday
column3: the UK Ministry of Defence said that Russia was now moving 50-year-old T-62 tanks out of storage for deployment. “These tanks are antiquated
column4: ” O’Brien said. “The Russians don’t have nearly the frontline armoured capability that they had.”

column1: Why has that happened?
The military doctrine that sees tanks as all-powerful is pretty out of date
column2: as you might expect given its second world war foundations. There are many examples of videos that appear to show Russian tanks being destroyed by handheld missiles
column3: some of which – like the British-manufactured Next-generation Light Anti-armour Weapon (NLAW) (pictured below held by a Ukrainian soldier shortly after destroying an armoured personnel carrier) – are designed to strike on top of the tank
column4: where its armour is weakest.

column1: Most importantly
column2: Russia has failed to secure the air superiority which is a prerequisite of effective tank warfare – instead finding that Ukrainian planes and drones continue to be able to stop Russian tanks in their tracks. “They’re far more vulnerable than they need to be
column3: ” said O’Brien. “They’re not flying air patrols
column4: or close air support. So they’re running into considerable defensive firepower.”

column1: How did Russia get itself into this position?
Because it overestimated its prospects of air superiority
column2: and underestimated the capacity of simple
column3: cheap anti-tank systems to stop it in its tracks. If
column4: as O’Brien has written
column5: “we are witnessing in Ukraine the final war of 20th-century militaries”
column6: we might be shocked that the Kremlin entered such a fight without a clear-eyed assessment of the likely risks – but “dictators on the whole have systems that tell them what they want to hear
column7: and Putin has clearly done that”.

column1: As for the failure of analysts worldwide to spot the same flaw: “A lot of people fell for what we could call ‘the American trap’: because the US military was able to do something
column2: people looked at other militaries
column3: and just view it as a scaled-down version of the US. And that is not the case here. The Russian military is an entirely more deficient beast. The US can overwhelm an enemy with complex air systems and defeat their air defences
column4: it still has the capacity to do these ‘break out’ operations. Russia just can’t.”

column1: What does it mean for the future of this war – and wars around the world?
It’s obviously favourable to Ukraine if the tanks are failing
column2: but as Russia’s grim progress in Sieverodonetsk indicates
column3: it doesn’t signal an end to the fight. “If they’re bringing out obsolete equipment they probably can’t keep going with their current approach for that much longer
column4: ” said O’Brien.

column1: “The problem the Ukrainians then have is: can they drive the Russians back? I wouldn’t be surprised if we have a summer of ranged warfare
column2: mostly – more attritional combat with both sides trying to destroy the other’s resources.” That’s why
column3: as the Guardian’s defence and security editor Dan Sabbagh wrote yesterday
column4: Ukraine has been pleading with its western allies for longer-range rocket systems.

column1: There is
column2: meanwhile
column3: a wider positive for those who fear Russia’s invasion signals a new era of military expansion around the world. “The one hopeful thing to come out of this is that this conflict demonstrates that going to war is really hard
column4: ” O’Brien said. “And it may be that militaries around the world look at it and realise that war is fraught with enormous new risks because of the power of cheaper forces. So maybe people will be less likely to take that risk in the future.”

column3: hailed the deal as a “remarkable achievement”

column5: “cutting a huge source of financing for its war machine”.

column2: Sberbank; banning three more Russian state-owned broadcasters; and further sanctions against “individuals responsible for war crimes in Ukraine”.

column1: Six million households in Britain face the possibility of morning and evening blackouts this winter to maintain sanctions against Russia
column2: as do consumers across Europe. This is despite Europe pouring about $1bn a day into Russia to pay for the gas and oil it continues to consume. This seems crazy. Proposals by the EU to halt the payments are understandably being opposed by countries close to Russia and heavily dependent on its fossil fuels; Germany buys 12% of its oil and 35% of its gas from Russia
column3: figures that are much higher in Hungary.

column1: The EU in Brussels seems not to know what to do. A diplomatic compromise has been raised – exempting sanctions on imports via pipeline
column2: which would spare Hungary and Germany – but no practical plan has been agreed. The real reason is that arguments over the sanctions weapon have been reduced to macho rhetoric. They are supposed to induce a foreign regime to change some unacceptable policy. This rarely if ever happens
column3: and in Russia’s case it has blatantly failed. Apologists now claim that sanctions are merely a deterrent
column4: intended to work in the medium to long term. As war in Ukraine shifts into a different gear
column5: that term could be long indeed.

column1: Sanctions may have harmed Russia’s credit-worthiness
column2: but the 70% surge in world gas prices alone has supercharged its balance of payments. Its current account trade surplus
column3: according to its central bank
column4: is now over three times the pre-invasion level. At the same time
column5: sanctions are clearly hurting countries in western and central Europe who are imposing them.

column1: It is absurd to expect Hungary to starve itself of energy and
column2: as it says
column3: “nuclear bomb” its economy
column4: with no fixed objective or timetable in sight. Sanctions have an awful habit of being hard to dismantle. Worse is to come. Russia’s reaction to sanctions has been to threaten to cut off gas to Europe
column5: further driving up prices to its advantage. It is already blockading the Black Sea ports
column6: from which millions of tons of Ukrainian grain are normally shipped to the outside world. This blockade has seen cereal prices rise 48% on their 2019 base
column7: devastating markets
column8: particularly across Africa. This in turn has increased the value of Russia’s own massive grain exports. Russia has offered to lift the blockade if sanctions are lifted. Whether it means this is moot
column9: but the west cannot be blind to the unintended consequence of its sanctions war.

column1: Nato has been sensibly scrupulous in not escalating the war in Ukraine into a Europe-wide conflict. Sanctions know no such subtlety. Millions of innocent people across Europe and far from its shores will suffer as food and energy prices soar. Supply lines are disrupted. Trade links collapse. The victims are overwhelmingly the poor.

The objective – to compel Russia to withdraw its forces from Ukraine – has patently not been achieved. Military aid has been far more effective in that respect. But the harm done to the rest of Europe and the outside world is now glaring. The EU should stick to helping Ukraine’s war effort and withdraw economic sanctions against Russia. They are self-defeating and senselessly cruel.
Simon Jenkins is a Guardian columnist"

column1: Nato has been sensibly scrupulous in not escalating the war in Ukraine into a Europe-wide conflict. Sanctions know no such subtlety. Millions of innocent people across Europe and far from its shores will suffer as food and energy prices soar. Supply lines are disrupted. Trade links collapse. column1: Jennifer worked as a medic in Afghanistan
column2: on contract with the international mission
column3: so is used to conflict injuries and dangerous environments but the intensity and proximity of the fighting in Ukraine has still shocked her.

column1: “It’s more than I expected. Yesterday morning I was upstairs getting changed
column2: a rocket flew by and landed just close by. The first night we got here we were in the basement
column3: told to get ready to evacuate
column4: because they thought the Russians had breached [Ukrainian lines] and were coming.”

column1: She made up her mind to volunteer when she saw Zelenskiy appealing to the world for assistance in Ukraine’s struggle
column2: and began researching her options before contacting Gennadiy Druzenko
column3: the founder of Medbat. “It’s a struggle for freedom and they need help
column4: ” Jennifer said.

column1: Ukrainians have tried to deter foreigners who do not have military experience from trying to go to the frontlines but Martin and Jennifer have practical skills that are needed as the deaths and injuries mount among civilians and soldiers.
There are also Ukrainian medics in the team
column2: some returned from abroad
column3: others unable to get commissions in the oversubscribed military medical corps but determined to serve. Dmytro Rusnak drove back from Germany with a car full of medical aid.

column1: He had been getting ready for this moment for the best part of a decade. In 2014
column2: after Russia seized Crimea and Russian-backed proxy forces took control of parts of Donbas
column3: Rusnak changed his speciality from radiology to acute care.

column1: “I saw I had to prepare myself
column2: because at any moment it was possible that Russia could start a full war
column3: ” he said. When they did
column4: he paused only to put his contract on hold – his bosses were very understanding – and gather as much medical supplies as he could from friends and colleagues.

column1: His main worry when the shells start falling is not his own safety but the worry he is bringing his elderly parents. “Although they are proud
column2: it is very traumatic for them
column3: there are no parents who want to see their children’s funeral.”

column1: He is waiting to get his German medical qualifications certified so he can practise as a doctor in Ukraine
column2: so for now works with Wyness as an ambulance paramedic.

column1: “These years of education and preparation
column2: all these skills
column3: should be used
column4: ” he said. “I wanted to be an example
column5: you can say thousands of words
column6: make thousands of posts on social media
column7: but this means nothing … you have to act
column8: to do something.”"

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/may/29/homes-for-ukraine-teenager-left-limbo-home-office;2022-05-29;‘It doesn’t make sense’: Ukrainian teenager left in limbo by Home Office;"Vlad Ksheminskyi
column3: is one of hundreds of teenagers still waiting for a Homes for Ukraine decision

column1: It has been two months since 16-year-old Vlad Ksheminskyi sent off the forms he hoped would trigger the start of a new life in Britain.
Vlad is one of hundreds of teenagers who applied to the Homes for Ukraine scheme having fled war without his parents. While the Home Office struggles to decide how to deal with cases like his
column2: they have been left in limbo for weeks – and even months – with no decision.

column1: “It is very difficult to be waiting
column2: knowing that my parents are one and a half thousand miles away and our destiny is still unknown
column3: ” Vlad said. “It’s very hard.”

column1: A keen student
column2: Vlad was preparing for school exams when areas around his home town of Krasyliv in western Ukraine came under intense bombing. His mum
column3: Marina
column4: was scared for his life but
column5: being unable to leave
column6: she rang her best friend
column7: Olesia Reviuk
column8: to ask if she could help her son escape.

column1: Reviuk
column3: recalled: “She was telling me that every day they could hear sirens and three or four times a day they would go down to the bomb shelter which was very cold
column4: with no water. It was impossible to sleep there at night with the sirens going off.”

column1: Reviuk did not hesitate. “I promised that I would take good care of Vlad
column2: ” she said. She arranged for him to join her and her two sons in Italy
column3: to where she had fled in February. Then
column4: with his parents’ blessing
column5: she became his legal guardian.

column1: The children spoke English and no Italian
column2: so Reviuk applied under the Homes for Ukraine scheme at the earliest opportunity.

column1: They were matched with Paul Hanlon
column2: a GP from Lancaster
column3: his wife
column4: Rebecca Shepherd
column5: an anatomy lecturer
column6: and their two young children. The British family quickly made ready two large spare bedrooms and a separate living room
column7: assuming the group would soon be arriving.

column1: Instead
column2: two months have gone by while Reviuk and the children wait in a cramped rented room in a flat in Modena
column3: Italy.

column1: Reviuk said: “Living in one bedroom with two teenage boys and one small child who wakes up at night and is also sometimes sick is very difficult for us.”
Hanlon
column3: said: “It’s so frustrating to think that they could have been enjoying the space and support on offer here
column4: but instead we’ve all been spending hundreds of hours battling with bureaucracy that seems to have been set up to deflect rather than to protect those fleeing this brutal conflict.”

column1: Hanlon is in touch with about 40 other sponsors in similar situations
column2: all despairing at the same impasse. “The government’s broad answer to most questions on the subject
column3: ‘because of safeguarding’
column4: is a cynical use of this term to avoid having to deal with the most vulnerable group affected by this war.”

column1: Given that Vlad is travelling with a legal guardian
column2: his case should be one of the straightforward ones. But it appears to have made no difference.

column1: “I do not understand the logic of safeguarding me because in my country there is a war and there is no worse security situation for me than staying there
column2: ” Vlad said. “It just doesn’t make sense to me what safeguarding issues the government could have
column3: when we have all the documents in place and Olesia is a family friend who has legal guardianship?”

column1: The Home Office has been sent a “letter before claim” over the families’ case
column2: threatening judicial review. Vlad’s lawyer
column3: Simon Robinson
column4: said: “The delay in even providing a decision while keeping the family in the dark demonstrates that the secretary of state has failed to make an adequate policy to meet the promises she has made. She is turning her back on some of the most vulnerable people fleeing the conflict
column5: children.”

column1: For Vlad
column2: the waiting means uncertainty over his education. He has only a week left to tell the Ukrainian authorities which country he will be in to take his exams remotely and is unsure what to put. He also wants to apply to university.

column1: Reviuk said: “The UK government is taking the future away from Vlad. He’s a very talented boy. He reads a lot
column2: he wants to study. And right now we just do not see the future.”"

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/may/29/homes-for-ukraine-children-stuck-waiting-for-uk-visa-decision;2022-05-29;Over 500 Ukrainian children stuck waiting for UK visa decision;"Exclusive: sources say most have hosts ready under Homes for Ukraine scheme but have heard nothing
More than 500 Ukrainian children who fled the war without their parents are stuck waiting in limbo across Europe after applying to the Homes for Ukraine scheme
column2: sources working closely with the Home Office say.

column1: Most are teenagers who thought they would be eligible and have British families waiting to host them
column2: but have heard nothing from the Home Office.

column1: Many have been waiting for two months or more without an answer due to indecision about how to handle their cases.

Some are alone in Europe having left home thinking they would soon be joining a British family that is ready to welcome them. Others are with adult siblings or family friends who have been made legal guardians but still have no permission to come.
About 25 unaccompanied children were allowed into Britain during the first two weeks of the Homes For Ukraine scheme and ended up in care as a result
column2: sources say.

column1: Though the policy now says children cannot travel without their parents unless they are with a legal guardian
column2: the Home Office has not been offering a decision or solution to all those who applied before this was set out.

column1: Even teenagers travelling with adults who have been made legal guardians by their parents are among those caught up in the deadlock.
Stephen Kinnock
column2: the shadow immigration minister
column3: said: “I have only this week raised concerns in a letter to the immigration minister regarding the government’s policy on unaccompanied minors
column4: but this latest information reflects the potential scale of the problem.

column1: “We understand that the government needs to undertake comprehensive safeguarding checks but there is a particular question about why long delays are still happening in instances where a parent has already completed the relevant paperwork which grants permission for their child to be placed in the care of a relative.”
Earlier this month
column2: the Guardian told the story of Nazarii
column4: who was listening to war planes flying overhead in his village in western Ukraine while he waited for a decision from the Home Office. A teaching assistant and her family in Hampshire were ready to host him but he had heard nothing since submitting an application on 11 April.

column1: More than three weeks later
column2: he is still in Ukraine with no refusal or update. “The Home Office hasn’t given me any information. I don’t know what to do
column3: ” he said. “If it’s a refusal
column4: OK
column5: but without any information it’s impossible.”

column1: Beth Gardiner-Smith
column2: the chief executive of the child refugee charity Safe Passage
column3: said: “We know of far too many children who are currently stuck in limbo
column4: alone in Ukraine and neighbouring countries
column5: who are desperate to join their sponsors here in the UK. Unacceptably
column6: this is leaving lone children in dangerous and vulnerable positions
column7: at risk of exploitation.”

column1: Gardiner-Smith said the government should expand the Homes for Ukraine scheme to include unaccompanied children by working with local authorities and charities to ensure safeguarding.
Even those with British hosts ready to foster children have had no decision. Among these is severely autistic 16-year-old Timothy Tymoshenko
column2: who the Guardian reported is still waiting in Poland to be allowed to join a British foster carer.

column1: The situation is so critical that sources said it was the biggest point of concern at the latest weekly meeting of MPs’ offices with the Home Office.
Krish Kandiah
column2: the founder of the Sanctuary Foundation
column3: which is supporting British hosts in the Homes for Ukraine scheme
column4: said: “It is disturbing to hear that unaccompanied minors seeking to leave Ukraine for their own safety are waiting so long for visas when I know that there are foster carers like my own family and other appropriate hosts in the UK that are willing to care for them.”

column1: A government spokesperson said: “Due to safeguarding concerns
column2: unaccompanied minors are only eligible under the Homes for Ukraine scheme if they are reuniting with a parent or legal guardian in the UK.

column1: “The Ukrainian government has been clear that their preference is children should not be taken from Ukraine without their parents and that moving a child from their home region must be in their best interest.”"
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/29/ukraine-donbas-donetsk-luhansk-fighting-putin-kharkiv-kyiv;2022-05-29;Fighting focuses on Donbas
column2: but Putin has not given up on Kharkiv – or Kyiv;"The outcome of Russia’s attacks on the Donetsk and Luhansk areas will determine the fate of the rest of Ukraine

column1: After three months of full-scale war against Ukraine
column2: in which ground troops invaded from several directions and missiles hit targets across the country
column3: right up to the western border with Poland
column4: the focus of the current phase of the conflict is back on the region where Russia has been fighting Ukraine for the past eight years: Donbas.

column1: Military analyst Michael Kofman wrote on Twitter last week: “The overall military balance in this war still trends in Ukraine’s favour
column2: given manpower availability and access to extensive Western military support … But the local balance in the Donbas during this phase is a different story.”

column1: How fully and how quickly Vladimir Putin attains his objectives in Donbas may dictate how and whether other parts of Ukraine come back into play. The level of losses sustained will also play a role.

Russia has abandoned attempts to encircle all Ukrainian forces in Donbas for the more modest goal of creating “cauldrons” – smaller encirclements cutting Ukrainians off from supplies and reinforcements.
Last week
column2: the focus was on the city of Sievierodonetsk
column3: where local governor Serhiy Haidai said Russia had committed 10
column4: 000 soldiers and an extra 2
column5: 500 pieces of equipment to attacking the city. There are reports that the Russians already control a hotel on the outskirts of the city
column6: after many days of ruthless bombardments.

column1: If Russia takes Sievierodonetsk
column2: it will control the entire Luhansk region
column3: and can increase its focus on parts of Donetsk it still does not control.

column1: “I don’t think the Russian offensive looks stalled
column2: and while sluggish
column3: there is no good way to predict when it will culminate
column4: ” wrote Kofman.

column1: There is no longer any doubt that Russia plans to fully annex parts of Ukraine
column2: as it did with Crimea in 2014. Then
column3: Moscow declined to do the same with the areas it controlled in east Ukraine
column4: preferring instead to prop up separatist administrations there. Now
column5: there is talk of rapid annexation of the parts of Kherson and Zaporizhzhia provinces that Russia took in the first days of the invasion.

column1: Unlike Mariupol
column2: which Russia conquered after bombing it to rubble – and possibly other cities in Donbas that Russia may soon capture – these territories were largely taken with no fighting
column3: so Russia has been able to focus on mopping up dissent and trying to take full control.

column1: The areas have seen an increased crackdown on pro-Ukrainian sentiment
column2: as well as reports that Russia is introducing the rouble and Moscow time zone
column3: announcements that teachers will be retrained in the Russian curriculum
column4: and a series of sinister videos of locals announcing on camera that they had been through “a course of denazification” and no longer support Ukraine.

column1: Formal annexation of this territory could have huge consequences for the prospect of a peace deal. Ukraine will not accept the loss of these areas
column2: but if it launches a counterattack
column3: Russia could claim Ukraine was attacking Russian territory.

column1: Life in the Ukrainian capital feels more normal by the week. The occasional air raid siren and men with guns on the streets are reminders of the war
column2: but cafe terraces are busy
column3: the opera has reopened and the curfew has been pushed back to 11pm. Since the Russians withdrew at the beginning of April
column4: there has been no artillery threat
column5: and no repeat of the booms from the suburbs that characterised the first weeks of the war.

column1: However
column2: Russian-language news outlet Meduza last week quoted Kremlin-linked sources claiming that Putin had not yet given up on Kyiv and may launch another assault once the battle for Donbas is over.

column1: As with Kyiv
column2: the Russians attempted to storm the country’s second city in the early days of the war and
column3: as in the capital
column4: they faced unexpectedly strong resistance
column5: were stalled on the outskirts and then pushed back into positions surrounding the city.

column1: In recent weeks
column2: Ukrainian forces have pushed the Russians back further but
column3: unlike with Kyiv
column4: the invaders are still within striking distance of the city. Last Thursday
column5: areas within the city limits were shelled for the first time in two weeks and nine civilians died
column6: according to local authorities.

column1: Military commanders say there is no sign of a new advance on Kharkiv
column2: but the Russians are digging firmly into the positions they still hold
column3: with no plans to retreat all the way to the border as they did elsewhere.

column1: “They are planning something
column2: ” said one commander based outside the city last week.

column1: “We may only find out what it is when it happens.”"

https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/may/29/ukraine-must-negotiate-from-position-of-strength-worlds-attention-fading;2022-05-29;Ukraine must negotiate from a position of strength. But the world’s attention is fading;"NA
Russia needs to stop being a threat: to its neighbours
column2: to its own people
column3: to the world. Minimising that threat should be the goal of our policies and the only way to face up to the reality of the Kremlin’s boot stamping on so many faces. The hope that the current iteration of Russia is ready to recognise that other states have rights is gone. Putin’s Russia is not an ordinary country seeking some rational security guarantees. It’s a predator that works according to its own logic of internal oppression and external aggression. With such a state there is no going back to “normal”. No clever “deal” that can be cut to restore previous relations.

column1: As we work out what minimising Russia’s threat means in practice
column2: we may also get to something bigger: a set of security
column3: humanitarian and economic interconnections that redefine how we reduce aggression in an interconnected age. Russia’s aim in its invasion of Ukraine was to reset the world order
column4: tilt it towards dictatorships
column5: impunity and the right of great powers to crush the small. Instead
column6: it may produce a desire to strengthen rights
column7: sovereignty and democracy. In pushing for the worst
column8: it might produce something better.

column1: The first place where Russia’s threat has to be minimised is in Ukraine itself. This will be achieved on the battlefield. Ukraine is still vastly outnumbered in both men and arms. The situation in the Donbas is tenuous. Every day
column2: about 100 Ukrainian soldiers are killed. And it’s no longer hardened professional fighters – it’s IT specialists
column3: sociologists
column4: students.

column1: When I met President Zelenskiy
column2: together with colleagues from the Atlantic magazine a few weeks ago
column3: his greatest fear was that the victory in the battle for Kyiv meant that too many people would think the war over when it was just shifting to a different
column4: more deadly phase in the Donbas. The world’s attention has faded. Allies are being slow to arm Ukraine sufficiently. Positions are being ceded daily because of a lack of basic munitions for artillery. This needs to change fast. Any eventual negotiations have to be taken from a position of Ukrainian strength
column5: not weakness
column6: or else they risk being another deal that gives up all the leverage to Russia
column7: only augmenting the threat it poses.

column1: We shouldn’t be worried about “humiliating” Putin and his henchmen on the battlefield – humiliation in Russian politics and society comes from within
column2: centuries of not dealing with a history of repression and mass murder has produced a political culture that seethes with resentment and fear. All that can be done is encourage Russian elites and society to face up to the reality and the limits of their power. It’s up to us whether negotiations – if and when they happen – take place in the far east with Russia exhausted – or at the gates of Kyiv
column3: with Russia ascendant.

column1: If and when those negotiations happen
column2: Ukraine has to be armed to the teeth to deter future Russian incursions. It is also hoping for security guarantees
column3: including from the UK. But there’s a greater context here too. The Russian invasion is relevant to any nation that lives unprotected in the neighbourhood of nuclear bullies: think Moldova
column4: Georgia and the central Asian states around Russia; Japan
column5: Australia and Taiwan around China. It’s no coincidence that Australia
column6: a country that could have chosen to sit out this conflict
column7: has been such an enthusiastic advocate of the Ukrainian cause
column8: even providing $70m-worth of defensive equipment.

column1: How can you protect such countries from aggression
column2: given they are not Nato members and the nuclear status of the states that threaten them? The ad hoc support to Ukraine gives us a clue: a mix of economic warfare and provision of arms. But to act as a deterrent this threat has to be made clear and be coordinated before any invasion. Russia attacked Ukraine in 2022 because
column3: after its 2014 invasion
column4: Putin thought he could get away with it. The moment sanctions kick in should not be up for debate: a war of aggression should trigger harsh measures.

column1: Moreover
column2: we need to tie crimes against humanity to even more aggressive sanctions. The indiscriminate bombing of Mariupol or slaughter in Bucha should lead to oil embargoes. We need to reconnect humanitarian norms to economics.

column1: So far
column2: the economic power dynamics lie the other way. At the moment
column3: a country such as Australia
column4: which criticised Beijing’s human rights record
column5: is bullied by China with grain sanctions. Russia holds the world hostage to hunger by limiting its own grain exports and blocking Ukraine’s
column6: demanding sanctions against Russia are lifted. In central Europe
column7: a gruesome calculation is emerging: what hike in gas prices are people willing to bear before they close their eyes to Putin’s crimes against humanity? Everywhere
column8: human rights are subservient to economic needs. For us to rein in the aggression of the Russias and Chinas of this world
column9: it needs to be the other way round.

column1: While such measures can act as a deterrent
column2: Russia will also have to change internally before it stops being a threat. Can we ever hope for a Russia that is ready to give up imperial pretensions
column3: live in harmony with its neighbours and even establish rule of law at home? It seems a far-off dream. All talk about “regime change” from outside is foolish: Russia is a great power no one can influence or attack that brazenly. But what we can do is remain steadfast in our sanctions and commitment to indicting war criminals
column4: showing Russian elites that their punishment is long and serious. Anecdotal research from inside the country suggests many think the sanctions will be lifted soon. This betrays great weakness. In his memoirs of life in Nazi concentration camps
column5: the psychiatrist Viktor Frankl noted that those who thought their imprisonment would end soon were in denial of reality – and the first to then break and collapse.

column1: Who will communicate this? Currently
column2: we are not explaining the meaning and intent of sanctions and western policy to the Russian people. If they are perceived purely as random and poorly motivated economic weapons
column3: this will actually risk strengthening the cleaving of Russian society to the state. People bunch together when faced with what they claim
column4: rightly or wrongly
column5: is an unjustified attack. However
column6: if they are shown to be part of a more values-based rejection of Russia from the global community
column7: somewhat like South Africa under apartheid
column8: then they will act as a way to undermine Russians’ connection to their own leadership. It’s no wonder that Kremlin propaganda is always celebrating any cracks in western resolve towards Russia: from Tucker Carlson’s pro-Russian diatribes through to Italian and French “peace” proposals favourable to Moscow. The Kremlin knows many Russians don’t want to feel completely isolated and rejected from the world.

column1: We have launched a form of economic warfare
column2: without backing it up with advocacy and engagement. This is absurd
column3: allowing the Kremlin to manage perceptions. It wouldn’t be hard to get Russians’ attention. A short video from Arnold Schwarzenegger directed at his Russian fans and condemning the war got millions of views. The Russian internet firewall is feeble: you can still use radio
column4: WhatsApp
column5: Telegram and YouTube. The more understanding there is that the Kremlin has led people into a dead end
column6: that this is permanent
column7: the more impetus there is for elites to change the direction of the country.

column1: Peter Pomerantsev is the author of Nothing Is True and Everything Is Possible: Adventures in Modern Russia

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/29/kherson-ukraine-diarists-escaped-city-russian-occupation;2022-05-29;‘We were lucky to escape’: Kherson diarists tell of their flight from Russians;"Their dispatches in the Observer revealed the reality of life in the occupied city. Now the two female journalists are safe in England but want to continue their work
After 48 days under Russian occupation
column2: they were so used to seeing enemy soldiers on every street corner that they thought the first Ukrainian checkpoint out of Kherson could be a trap. Arriving in a long column of cars
column3: filled mostly with women
column4: babies and pets
column5: Oksana Borisova and Alisa Poliakova (who are speaking under pseudonyms to protect their families still living in occupied territory)
column6: didn’t dare trust that they were safe.

column1: For weeks
column2: Russian soldiers had stalked them around the southern Ukrainian city in Z-marked vehicles
column3: destroyed their livelihoods
column4: imprisoned and tortured their friends and lobbed grenades at them at rallies. But after driving past seven Russian checkpoints over 10 hours to Mykolaiv – a journey that prewar would have taken an hour – and surviving a close encounter with a missile
column5: they had finally reached what appeared to be a Ukrainian soldier.

column1: “You understand that it should be our territory
column2: and you see the soldier
column3: but can’t distinguish the military signs on his uniform
column4: ” said Borisova
column5: now in the UK
column6: recalling their escape last month. “And you think: ‘Well
column7: Russian or Ukrainian?’”

column1: The confirmation she was looking for came when
column2: the car window lowered to the greeting “dobrogo dnia!” (Ukrainian for “Good day”). She could have hugged him
column3: she said. “Because now I believed that the Ukrainian army exists. Since 24 February we hadn’t seen our soldiers.”

column1: In a series of dispatches for the Observer at the start of the war
column2: the two female Ukrainian journalists bravely documented the horrors of life in occupied Kherson – from the city’s brave resistance to looming humanitarian disaster and burying the dead. But they also offered an insight into how
column3: despite it all
column4: residents fiercely continued to find glimmers of joy: a tale of young hospital interns getting married; drinking coffee at their favourite coffee shop under the roar of artillery strikes. There were scenes of dark humour too. In one dispatch
column5: they described how a queue of civilians laughed a group of empty-handed Russian soldiers out of the butcher’s shop because they were unimpressed with the quality of meat available.

column1: Despite growing numbers of people leaving
column2: the escalating danger – particularly for journalists – and dwindling supplies
column3: the old friends
column4: who are both in their 50s
column5: hadn’t planned to leave their home city.

column1: Despite writing anonymously
column2: they feared being identified by their reporting. One of their friends
column3: Oleh Baturin
column4: was detained and tortured for eight days and threatened with mutilation and death
column5: and Maxim Negrov
column6: the owner of the online newspaper Postfactum
column7: was arrested and detained. They also worried that if the city were liberated it could lead to further killings by Russian soldiers.

column1: But it was only when they were offered seats in friends’ cars that they made the decision to go. Borisova in a car with her daughter-in-law and a baby
column2: and Poliakova with a friend and her cat. Their husbands and sons remain in Kherson.

column1: “I made up my mind very quickly
column2: during half a day
column3: ” said Borisova. “Not because of me
column4: more for the sake of my daughter-in-law because my son begged me. Now with all these Bucha stories [of rape]
column5: he was very afraid. He said: ‘I will sleep well when you girls get out of Kherson.’” She added: “That chance was given to me and it was too foolish not to take it.”

column1: They left just in time. Just a few days ago
column2: an acquaintance was shot in the head and killed trying to escape. His family were not allowed to bury him. “Now I’m ready to pay any money for my son to leave
column3: ” said Borisova. “And I told him frankly: ‘Don’t bargain
column4: pay anything they want
column5: I will get money for you.’” Her mother
column6: who her husband has promised to take care of while she is away
column7: is dying with cancer.

column1: After reaching Mykolaiv
column2: they went to Odesa
column3: which
column4: initially at least
column5: felt like “a resort”. At a cafe
column6: they drank good coffee and ate fish
column7: revelling in the fact that they didn’t have to worry about being harassed by Russian soldiers. But when bombing started
column8: they realised it wasn’t safe there either.

column1: With the help of Christian volunteers
column2: they travelled for free by bus to Germany via Moldova
column3: where they stayed at a shelter for two nights
column4: before reaching Halle where they had been invited to Artist and the City
column5: a residency on the role of public spaces. Last week
column6: they arrived at Stansted under the Homes for Ukraine scheme after a London-based friend found them a host.

column1: After months of communicating online
column2: this is our first time meeting in person. Sat side by side on a sofa in the quiet Surrey suburbs
column3: Poliakova wearing a blue T-shirt and Borisova a hoodie that says “I speak fluent sarcasm” across it
column4: they seem remarkably calm and pragmatic on the surface – direct and quick to laugh and joke – but as they talk the heaviness of their deep pain seeps through.

column1: Although arriving in the UK was in some ways a relief
column2: they continue to suffer from the steady stream of debilitating updates from home via Telegram. “This news makes us anxious
column3: depressed
column4: we cry
column5: ” said Borisova. “We cry every day.”

column1: Before the war
column2: their lives in Kherson were busy and full. Borisova travelled throughout Europe
column3: writing about architecture and contemporary art
column4: and Poliakova reported on political and social issues. In the summer
column5: they spent holidays and weekends at the nearby seaside. Now
column6: however
column7: the shore has been mined by Russia.

column1: While it was not very prosperous and had fallen victim to corruption
column2: Kherson was “a cosy city and very warm”
column3: they said
column4: and had potential as a tourist attraction. They had a new mayor
column5: Ihor Kolykhaiev
column6: who they hoped would restore the city with new green zones and public spaces. But after the invasion of Ukraine and a battle for the city
column7: on 2 March Kherson became the first to fall. Kolykhaiev has since been replaced by a pro-Russian administration.

column1: After the Russians arrived
column2: they said
column3: the city was “cut off from the rest of the country immediately”. The television centre was quickly seized and the vast majority of residents did not have time to leave. “The next day we were absolutely sieged.”

column1: Living under occupation
column2: the issue of trust has become a life or death matter. “We stopped talking to anyone
column3: it’s a paranoia
column4: ” said Borisova. “You stop believing people.” To illustrate
column5: Poliakova cites the example of a former city manager who was such a convincing patriot with his “perfect Ukrainian”

column1: As Russia’s invasion of Ukraine began
column2: the director of the Museum of Local History in Melitopol in the south-east of the country
column3: Leila Ibrahimova
column4: arranged for a hoard of gold artefacts from ancient Scythia to be hidden. Just a few weeks later
column5: she was kidnapped and interrogated by Russian troops. They demanded to know where the Scythian gold was; she refused to cooperate. Subsequently the museum’s curator Galina Andriivna Kucher was taken at gunpoint to the museum and asked to show a Russian “expert” and agents where the gold was. She also refused to locate the collection. Kucher was later abducted from her home on 30 April and her whereabouts remains unknown.

column1: According to a report on the theft in the New York Times

column3: which dates back to the fourth century BC
column4: boxed up in the museum’s basement. The items were taken to Donetsk
column5: in the Russian-controlled Donbas region
column6: for “safety”
column7: with the museum’s newly installed puppet director
column8: Evgeny Gorlachev
column9: stating that the gold artefacts were not just for Ukrainians but “of great cultural value for the entire former Soviet Union”. His carefully chosen words were designed to erase the collection’s Ukrainian heritage and replace it with a Soviet one
column10: one that suggested Ukraine was back within Russia’s sphere of influence and control.

column1: To date
column2: Russian forces have caused the destruction or severe damage of 250 museums and institutions in Ukraine. Twenty-five paintings by Ukrainian folk artist Maria Prymachenko were incinerated after the Museum of Local History in Ivankiv was hit by a missile. The Arkhip Kuindzhi museum in the besieged city of Mariupol was badly damaged by an airstrike that left paintings exposed to the elements
column3: hanging on walls amid piles of rubble. The Cultural Heritage Monitoring Lab
column4: run by the Virginia Museum of Natural History in association with the Smithsonian
column5: has already logged more than 110 memorials destroyed by Russian weapons. But as well as destroying museums and galleries
column6: Russian troops are accused of having stolen an estimated 2
column7: 000 artworks. In addition to the theft of the Scythian gold in Melitopol
column8: in Mariupol a handwritten Torah scroll and a valuable gospel printed in Venice in 1811 were all have been taken.

column1: Autocratic leaders seizing art as a means to rewriting a nation’s cultural history and advance their interests is nothing new: in 1937
column2: Hitler confiscated 17
column3: 000 works of art from more than 100 German museums in less than a month. Some were shown in his Degenerate Art exhibition but many were destroyed or “lost”. Napoleon had cartloads of masterpieces shipped to Paris from all over Europe: the classical sculptures Apollo Belvedere and Laocoön from Italy; Rubens’s The Descent from the Cross from Belgium. But these latest thefts are in keeping with Putin’s attempts to erase Ukraine’s independent history and promote his own expansionist model of a new Russian empire.

column1: It is clear that Putin sees the Scythian gold as particularly central to Ukraine’s cultural identity and independence. It is not the first time he has tried to claim it for Russia. In 2014
column2: examples of Scythian gold were on loan to the Allard Pierson museum in Amsterdam. Four of the Ukrainian museums that had issued the loans were in Crimea. As Putin invaded and annexed Crimea
column3: he pressed the Netherlands to send the gold back. A protracted legal battle ensued and only in October 2021 did a judge finally rule that the works categorically belonged to the State Museum Fund of Ukraine and not the Russian-controlled Crimean museums (the works remain in the Dutch museum’s stores).

column1: When the paintings that were forcibly removed from Mariupol are also considered
column2: a clear pattern emerges. These works have been chosen to undermine Ukraine’s national identity. Paintings by western European artists have not been targeted
column3: for example. Instead it is the work of Ukrainian-Russian artists that has been stolen. Take 19th-century maritime painter Ivan Aivazovsky. Born in Feodosiya
column4: a Crimean port
column5: he was a leading Romantic artist who painted heavy seas
column6: golden sunsets and storm-tossed ships. The slightly younger Arkhip Kuindzhi
column7: another whose works were taken
column8: was born in Mariupol. His paintings are the calm before Aivazovsky’s storm: landscapes of harmonious tranquillity. Both painters worked in regions that are now in modern-day Ukraine and Russia
column9: and both countries claim the artists as their own. Other works stolen are by Tetyana Yablonska (1917–2005)
column10: a politically active Ukrainian painter who was born in Smolensk
column11: Russia
column13: who lived in Donetsk from an early age but was likewise born in Russia. Russia’s line of thinking seems to be that if it seizes such paintings by Ukrainian-Russian artists then the contested territory they once called home will follow.

column1: There is hope
column2: however. The resilience Ukraine is showing in the war is mirrored by the country’s response to this parallel attack on its culture. At the Venice Biennale
column3: the exhibition This Is Ukraine was crowded with artists

column8: wrapped in blankets and tape or surrounded by hundreds of sandbags. All Ukrainians are aware that their heritage is under direct attack.

column2: students are designing games that explore diplomacy

column1: On the second floor of the stately King’s College London building on the Strand
column2: Vladimir Putin
column3: Emmanuel Macron
column4: Olaf Scholz and Joe Biden are sitting around a table studying a map of Ukraine. They are here to negotiate the future of the country
column5: but they all have ulterior objectives too. Germany wants to ensure the safe transit of refugees; the US wants Russia to cease its disinformation campaign; France wants trade; and Russia needs dozens of sanctions to be lifted. But nobody is giving anything away. It’s tense as hell and the clock is ticking.

column1: This is not real
column2: of course
column3: it’s just a game – but it’s a game with serious intentions. Today
column4: the heads of state are being played by four people attending an event organised by the university’s department of war studies. Several students who have taken an MA module entitled Designing Wargames for Education & Analysis are showing games they have created to a select crowd of wargaming professionals
column5: members of the military and representatives of a few big corporations.

column1: Wargaming is essentially the competitive simulation of conflict
column2: usually on some sort of map board with a variety of playing pieces. Chess can be understood as a heavily abstracted version
column3: but there are detailed
column4: complex games based on everything from the unification of Japan (Sekigahara) to apocalyptic sci-fi combat (Warhammer 40
column5: 000). Wargames have also been used extensively by military forces for about 200 years in order to plan real-life campaigns and role-play possible outcomes. The UK’s Defence Science and Technology Laboratory (DSTL) has a dedicated Defence Wargaming Centre near Portsmouth
column6: while the US Marine Corps is currently building a Wargaming and Analysis Center at its base in Quantico
column7: Virginia.

column1: One of those attending is an expert from the MoD who assures me the Ukraine invasion has been heavily war-gamed by both Nato and Russian military planners. Indeed
column2: a report published by the Royal United Services Institute in February claimed that Russian forces ran wargames preceding the invasion in order to plan an attack on Ukraine’s infrastructure using assets within the country.

column1: The Ukraine game here today is called War and Change and was designed by Sacha Nacouzi
column2: currently studying for an MA in international security. The main aim for the western countries is to get Russia out of Ukraine
column3: but each country also has to secure its own interests in the region. Meanwhile the player representing Russia must seek to end sanctions
column4: reopen trade routes and get back on the Swift financial system. The action is separated into a series of 10 five-minute rounds
column5: in which players negotiate
column6: swap asset cards and work out mini deals. It’s more like a fantasy role-playing game
column7: especially as Nacouzi encourages players to mimic the personalities and policies of the leaders they are portraying.

column1: When I take part
column2: I get stuck with Donald Trump
column3: who is voted back in to power early in the game. I decide this means I should seek to grab the most valuable Ukrainian territories back from Russia so that I can look like a tough guy
column4: while also reopening US airspace to Russian craft and unfreezing the assets of oligarchs so I can suck up to my pal Putin.

column1: “The game is designed to provide a holistic overview of issues considered in territorial negotiations
column2: ” says Nacouzi. “This includes the strategic placements of regions
column3: borders
column4: trade agreements
column5: agrifood exports
column6: economic sanctions
column7: gas and oil.” Her hope is that players come away with a better understanding of the assets countries have at their disposal and the kinds of liabilities they face in complex negotiations.

column1: On a table beside War and Change
column2: another group is playing Guns N’ Money
column3: a game about weapons procurement. Nearby there’s Shooting Daedalus
column4: about the tactics of modern urban combat.

column1: What is interesting about these games is that the students don’t come from the professional wargame sector
column2: so they’re unencumbered by conventional thinking and design rules. “It’s precisely because the students don’t have a professional background that they have a way of thinking of questions or ideas that you wouldn’t otherwise see
column3: ” says the event’s organiser
column4: David Banks
column5: a wargaming lecturer and academic director of the Wargaming Network at King’s College London. “One of the designers of the game about urban warfare was an architect – he’s really interested in the use of space. The diversity of life experiences on this course really helps. They don’t fall back on things they’ve learned or played.”

column1: The next game I play illustrates this pretty clearly. Called Don’t Fear the Reaper Drone
column2: it’s a simulation of drone warfare involving two players
column3: one taking part as a drone pilot
column4: the other as their commanding officer. In each round a possible target is identified on the board
column5: which represents a satellite image
column6: and the CO gives the pilot the command to strike. The pilot needs to follow that order or play an action card to question the directive. Each square on the board has a number relating to how many civilians may be killed if an attack goes ahead. Some of the actions are “signature strikes”
column7: where the drone spots someone who looks like
column8: or is behaving like
column9: a known enemy target but their identity is not confirmed. The outcome of each strike is decided by the roll of the dice and if things go wrong
column10: the pilot could be responsible for civilian casualties. When this happens
column11: the player loses moral points
column12: and they need to draw cards that show photographs of their victims. Repeated failures lead to increasing mental health difficulties and eventually incapacitating depression.

column1: It is uncommon for wargames to model psychological outcomes
column2: and I ask the game’s lead designer
column3: Edward McEvoy
column4: if there has been interest from those attending. “Yes
column5: ” he says. “Some of the experts we’ve spoken to today think that games that explore the human aspects of war and conflict could give new perspectives that may change certain policies. Perhaps they’ll even lead to less conflict.”

column1: Wargames aren’t employed only by the military. Corporations use them to explore business decisions; government policymakers use them to simulate major events
column2: including pandemics; and they have a role in disaster relief. “The UNHCR has made efforts in various cities to help with the influx of Ukrainian refugees and provide relief to civic centres and to other spaces housing many people and aid workers
column3: ” says Lily Boland
column4: co-designer of Don’t Fear the Reaper Drone. “Wargaming and/or simulating some of these crucial aspects of refugee aid work would certainly help organisations like the UN and local institutions to prepare for these scenarios in advance.”

column1: What the situation in Ukraine has shown the world is that the outcomes of military action are becoming less predictable. Russia’s command and control strategy has been found wanting
column2: while Volodymyr Zelenskiy’s innovative and playful use of social media has increased awareness and support for his country in a way that would have been tough to forecast. As Banks puts it
column3: “I’m a huge believer in using historical case studies as much as possible
column4: but a lot of the problems we’re facing in the 21st century are not ones that we have any ready guides for.”

column1: As the world becomes ever more unpredictable and prone to disruptive global events
column2: perhaps new strategies and solutions will be discovered in games like these."

column1: For the last three months
column2: 600 people have slept in the Heroiv Pratsi metro station in Kharkiv
column3: north-east Ukraine. The city lies just 40km (25 miles) from the Russian border and has been heavily shelled since the first day of the invasion. Last week
column4: the mayor of Kharkiv urged the temporary residents of Heroiv Pratsi to return to their homes. I first visited Heroiv Pratsi in mid-March
column5: and recently returned to the metro station a few days before the mayor’s announcement. I was amazed by how well-maintained people’s temporary sleeping areas had become since my previous visit. Bouquets of lilac and daffodils had been placed next to almost every mattress.

column1: Nina Maksymivna
column2: an 80-year-old woman who had been staying in Heroiv Pratsi on my last visit
column3: was still sleeping by the stairs in the same place where I had met her in March. Aside from very brief forays outside
column4: she had barely left the underground in two months. It’s still possible to hear sounds of distant explosions in the area. For her
column5: they were too close to feel safe. The Ukrainian army pushed the Russians back from Kharkiv’s outskirts in early May
column6: but local fighting continues.

column1: At 3am during my night in Kharkiv city centre
column2: I was awoken by a loud bang. Still
column3: I’m told this was nothing compared to how the city felt weeks ago. In Saltivka
column4: the most damaged neighbourhood of Kharkiv
column5: which had been inaccessible for some time
column6: all that remains are empty buildings and burnt-out blocks. Russian troops are still stationed less than a mile away. On my recent visit
column7: I met residents returning to check whether any of their belongings had survived. Men and women were cleaning the streets
column8: some obviously shocked to see what remained. A local shipping company was helping people to move fridges and TV sets. “Long live Saltivka
column9: ” one of their guys
column10: who was loading a lorry
column11: shouted to me as I passed.

column1: Almost two million people were living in Kharkiv at the start of the war. There are still more than a million left
column2: and many more are now returning. The Kyiv to Kharkiv express trains are now packed. For Ukrainians
column3: the decision to return is rational
column4: but only if two conditions are met: first
column5: if your house survived the shelling
column6: and your water and electricity supply are fixed. Second
column7: if there’s still a chance of getting a job. After three months of war
column8: people’s savings are depleted. Many working-age adults are returning home to Kharkiv
column9: leaving family members and friends to look after kids and elderly relatives in safer towns. But it’s especially hard for families where relatives have joined the army.

column1: Compared to Kharkiv
column2: my native Kyiv feels strangely normal
column3: despite the curfew
column4: the not yet fully operational public transport
column5: and the occasional air-raid siren. Yet the war still goes on. The major battles are being fought in Donbas
column6: in the south of Ukraine. In the newly occupied area around the southern city of Kherson
column7: people are being kidnapped and tortured. I covered the Russian invasion of Donbas and Crimea in 2014. My biggest fear now is that Ukrainians in Kyiv and the west of the country will get used to the distant battles unfolding hundreds of kilometres away
column8: and ignore the war. Last time
column9: the unresolved conflicts in Donbas and Crimea became a pretext for the Kremlin’s full-scale attack.

column1: Yet
column2: finding myself recently at a small party in Kyiv
column3: I know this time it’s different: there is nobody in the country untouched by the war. At the party
column4: I spoke to one of Ukraine’s most famous travel bloggers
column5: who is now making stories not from exotic far-flung locations
column6: but from liberated Ukrainian towns. He is originally from occupied Luhansk
column7: in the east. Every one of us at the party had a friend who had been killed
column8: lost a house
column9: became a refugee or is fighting on the frontline.

column1: As a conflict reporter I know that wars cause societies to disintegrate. But from what I’ve seen
column2: Ukrainians
column3: and in particular Kyiv residents (who were previously known for their briskness and focus on work)
column4: have become kinder and warmer. The discussions that prevail are about rebuilding the country for the better. Professionals who helped with the logistics during the first months of the military invasion are now figuring out how their skills might be useful in a new environment. My cousin
column5: an architect
column6: recently called to tell me how his university mates have been united in developing a plan for rebuilding the country’s demolished infrastructure.

column1: I find it hardest to interact with foreign experts and analysts. One veteran reporter from the Balkans recently told me that the longer the war lasted
column2: the less she could understand its goal. Perplexed
column3: I responded that Ukrainians saw the goal even more clearly now than before: to defend cities from invasion while ensuring the fewest possible casualties and to liberate the occupied territories
column4: where the atrocities have been greatest.

column1: Despite the many positive surprises we have seen during the war – including the strength of the Ukrainian army
column2: which has shown itself to be more efficient compared to Russia’s poorly organised troops – for Ukrainians
column3: it is going on exactly as we imagined. We knew that if we were attacked
column4: it would last a long time. I’ve head many times that Ukrainians should manage their expectations
column5: and that “compassion fatigue” is inevitable from the west. But Ukrainians aren’t asking for compassion: we’re asking for solidarity. We’re fighters
column6: not powerless victims.

column1: Yes – Ukrainians are adjusting to the war
column2: and trying to make daily life more bearable
column3: as the people who put flowers near their beds in the Kharkiv metro attest. But this doesn’t mean we have to normalise the conflict. Discussions about rebuilding the country and victory come not from naivety: they are rooted in the knowledge that we can’t afford to waste energy and time explaining why things are impossible. We need to preserve our strength to prove the opposite is true.

column1: In Kyiv

column3: go fuck yourself”. On the label of one pair was written: “Made of 92% cotton
column4: 8% Lycra
column5: and 100% trust in Ukraine”.

column3: said: “It must not be that at the end of the war the world sees Germany as a complete brakeman and loser just because we are unable to organise and communicate.”

column1: Early in the conflict Germany proposed quickly supplying Ukraine with heavy weaponry in a “ring system” – whereby eastern European countries such as Poland and the Czech Republic would provide Soviet-era tanks to Ukraine
column2: with these being replenished by modern German Leopard tanks. Whether the failure to achieve this yet is due to bureaucratic inertia
column3: cynical procrastination or a reflection of the depleted state of the German armed forces is hard to unravel. If you are on the frontline
column4: it probably matters little.

column1: In a speech in Davos
column2: Scholz tried to dismiss claims that he did not understand the scale of the issues at stake. He said the 24 February invasion had come like a thunderclap.

column1: He described Putin’s war as “imperialism” that is “trying to bomb us back to a time when war was a common tool. It is not only the statehood of Ukraine at stake but a world order that binds might to law”. He claimed Putin had already missed all of his strategic goals. “A capture of all of Ukraine by Russia seems further away today than it was at the beginning of the war. More than ever
column2: Ukraine is emphasising its European future.”

column1: He added that “our goal is clear. Putin must not win this war”. His remarks
column2: insisting there can be no peace dictated by Putin
column3: contrast with those of Boris Johnson
column4: who has always insisted Putin must lose the war and be seen to lose the war.

column1: Truss was one of the first European figures to echo Ukrainian claims that it cannot lose territory in the war
column2: but must regain land lost to Russian separatists since 2014. The Polish president
column3: Andrzej Duda
column4: in Kyiv this week said: “Only Ukraine has the right to decide about its future. No decisions can be taken about its future without it.” Although there are different voices within the Ukrainian diplomatic landscape
column5: Zelenskiy’s public position appears to be broadly the same. He told a meeting at Davos that he joined by video link: “When Ukraine says it is fighting to regain its territories
column6: it means that Ukraine will fight until it restores all of its territory. It doesn’t mean anything else. It’s about our sovereignty
column7: our territorial integrity and our independence.”

column1: He added: “This state of ‘hot’ hostilities
column2: of bloody war
column3: can only move into diplomatic negotiations with the authentic participation of the Russian and Ukrainian presidents
column4: supported by our strategic partners
column5: when we see that the Russian Federation shows real willingness and desire to move from bloody war to diplomacy. This will be possible only when Russia concedes at least something
column6: such as pulling back troops to the borders as they were on February 24.”

column1: At present there does not seem to be any likelihood of Russia signalling such a retreat. Quite the opposite.
But that does not mean countries are not coming forward to offer their mediation services. Italy’s prime minister
column2: Mario Draghi
column3: for instance
column4: has assembled a complex four-point plan that was formally presented to the UN secretary general
column5: António Guterres.

column1: The first step in the plan would involve a supervised ceasefire and “demilitarisation” of the frontline. This would be a multilateral negotiation at a conference on the future status of Ukraine
column2: resuscitating the proposal of future Ukrainian neutrality backed by security guarantees provided by major powers. This could give a security umbrella to Ukraine before the end of the peace process
column3: and act as a substitute for Ukraine’s one-time aspiration to Nato membership.

column1: The next stage would be a bilateral treaty between Ukraine and Russia on “border issues”. The language of the proposal points to free movement of people and economic life
column2: de facto autonomy for the occupied territories and a single economic zone
column3: as well as civil guarantees for Russian minorities
column4: including over language. This would be very close to the Minsk agreement
column5: a format that France and Germany oversaw and the Ukrainians never liked.

column1: The final stage would be a grand bargain on EU/Nato-Russia relations
column2: revival of strategic stability talks
column3: a new role for the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe and a revisiting of some of the other issues that were being discussed between the US and Russia last summer.

column1: Russia seemed to take great pleasure in ridiculing both the plan and its proponent. The former Russian president Dmitry Medvedev blasted Draghi’s proposals: “It seems that it was prepared not by diplomats
column2: but by local political scientists who have read provincial newspapers and operate only with Ukrainian fakes.” Yet other voices in Russia think there are aspects of the plan that could be adopted later
column3: when both sides have fought themselves to a standstill."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/kharkiv-hit-by-fresh-strikes-amid-fears-city-is-still-on-russian-agenda;2022-05-27;Kharkiv hit by fresh strikes amid fears city is still on Russian agenda;"Life had begun to return to normal in Ukraine’s second city after Moscow’s troops were forced to retreat
Artillery has pounded the city of Kharkiv for the first time in two weeks
column2: just as life in Ukraine’s second city was starting to return to normal after Russian troops were pushed back from its outlying towns and villages.

column1: Kharkiv’s regional governor
column2: Oleh Synehubov
column3: said at least nine people had been killed and 17 injured in the attacks on the northern part of the city.

column1: “There’s no logic to it
column2: it’s just terror against the local population
column3: to sow panic and to destroy critical infrastructure
column4: ” said Synehubov
column5: dressed in military fatigues with a pistol at his hip
column6: in an interview with the Guardian in central Kharkiv shortly after the attacks.

column1: The largely Russian-speaking city near the border of the two countries was heavily attacked during the first days of the war as Russian forces tried to take control
column2: but they were pushed back to the suburbs. The Russians sent artillery and missiles into the city
column3: on one occasion destroying the regional administration building
column4: housed in a grand Stalin-era structure.

column1: The Russians have been pushed further back over the last six weeks as Ukrainian forces regained control of several towns and villages
column2: but they remain well within artillery range of the city centre.

column1: “For two weeks it’s been relatively quiet … I think this is them saying hello
column2: telling us they are still there
column3: trying to create panic
column4: ” Synehubov said.

column1: The booms of incoming and outgoing artillery fire were audible throughout Thursday
column2: shaking buildings and setting off car alarms in central Kharkiv.

column1: In the afternoon
column2: a deep shell crater was left on Otakara Yarosha Street in front of a block of flats from which the windows on all five floors had been blown out. Police at the scene said they did not know how many people had died there.

column1: Outside the 23 August metro station
column2: a blast had brought down large branches from several trees
column3: and dead pigeons and tangled electricity cables lay scattered across a wide expanse of concrete. Shrapnel had torn holes in a nearby second world war monument.

column1: It was not immediately obvious whether people had died at the scene
column2: and there were few people around to ask
column3: as air raid sirens and the booms of artillery sounded.

column1: A steady flow of residents had started to return to their homes in the city. A few cafes and restaurants had opened
column2: people were strolling in city parks on Thursday morning and this week
column3: and the metro began operating again for the first time since the invasion. In recent weeks
column4: its main use has been as a bomb shelter
column5: with thousands living on its underground platforms.

column1: The city mayor
column2: Ihor Terekhov
column3: told residents: “We will not stop the metro
column4: but we will allocate special sectors where you can stay and shelter from bombing.”

column1: After Russia failed in its assaults on Kyiv and Kharkiv in the early days of the war
column2: Moscow has concentrated much of its efforts on a bloody offensive to take more territory in the Donbas region. But Thursday’s attacks raised fears that Kharkiv could still be on the agenda.

column1: “The Russian troops are engaged in a counter-offensive
column2: and are trying to reoccupy territories that were liberated by our troops just a month ago
column3: ” said Oleksandr Filchakov
column4: Kharkiv region’s chief prosecutor
column5: in an interview with the Guardian. He said he believed the ultimate aim was to launch a renewed assault on the city itself.

column1: Filchakov also noted reports that Russian troops were unloading Iskander missiles at the railway station in Belgorod
column2: just across the border.

column1: For now
column2: said Synehubov
column3: a renewed ground assault on the city was not possible. “They are firing from the positions they have held for a long time; they are constantly trying to counterattack but our forces are holding their positions.”

column1: He said there was not a significant enough buildup of new troops and equipment on the other side of the border to signal the capacity for a new assault on the city. “But that’s right now
column2: and the situation can change at any minute
column3: ” he added.

column1: However
column2: Synehubov said
column3: the main problem for the Kharkiv region
column4: unlike others
column5: was that the Russians continued to shell settlements after they had retreated.

column1: “In Kyiv
column2: Sumy
column3: Chernihiv regions
column4: the Russians fought for a certain period
column5: realised they had hit a wall and then took the decision to retreat
column6: and they retreated fully from these territories
column7: ” he said.

column1: “Here
column2: even if we liberate a place
column3: then the enemy stays in its positions and keeps hitting it
column4: and we can’t properly evacuate people
column5: we can’t bring humanitarian aid
column6: because these places are under permanent fire. We can’t bring in de-mining teams because of the shelling
column7: so we need to push the enemy back even further so they would focus on our positions and not on population centres
column8: ” he said."
