column1: https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/may/26/autistic-ukrainian-boy-timothy-tymoshenko-uk-grant-visa;2022-05-26;‘No humanity whatsoever’: pleas for UK to grant visa to autistic Ukrainian boy;Timothy Tymoshenko was sent to Poland because of his distress but does not qualify for Homes for Ukraine scheme

A British man who has turned his Polish castle into a makeshift hotel for Ukrainian refugees has accused the UK government of showing “no humanity whatsoever” for not allowing a severely autistic teenager to come to live with an approved foster carer in Lancashire.
Pleas are mounting for compassion to be shown to Timothy Tymoshenko
column3: who fled the war in Ukraine without his parents. He is living with his 17-year-old brother
column4: Yurii
column5: in what was once a private palace for the prince-bishop of Wrocław in Piotrowice Nyskie
column6: a tiny Polish village near the Czech border.

column1: Jim Parton
column2: a former stockbroker and writer from London
column3: lives there with his Polish wife
column4: Anna
column5: and their six children
column6: aged seven to 17.

column1: When the Russian invasion began in February
column2: they decided to turn what is usually a guest house and wedding venue into an open house for Ukrainians seeking sanctuary abroad.

column1: They are currently hosting 17 people in the sprawling 700-year-old palace
column2: after four left for Canada on Monday. Among those remaining is Timothy
column3: who is severely autistic
column4: non-verbal and needs strong prescription medication to control his changing moods.

column1: Experienced children’s carers in Lancashire have been to visit the boys in Poland and are willing to take brothers in
column2: but are growing increasingly frustrated that the UK government hasn’t yet granted them visas to enter the country.

column1: Julie Elliot
column3: and her husband
column4: Roger
column6: already have 14 children together – four biological and 10 adopted. Both worked as nurses before becoming full-time carers to their adopted family
column7: and were made MBEs in 2016 for services to children.

column1: Their adopted children
column2: aged between nine and 40
column3: all have disabilities and eight of them still live at the couple’s home in the Ribble Valley
column4: Lancashire.

column1: They and Parton are pleading with the Home Office to let Timothy come to the UK along with his brother. They do not qualify for the Homes for Ukraine scheme as unaccompanied children under 18.
The issue is the subject of a high court challenge and dozens of UK foster carers are anxiously waiting to see if approval is granted for the children they hope to care for to be brought to the UK.

Parton is growing increasingly frustrated with the visa situation. “It’s an absolute disgrace that it is taking so long. There’s no humanity whatsoever from the government in recognising that this is a special case
column2: ” he said.

column1: “What makes me most cross is the safeguarding reason for delaying visas for these children
column2: ” said Julie Elliot
column3: who recently travelled to Poland to meet Timothy and Yurii and help look after Timothy for a week.

column1: On arrival
column2: she found him to be hungry
column3: unwashed and dehydrated. “Tim needs someone to care for him to ensure he eats and drinks regularly
column4: ” she said.

column1: The boys’ mother
column2: Anna
column3: sent the two brothers across the border because Timothy was not coping with the interruption to his routine by having to hurry into underground bomb shelters and was getting very distressed at the sound of the constant warning sirens.

column1: “Tim is in a very unsafe situation
column2: ” said Elliot. “We have been through 10 adoption assessments and they are the most frightening thing on God’s earth but they don’t compare with this process of trying to get a visa for Tim. There doesn’t seem to be a system in place. I was told we should hear something about the legal case in 14 days but that is a long time when you’re a child and nobody’s looking after you … All I’m asking for these children like Tim who are waiting to be fostered is just give them a visa
column3: they’re not going to be any trouble to anyone.”

column1: Anna is also frustrated about the delays in granting the visas: “When the generous people of Britain extended a helping hand to my family we cannot grab it because the documents will not be issued. As a mother I am under a lot of stress and want to breathe a sigh of relief that my children are not under shelling and are under supervision of responsible and kind people
column2: ” she said.

column1: A government spokesperson said: “It is tragic that children have been caught up in Putin’s war. The safety and wellbeing of children is paramount and it is vital we have robust safeguarding processes. For this reason
column2: only under-18s who are reuniting with a parent or legal guardian in the UK are currently eligible for Homes for Ukraine. We keep eligibility for all schemes under review.”"

column2: Ukrainian officials say;"Governor of Luhansk says Ukrainian troops retreating in some areas

column1: Officials in Ukraine have admitted that Russia has the “upper hand” in fighting in the country’s east
column2: as Ukrainian forces fell back from some of their positions in the Donbas region.

column1: Amid reports that Lyman
column2: the site of an important railway junction
column3: had largely been taken by Russian forces
column4: Ukraine’s general staff reported that Russian forces were also advancing on Sievierodonetsk
column5: Bakhmut and Avdiivka.

column2: Serhiy Haidai
column3: said just 5% of the region now remained in Ukrainian hands – down from about 10% little more than a week ago – and that Ukrainian forces were retreating in some areas.

column1: “It is clear that our boys are slowly retreating to more fortified positions – we need to hold back this horde
column2: ” Haidai said. Hinting at further withdrawals
column3: he said it was possible that troops would leave “one settlement
column4: maybe two. We need to win the war
column5: not the battle.”

column2: a senior Ukrainian military official conceded at a briefing on Thursday that Russia had the upper hand in fighting in Luhansk. “Russia has the advantage
column3: but we are doing everything we can
column4: ” Gen Oleksiy Gromov said.

column1: Haidai said police in Lysychansk were burying the bodies of civilians in mass graves
column2: with about 150 people having been buried in such a grave in one district.

column1: If confirmed
column2: Russia’s continuing advances in Lyman
column3: which has been contested for a month
column4: would make it easier for Russian forces to isolate the key city of Sievierodonetsk
column5: which has been under relentless shelling for days.

column1: According to accounts posted on social media

column4: in particular around the railway sidings in the city.

column1: Outside Sievierodonetsk
column2: now the focal point of Moscow’s renewed offensive in Donbas
column3: Haidai said fighting was “very difficult”.

column1: Predicting the “coming week will be decisive”
column2: Haidai said the city was being subjected to a “colossal amount of shelling” by Russian troops attempting to batter it into submission.

column1: After failing to seize Ukraine’s capital
column2: Kyiv
column3: or its second city
column4: Kharkiv
column5: in its three-month war
column6: Russia is trying to take full control of Donbas
column7: comprising two eastern provinces that Russia claims on behalf of separatists.

column1: Moscow has poured thousands of troops into the region
column2: attacking from three sides in an attempt to encircle Ukrainian forces holding out in Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk.

column1: Their fall would leave the whole of Luhansk province under Russian control

column1: Meanwhile the Ukrainian president
column2: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column3: issued a bitter rebuke to the west for not doing enough to help Kyiv win the war.

column1: Calling for help “without limits”

column1: Zelenskiy has said Russian troops heavily outnumber Ukrainian forces in some parts of the east

column1: The heavy attrition on Ukrainian defenders in the east – where between 50 and 100 soldiers are dying every day
column2: according to Zelenskiy – has also led to claims by Russia of large numbers of prisoners being taken.

column1: Ukrainian prisoners of war held in the Russia-backed self-proclaimed people’s republics of Luhansk and Donetsk number about 8
column3: the Luhansk official
column4: Rodion Miroshnik
column5: was quoted by Tass news agency as saying.

column1: “There are a lot of prisoners
column2: ” Miroshnik said. “Now the total number is somewhere in the region of 8
column3: 000. That’s a lot
column4: and literally hundreds are being added every day.” His claims could not be verified.

column1: As Russia seeks to solidify its grip on the territory it has seized
column2: Vladimir Putin signed a decree simplifying the process for residents of newly captured districts to acquire Russian citizenship and passports.

column2: highlighting the need to replace lost troops.

column1: In a late-night video address
column2: Zelenskiy said of the changes to the Russian enlistment rules: “[They] no longer have enough young men

column1: Earlier in the day

column3: Dmytro Kuleba
column4: told the World Economic Forum in Davos his country “badly” needed multiple-launch rocket systems to match Russian firepower in the battle for Donbas.

column1: In the eastern town of Soledar
column2: Ukraine’s salt manufacturing hub
column3: the ground shook moments after Natalia Timofeyenko climbed out of her bunker on Wednesday.

column1: “I go outside just to see people. I know that there is shelling out there but I go

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/russia-uses-orwellian-propaganda-news-vans-in-mariupol;2022-05-26;Russia uses Orwellian propaganda news vans in Mariupol;"Large TVs play Russian state news in support of invasion in war-torn city still lacking electricity and water

Russia has deployed mobile propaganda vans with large-screen televisions to humanitarian aid points in the captured city of Mariupol as the Kremlin has pushed forward with efforts to integrate newly occupied territories across the south of Ukraine.
Videos published by the Russian ministry of emergency situations showed the vans
column2: which it called “mobile information complexes”
column3: playing state TV news segments and political chat shows where pundits support the invasion to locals in the ruined city that still lacks electricity and running water.

column1: The Orwellian turn comes as much of Mariupol was destroyed in an artillery bombardment that left thousands dead. One of the vans was deployed near the ruins of the Mariupol drama theatre
column2: where hundreds were killed in an airstrike in March.

column1: Several of the trucks now patrol the city
column2: mainly playing Russian television news segments. “The people of Mariupol have been held in a virtual informational vacuum for three months due to the lack of electricity
column3: ” wrote the emergencies ministry in a statement.

column1: The mobile screens have reportedly been deployed to places where Mariupol residents are receiving humanitarian aid
column2: Russian documents
column3: and at points in the city where drinking water is available.

column1: “The practice of ‘there is nothing to eat
column2: so feed them lies’ is gaining momentum
column3: ” wrote Petro Andryushchenko
column4: an adviser to the Ukrainian mayor of Mariupol. It’s “cynicism of the highest level”.

column1: “The truth and the propaganda
column2: ” wrote Anton Gerashenko
column3: an adviser to the Ukrainian interior ministry
column4: posting a video of the trucks superimposed over images of the ruins of the city. This is “the Russian world”
column5: he added.

column1: The effort to install Russian propaganda in the ruined city is part of a larger effort at pacifying and integrating captured cities like Mariupol despite earlier assurances by Vladimir Putin that Russia did not seek to occupy new territory in Ukraine.
Putin on Wednesday signed a law that would fast-track applications for citizenship from Mariupol
column2: as well as the Ukrainian regions of Kherson and Zaporizhzhia that are partly under government control.

column1: The Kremlin decision has been decried as “passportisation”
column2: an attempt to annex the territories by filling them with de facto Russian citizens.

column1: Senior Kremlin officials have already promised to remain in southern Ukraine “for ever”.
“The simplified system will allow all of us to clearly see that Russia is here not just for a long time but for ever
column2: ” the Moscow-appointed deputy leader of the occupied Kherson region
column3: Kirill Stremousov
column4: told Russia’s RIA Novosti state news agency.

column1: “The illegal issuing of passports … is a flagrant violation of Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity
column2: as well as norms and principles of international humanitarian law
column3: ” the Ukrainian foreign ministry said in a statement on Wednesday.

column1: The Russian-controlled administration in Kherson also announced that it would begin issuing salaries in roubles on Thursday
column2: effectively adopting Russia’s currency as part of the creeping annexation of southern Ukrainian territories.

column1: Local authorities installed by Russia have also said they may formally request annexation."

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/ukraine-war-government-to-allow-councils-to-sever-russian-contracts;2022-05-26;UK government to allow councils to sever Russian contracts;"Councils pushing to break ties had been prohibited from taking ‘non-commercial considerations’ into account
The UK government introduced legislation on Thursday to help councils
column2: NHS trusts and other public bodies exit contracts with Gazprom and other Russian companies

column1: Councils have been keen to withdraw from contracts amid concerns they were helping to fund Vladimir Putin’s regime. They had been prohibited from taking “non-commercial considerations” into account when procuring or terminating contracts
column2: and they have a statutory duty to find the cheapest deal on behalf of the taxpayer.

column1: Many councils had been forced to select Gazprom as a supplier because it offered the greatest value for money. They paid £29m to Gazprom from 2016 to 2021
column2: data firm Tussell has said.

column1: In March
column2: the Cabinet Office asked central government to review all contracts with Russia and Belarus-linked firms and to consider terminating those contracts. This process has now been extended to local councils.

column1: Councils including Merton and Telford and Wrekin have said they are keen to cut ties with Russia.
A government source said: “Local authorities are not obliged to terminate contracts
column2: but our message is clear: Putin’s barbaric regime should not benefit from taxpayers’ money.”

column1: The communities secretary
column2: Michael Gove
column3: will now write to all councils to make them aware of the changes.

column1: The government has said any costs incurred from exiting contracts will have to be covered by existing budgets.
The west is attempting to choke off the Russian economy to damage Putin’s war coffers and fuel anti-war sentiment among the Russian public.
A Department for Levelling Up
column2: Housing and Communities spokesperson said: “Businesses with links to Putin’s murderous regime should not benefit from taxpayers’ money.

column1: “These measures will allow councils to terminate existing contracts – ensuring public money does not fund these organisations or Putin’s barbaric war machine.”
Research for the Guardian and Tussell shows that councils and NHS trusts have paid nearly £5m to Russian firms including Gazprom since the invasion of Ukraine under existing contracts.
NHS trusts – including Manchester University NHS foundation trust and the Southport & Ormskirk hospital NHS trust – have paid £3.2m. Councils including Portsmouth and Buckinghamshire have paid £1.6m.
Separately
column2: a Treasury deadline to halt payments to Gazprombank and its subsidiaries for gas going from the UK to European Union countries is fast approaching. An original deadline of 21 April to halt payments was extended to 31 May last month. Many large Gazprom gas contract holders are based in the UK and help supply gas to the EU
column3: which imports about 40% of its gas from Russia.

column1: Gazprom’s UK arm is the largest non-UK supplier of gas to businesses and public bodies. Its market share was 22% before the invasion of Ukraine and it supplied gas to 178
column2: 000 sites
column3: with contracts worth approximately £4bn
column4: according to Capital Monitor estimates."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/filtration-and-forced-deportation-mariupol-survivors-on-the-lasting-terrors-of-russias-assault;2022-05-26;Filtration and forced deportation: Mariupol survivors on the lasting terrors of Russia’s assault;"Svitlana and Vitaly lost almost everything
column2: including their unborn baby
column3: during Russia’s siege
column4: their experiences a snapshot of the horrors endured by Mariupol’s remaining residents

column1: On the final day of March
column2: soldiers of the so-called Donetsk People’s Republic entered the basement in Mariupol where Svitlana and Vitaly were sheltering.

column1: “You have 15 minutes to get ready and then you’re leaving
column2: ” shouted one
column3: waving an automatic rifle.

column1: It was
column2: according to the Russian narrative of its Ukraine invasion
column3: the day that Svitlana and Vitaly were liberated. But it did not feel much like that to them.

column1: Instead
column2: it was merely the end of one ordeal and the start of another: a wearying and humiliating journey through so-called “filtration” procedures
column3: followed by forced deportation to Russia.

column1: The siege
column2: destruction and ultimate Russian conquest of Mariupol have been well-documented
column3: but Svitlana and Vitaly’s experiences provide a particularly vivid illustration of the unexpected terror that was visited on this city of half a million people over the past months.

column1: Until late February
column2: the couple lived in a compact but cosy one-room apartment on the eastern side of Mariupol
column3: with Svitlana’s two children from a previous marriage. She worked in a school
column4: he had a factory job. She was three months pregnant and the couple were looking forward to their first child together.

column1: Over the next two months
column2: they lost almost everything.

column1: They had not paid much attention to the warnings that Russia could launch a new war in Ukraine
column2: but they could see and hear the first incoming fire on 24 February from their windows.

column1: It soon became clear that it was too dangerous to stay sleeping in the apartment
column2: but their block’s cellar was not fit for habitation
column3: so instead most residents moved to the stairwell
column4: laying out makeshift mattresses on the hard concrete floors.

column1: Gradually
column2: they settled into a routine. In the first days
column3: there were lulls in the shelling and they could scurry outside to buy food. They bought two chickens from an acquaintance with a garden; with someone else
column4: they swapped a bottle of vodka for some potatoes.

column1: They cooked over open fire in the courtyard
column2: though at times even that seemed too dangerous
column3: as the artillery shells flew in with increasing frequency. Once every two days
column4: Vitaly would risk his life to venture out to a well and bring water for the family. Some days
column5: he took Svitlana’s 13-year-old son with him
column6: so they could carry more water back. In the night
column7: it was sometimes so cold in the stairwell that the bottles of water turned to ice.

column1: One day
column2: when Vitaly began to lower the bucket into the well
column3: he saw there were dead bodies floating far down below. He assumed they had jumped in to take cover during unexpected shelling
column4: but had then fallen and drowned. He set off to find another well
column5: with clean water.

column1: On one water run
column2: a shell landed so close to Vitaly that he was thrown to the ground by the blast. “He came back home with these crazy eyes
column3: he was making no sense
column4: I thought I’d lost him forever
column5: ” said Svitlana. The next day
column6: his cognitive function was better
column7: but he lost hearing in his right ear for the next two months.

column1: How many people in their building were killed? Vitaly counted
column2: slowly: “One
column3: two
column4: three
column5: four
column6: five
column7: six
column8: seven
column9: eight. Eight people we knew personally
column10: just from our section of the block. And in the neighbouring block it was much
column11: much worse

column1: From the blown-out windows of the upper floors of their building
column2: they could see plumes of smoke rising across Mariupol. Svitlana wondered about her parents on the other side of town. She had no idea if they were still alive
column3: and no way of finding out. There was no electricity and no phone reception.

column1: On days when there were deaths
column2: a group of men from the block buried the bodies in the courtyard
column3: working as quickly as possible to minimise the time spent outside. It was the old people who died first.

column1: “I knew those old women all my life. They sat outside the apartment block on the benches
column2: chatting away
column3: passing the time. And then you have to close the eyes of those women and bury them in their own courtyard
column4: ” said Vitaly.

column1: Five times
column2: Grad missiles hit their apartment block
column3: as Russian forces haphazardly attempted to target detachments of Ukrainian forces that had based themselves nearby. Vitaly and Svitlana’s flat caught fire after one of the strikes. By the time the flames died down
column4: everything had been destroyed; even the wall between the kitchen and the living room had been incinerated.

column1: The cold nights
column2: the lack of food and the constant bombardment were hard to stand. Svitlana’s daughter had bouts of hysteria and screaming. An old man on one floor kept asking the same question: “When will it end?” On another floor
column3: a woman refused food. It would be better to end things sooner
column4: she said quietly.

column1: On 17 March
column2: after another rocket attack
column3: Svitlana lost her pregnancy. She was bleeding heavily and feverish
column4: but there was no chance to receive proper medical care. On the third day
column5: one of the neighbours managed to find an ampoule of Oxytocin; Svitlana injected it herself and blood started flowing more freely.

column1: “I’m not 15
column2: I know how these things work
column3: ” she said
column4: when asked how she knew how to inject the medicine. It may have saved her life.

column1: After the miscarriage
column2: the neighbours rallied around Svitlana with the few provisions they had left. Someone rustled up some vitamin pills. Someone else found a miraculously uneaten piece of cheese. She continued to bleed periodically
column3: but felt as if she might survive.

column1: One morning
column2: a part of the apartment block was hit by an airstrike
column3: causing the entire building to shake and debris to fall from the ceiling and walls. As they regained composure
column4: they could hear wailing from the ninth floor
column5: where a woman had remained
column6: living with her 11-year-old son throughout the bombardment.

column1: Vitaly rushed upstairs. He could see the boy’s arms and legs sticking out from under a pile of bricks and debris. He worked him free. The boy was shocked
column2: but unhurt. His mother was dead.

column1: They were not able to bury her in the courtyard like the others; she had not been a slim woman
column2: and it was too much to carry her down from the ninth floor. So they left her under the rubble.

column1: Afterwards
column2: the boy displayed few emotions. He did not cry. He politely said thank you when someone gave him food
column3: or a hug. But then
column4: in the nights
column5: he would let out terrible piercing screams amid his fitful bursts of sleep.

column1: Soon after the airstrike
column2: the family moved to the basement of a neighbouring house
column3: where another group of people were already sheltering. They took the boy with them.

column1: After a week living in the cellar
column2: with only the briefest forays above ground during which the shelling seemed to have intensified further
column3: the Russia-backed forces arrived on 31 March and ordered everyone out of the cellar.

column1: When the group emerged above ground
column2: they were ordered to walk for half an hour
column3: carrying their possessions with them and with shells flying overhead
column4: to a spot where they joined others from the district. Women and children were crammed into buses while the men continued on foot.

column1: In the village of Sartana
column2: Vitaly and some other men were put into the back of a truck that reeked of corpses. Nobody explained anything about where they were going or what would happen next.

column1: Svitlana and Vitaly were reunited in the town of Novoazovsk
column2: part of the Russian proxy Donetsk People’s Republic
column3: where they were housed in a school
column4: 20 people to a classroom. There was nothing to sleep on
column5: but they were given hot food. Soldiers confiscated their phones.

column1: They left the boy whose mother had died in Novoazovsk; his estranged Russian father would come to pick him up
column2: they hoped. His father would take him to live in Russia
column3: the country whose assault had killed his mother.

column1: After some days
column2: Svitlana
column3: Vitaly and the two children were again loaded on to buses
column4: and driven to the town of Dokuchayevsk
column5: where they joined hundreds of people waiting in the local Soviet-era House of Culture to undergo what the Russians have termed a “filtration” procedure.

column1: Svitlana was allowed into the mothers and children room; Vitaly was held in the main hall
column2: where hundreds of men tried to grab a few hours sleep slumped on chairs. The smell was disgusting.

column1: The mothers and children room was hardly any better. Many of the children had diarrhoea or dysentery; Svitlana’s daughter was vomiting frequently. She herself still felt weak. There was almost no food: breakfast was tea
column2: lunch was hot water and a biscuit.

column1: After two days
column2: it was Vitaly’s turn for filtration. He was taken to the police station
column3: where he was ordered to undress fully and examined for tattoos that might give away a Ukrainian nationalist affiliation. Then he was questioned
column4: photographed and fingerprinted. The process took five hours. After that
column5: the family were put on a bus to the border with Russia. They crossed after another round of questioning
column6: and spent the night at a camp on the other side
column7: from where the next morning yet another bus drove them to the train station in the city of Taganrog.

column1: In the filtration camps
column2: Mariupol residents had been told they would be given resources to start a new life anywhere they wanted in the Russian Federation. But when they arrived at the station in Taganrog
column3: there was one train
column4: departing to Saransk
column5: a dusty city 300 miles east of Moscow.

column1: For those who did not have their own travel plans
column2: Saransk was the only option. Exhausted
column3: weary and unwashed
column4: they boarded the train to an uncertain new life.

column1: Svitlana had found a better option. She had managed to contact a friend who had an acquaintance in Taganrog
column2: who agreed to put the family up for three days. For the first time in two months
column3: Svitlana and Vitaly slept in real beds and had hot showers.

column1: They told their host in Taganrog a little about what they had been through
column2: and the woman was incredulous. But they did not go into detail.

column1: “We didn’t want to say too much about what we had seen while we were still in Russia; we didn’t want to attract attention
column2: we wanted to be able to leave
column3: ” said Svitlana.

column1: She was still regularly bleeding from the miscarriage. Some of her skin had attained a blueish hue
column2: and her legs were swollen “like a bear”
column3: she said. On occasion
column4: she fainted. But she did not seek medical treatment. Spending time inside Russia after the weeks of misery they had been through felt like further abuse
column5: and she wanted to get out as soon as possible.

column1: From Taganrog
column2: the family took a train to Moscow
column3: then to St Petersburg. From there
column4: they crossed to Estonia without problems
column5: and made their way onwards to a western European country
column6: where they are now trying to make a new home.

column1: Soon after their arrival
column2: doctors performed an operation on Svitlana that she should have had weeks earlier. Slowly
column3: her life is getting back to normal. The children have calmed down a little. The aches and pains have dissipated and the swelling in her legs has subsided. She no longer jumps in fear every time someone opens or closes a door
column4: and she can recount the awful ordeal she went through with clarity and poise.

column1: But the nights are harder than the days. Almost every night
column2: Svitlana has visions of incoming artillery and missiles. She wakes up breathless and terrified.

column1: Many of the couple’s friends have simply disappeared. Are they still in Mariupol? Trying to start a new life after being dumped somewhere in a far-flung corner of Russia? Dead? They have no idea.
Svitlana does know that her parents survived the siege of Mariupol. She has not spoken to them since the beginning of the war
column2: and they do not currently have working phones. But twice
column3: they called Svitlana’s sister from a borrowed phone
column4: to give notice they were still alive.

column1: Svitlana has no more information than that; she does not know what horrors they went through in their part of the city
column2: though she can guess it was not easy. It was not easy for anyone in Mariupol.

column1: Svitlana and Vitaly are pseudonyms. They asked not to use their real names
column2: or give their address in Mariupol
column3: because they fear for Svitlana’s parents. She hopes that soon
column4: they too will be able to leave for Europe; she knows her father would not want to live under Russian rule
column5: she said. The fate of her parents is a constant worry that prevents her focusing fully on starting a new life in Europe.

column1: One thing Vitaly and Svitlana are both certain of is that they will never go back.
“Return to what?” asked Vitaly
column2: bitterly. “There’s nothing there. Nothing. It’s over. Mariupol is over.”"

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/may/26/russia-crude-tactics-ukraine-bombardment-kyiv;2022-05-26;The cold logic behind Russia’s crude
column2: nihilistic tactics in Ukraine;"Constant bombardment threatens to produce a stalemate that would cost Kyiv dear economically and politically

column1: Russia’s offensive in the Donbas region is making slow progress. Having rushed to launch the operation to avoid giving Ukraine time to bring up new weapons from the west
column2: Russia has found that its depleted and exhausted units are unwilling and unable to assault Ukrainian positions without incurring unacceptable losses. The Russian army has
column3: therefore
column4: fallen back on the mass application of artillery
column5: destroying village after village
column6: which they occupy after Ukrainian units withdraw.

column1: For the Ukrainian military
column2: the current Russian tactics may be unsophisticated and nihilistic
column3: but they are also dangerous. To stop the Russians from advancing
column4: the Ukrainian armed forces must occupy the ground. This subjects their units to heavy bombardment
column5: and is producing a steady accumulation of Ukrainian casualties. The Ukrainians are trying to limit the weight of Russian fire by raiding and striking the logistics supporting the Russian artillery.

column1: The challenge for the Russian military is maintaining troop levels. Moscow has begun an unannounced mobilisation of citizens with former military service
column2: complementing a recruitment drive for volunteers to take up short-term service contracts. The short-term contracts are intended to keep up the strength of units until mobilised personnel are organised and equipped. But with little training
column3: low morale
column4: poor unit cohesion following significant casualties and a steady influx of new personnel
column5: Russian units continue to perform badly and suffer disproportionately in engagements.

column1: Although the short-term military trends currently favour Ukraine
column2: the country faces hard choices. So long as Russia has a significant number of artillery systems and its air defences deny Ukraine air support
column3: the Ukrainian military is forced to remain dispersed
column4: limiting its available combat power at any one point and slowing the rate at which it can liberate territory. Ukraine must also guard against the risk that Russia moves into a large and more overt mobilisation of its population that
column5: while politically risky
column6: would threaten a significant offensive late in the year
column7: requiring Ukraine to hold forces in reserve.

column1: If the Ukrainian military cannot liberate significant tracts of territory or bleed out the Russian army this summer then there is the risk of a protracted conflict. The principal security concerns for Kyiv are economic and political. Without a peace settlement
column2: Ukraine will remain economically paralysed
column3: its ports blockaded
column4: its cities heavily damaged
column5: and investment or reconstruction deterred by the ever looming prospect of missile strikes. Kyiv is expected to lose almost half of its GDP this year. Many internally displaced Ukrainians have been living off their savings. These will begin to run out.

column1: A protracted conflict also risks damaging internal cohesion. Ukraine has so far been politically unified
column2: with Russia’s sympathisers in the Ukrainian state keeping a low profile or enthusiastically supporting the war effort. It would be dangerous to do anything else. As curfews and movement controls are lifted
column3: however
column4: and the political clarity of the need to defend Kyiv dissipates
column5: there are renewed opportunities for subversion. How the government ensures it can provide heating for citizens away from the front as winter approaches
column6: for example
column7: is an issue over which criticism may be justified. But such issues can also be weaponised by Russia to degrade the country’s internal unity.

column1: In a protracted conflict
column2: Ukraine will probably depend upon financial assistance from abroad
column3: but it is also likely to need that assistance precisely when its international partners are under the greatest economic strain. Inflation in the UK is approaching 10%. There is a serious risk of recession. If job losses come in the autumn
column4: it will coincide with people’s renewed need to heat their homes. Energy prices
column5: meanwhile
column6: are expected to remain high
column7: and Russia has so far kept supplying Europe. Under these conditions European citizens may become less supportive of aiding Ukraine to fight a grinding war in Donbas when there is acute pain felt at home.

column1: Given these dark clouds on the horizon
column2: Ukraine’s partners must pursue two courses of action. First
column3: Ukraine must improve its security position as much as possible over the summer. To do this it requires long-range artillery that can challenge Russia’s fires dominance. The US provision of M777 155mm howitzers is a good start. Ukraine’s partners must also help in training new Ukrainian brigades so that the country can withdraw and reconstitute some of its units. It is also critical that the Russian army not be given the opportunity to recover the initiative. To prevent this
column4: it is important to keep the rate of Russian casualties in Donbas high
column5: so that mobilised personnel have to be immediately pushed into maintaining Russian positions rather than organised into new units able to open up new axes.

column1: The second line of effort must be a coordinated approach across Europe to build resilience for this winter and to begin working out the best means of offering economic support to Ukraine. There is also a need to inform the public early and clearly as to the direct correlation between Russia’s actions and the economic pain to come. Russian disinformation will inevitably portray the economic pain as a consequence of supporting Kyiv. Such distortions need to be preemptively undermined.
Finally
column2: there is the question of alliance unity. There are growing calls across Nato to consider negotiated solutions
column3: often premised on trading Ukrainian territory for peace. While negotiations should never be abandoned
column4: pushing for a ceasefire that would lock in Russian gains
column5: allow the Russian army to recover and prepare for a renewed offensive and leave Ukraine economically crippled
column6: is deeply naive. It is vital that the disagreements about objectives between key European partners are thrashed out and resolved as soon as possible. As Ukrainian citizens are put through filtration camps
column7: and Russia plots the annexation of more of its territory
column8: it must be understood that peace on Russia’s terms would be a very violent affair.

In an unnamed basement bar in central Kyiv
column2: Ukrainian anarchists have created a headquarters where they gather supplies to send to their peers on the frontlines and welcome anarchists from abroad who have come to fight.

column1: It is unusual to see anarchists supporting state structures
column2: but they say taking action against Russia is necessary for their survival. “We are fighting to protect the more or less free society that exists in Ukraine
column3: ” said an activist
column4: Dmytro. “Without which there would be no space for activism or underground movements.”

column1: He added: “Putin’s terror is happening [in Ukraine] and it is indiscriminate. It is happening against every part of the population
column2: but especially against the Russian-speaking parts of the population that Putin supposedly came here to liberate
column3: ” referring to the fact that the war has been heaviest in eastern and southern Ukraine.

column1: “His regime is an ultraconservative
column2: rightwing dictatorship that represses anarchists in Russia
column3: the free press
column4: LGBT networks. It scares even the most banal
column5: grassroots initiatives
column6: like animal rights activists. We see the conflict between Ukraine and Russia as a conflict between a more or less democratic state and a totalitarian one.”

column1: The activist left is relatively small in Ukraine
column2: where the memory of Soviet communism lingers
column3: and its anarchist component is even smaller. But from 1917-21 Ukraine was home to one of the world’s most famous anarchist movements
column4: which sprung out of the power vacuum created by the fall of Tsarist Russia.

column1: Led by the anarchist Nestor Makhno
column2: the movement argued for the rights of Ukraine’s peasantry and quickly grew in popularity under the slogans “Death to those who stand in the way of free working people” and “Power breeds parasites
column3: long live anarchy!”

column1: At the height of the movement
column2: self-governing communes existed across most of southern and eastern Ukraine under the protection of Makhno’s army. His base was in Huliaipole
column3: a town in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region
column4: which has been frequently fought over since February. The Bolsheviks defeated Makhno’s army and he died in exile in Paris.

column1: Those at the Kyiv anarchists’ headquarters admit that these are no longer “Makhno times”. Today
column2: the anarchist movement in Ukraine is small and a battalion acting independently would collapse on a modern-day battlefield
column3: they say.

column1: About 100 anarchists have signed up to fight in Ukraine’s army and territorial defence forces
column2: according to Serhiy Movchan
column3: the group’s spokesperson. In addition
column4: about 20 foreign anarchists have signed up
column5: including a Russian who fled his country three years ago. Others have come to Ukraine to work as volunteer paramedics.

column1: “We have a strict screening process
column2: ” said Dmytro
column3: who was eager to stress that the foreign volunteers differ from some of the others who have arrived in the country since February. “We don’t want people who just come here to kill; we want them to understand what they are fighting for.”

column1: Before the 24 February invasion
column2: the anarchists – small in number – would join forces with wider leftwing activist networks. But attracting supporters faced obstacles due to the country’s experience of the Soviet era.

column1: In the name of socialism
column2: mass murders were carried out
column3: a man-made famine was created
column4: and swathes of culture and history
column5: including the Ukrainian language
column6: were repressed. A controversial set of de-Communisation laws were passed in 2015 to deal with this legacy
column7: but many on the left feel the wider population began to associate everything on the left with the Soviet Union.

column1: Then
column2: under Putin’s Russia Kremlin spin doctors and their allies co-opted leftist rhetoric to create pro-Russian political parties across the former Soviet Union
column3: including Ukraine. These parties were used to appeal to those voters who harboured nostalgia for communist times.

column1: Leaked emails in 2016 revealed how the Kharkiv regional leader of the Communist party of Ukraine
column2: banned the previous year for promoting separatism
column3: had received emails from the office of the former Kremlin spin doctor Vladislav Surkov on how to foment separatism and campaign for federalisation. (Since 2014 the Kremlin has been pushing for federalisation in Ukraine as Russia’s way of re-gaining leverage in national politics.)

column1: The recent full-scale invasion by Russia has brought another layer of mud for activists on Ukraine’s left

column1: “Putin has appropriated the word anti-fascist and he exploits it to justify his war
column2: ” said Movhcan. “[Ukrainian] nationalists say if you’re anti-fascist
column3: you’re pro-Russian
column4: but that’s not the case.”

column1: Movchan said far-right nationalism has always failed to gain popular support in Ukraine
column2: but moderate nationalism – which emphasises religion
column3: language and the army – became mainstream after 2014.

column1: Many Ukrainian politicians assumed nationalist messaging in an ensuing competition to present themselves as Ukrainian patriots. This nationalism promotes conservative
column2: non-progressive ideas and therefore presents a “big problem”

column1: “I think both sides of the elite did a lot to create a situation whereby Ukrainians argue a lot about language and versions of history instead of how Kryvyi Rih Stal was privatised
column2: ” said Movchan

column1: Movchan said that this form of nationalism has given those in power a tool to ignore Ukraine’s social issues

column3: ” said Movchan."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2022/may/25/they-wont-accept-us-roma-refugees-forced-to-camp-at-prague-train-station;2022-05-25;‘They won’t accept us’: Roma refugees forced to camp at Prague train station;"Humanitarian crisis grows as Ukrainian Roma families stuck at Czech train station say they are not treated like other refugees
Prague’s central railway station seems a picture of normality amid warm spring sunshine and the return of legions of tourists
column2: who had been largely absent at the height of Covid. On the platform one weekday morning
column3: two German sightseers gaze curiously at the statue of Sir Nicholas Winton
column4: the British stockbroker who helped 669 mostly Jewish children escape from Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia on the eve of the second world war.

column1: Yet just yards away
column2: hundreds of Roma people are sheltering in the only place available to them since they joined the millions of Ukrainians fleeing the Russian invasion.

column1: Unlike other Ukrainians who have been offered refugee visas
column2: these families have found they have nowhere to go and no one who wants them.

column1: On the morning the Guardian visited
column2: two small boys played unsupervised
column3: perilously close to the platform’s edge. Nearby
column4: a young mother lay asleep on a blanket as her infant toddler crawled over her.

column1: The scene was symptomatic of a festering crisis that has unfolded in recent weeks
column2: as hundreds of Roma refugees have sheltered on the station floor and in a makeshift sleeper train that berths only between 9pm and 5am
column3: in what emergency workers say are dangerously unsanitary conditions.

column1: More than 500 people are crammed each night into quarters that were originally envisaged to accommodate 260 on a one-night-only basis. Some have stayed for up to 10 nights.
Volunteer aid workers say they are overstretched and overwhelmed. “This is the most important situation in the Czech Republic
column2: ” says Geti Mubeenová
column3: crisis coordinator with the Organisation for Aid to Refugees (OPU).

column1: Along with other voluntary groups helping at the station
column2: the OPU plans to end its work there at the end of the month in an effort to pressure the government into providing more suitable accommodation.

column1: “We were set up to provide information
column2: but now we are dealing with a humanitarian crisis. It is no longer sustainable
column3: ” says Mubeenová.

column1: Out of sight of ordinary passengers in a sealed-off area of the ornate Habsburg-era station
column2: Roma families – mostly women and children
column3: some elderly and disabled – sit and lie around
column4: surrounded by bags of belongings and protected by security guards
column5: many of them also Roma.

column1: Many are waiting for Czech authorities to decide on their status and whether they qualify for permanent accommodation; others are in an even bleaker situation.
“We tried to register for refugee protection at the registration centre but they wouldn’t accept us and didn’t give us any document explaining why
column2: ” says Zanna
column3: a teenage mother of three children from Kyiv
column4: who says she had arrived in Prague with her family four days earlier.

column1: “We came here looking for a place to stay but instead we are just lying on the floor like dogs. We are exhausted and have no energy any more. I’m just feeling really hopeless.”
It is a tale typical of many Roma arrivals
column2: aid workers say.

column1: Since Vladimir Putin ordered Russian troops to invade Ukraine on 24 February
column2: the Czech Republic has issued about 350
column3: 000 temporary protection visas to refugees.

column1: Many Roma have faced a different fate
column2: driven – according to Mubeenová – by an anti-Roma prejudice that is widespread in the Czech Republic and neighbouring countries. Many Roma who left Prague for Germany later returned
column3: she says
column4: including some who reported that police in Dresden refused to allow them to disembark from their train.

column1: Czech officials say many Roma arrivals do not qualify for refugee status because they are EU citizens holding dual Ukrainian-Hungarian nationality – thanks to a policy enacted by Hungary’s prime minister
column2: Viktor Orbán
column4: of offering citizenship to ethnic Hungarians in Ukraine’s Transcarpathia region.

column1: Some of the Hungarian passport holders claim they were bribed into applying for the documents
column2: not understanding the consequences of dual citizenship. Several told the Guardian they left the Czech Republic for Budapest only to return to Prague after authorities in Hungary rejected their passports as forgeries.

column1: Holding EU citizenship protects them from deportation under Schengen rules while affording freedom of movement between member states – but it also potentially leaves them in limbo when states are not obliged to provide accommodation under protected status arrangements.
However
column2: Mubeenová says only a fifth of the current station inhabitants hold Hungarian citizenship. The fate of others
column3: who often face obstacles to submitting applications or even entering registration centres
column4: reflects hardening official attitudes that dismiss Roma arrivals as bona fide refugees.

column1: Vít Rakušan
column2: the Czech interior minister
column3: has claimed that the Roma influx is tied to organised crime and spoken of the need to combat “social tourism”.

column1: Mubeenová says: “I have sat in meetings with representatives of Prague city hall
column2: the police etc
column3: and noticed the narrative changing – people stopped talking about refugees and started referring to ‘economic migrants’ and ‘welfare tourists’.

column1: “Representatives have told me that they don’t have the necessary documents to apply for protection
column2: but they are often not even allowed to submit applications and that’s not legal.”

column1: A spokesperson for the Czech interior ministry – which is responsible for the processing of refugees – says those at the railway station who had applied for temporary protection were entitled to state-provided accommodation
column2: including at a recently established “tent city” in the Prague neighbourhood of Troja.

column1: “It happens that some people refuse this offer and return to the main station. However
column2: there are also people staying at the station who are not entitled to temporary protection or who have not applied for temporary protection at all
column3: ” he says.

column1: “When an application for temporary protection is submitted
column2: an assessment is made
column3: in accordance with the legislation in force
column4: as to whether the person concerned is eligible. If it turns out that the applicant is a citizen of another EU member state
column5: then temporary protection cannot be granted.”

column1: The increasingly dire situation at the station has led to instances of chickenpox
column2: measles
column3: hepatitis A
column4: lice
column5: scabies and tuberculosis being reported by medical students working as volunteers. Firefighters disinfect the premises three times a day.

column1: Hygiene restrictions prevent aid agencies distributing hot
column2: cooked food. In the absence of regular meals
column3: many refugees leave during daytime and go into Prague city centre
column4: where some resort to begging.

column1: Jan Vágner
column2: the station’s building manager
column3: describes the current situation as “more challenging” than early in the refugee crisis
column4: when more than 5
column5: 000 people poured off trains arriving from Ukraine.

column1: “Even though the numbers are far fewer now
column2: we need to talk to them all individually and work closely with them
column3: but we don’t have the right kind of help
column4: ” he says.

column1: Amid the chaos
column2: however
column3: one man has a relatively happy story. Stick thin and wearing a white cap
column4: Heorhii Stan
column6: originally from Odesa
column7: was preparing to travel to Vienna with his four children to collect his wife after successfully applying for protected status in the Czech Republic.

column1: His relief was sharpened by having spent four nights at the railway station
column2: an experience he described as “tough and hopeless” before being moved to an isolated refugee camp generally reserved for Roma in the Bohemian forest. “I really want to integrate here and ensure my kids go to school
column3: ” he says. “And I want to work.”

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/25/im-never-going-back-the-high-profile-russian-defectors-rejecting-war;2022-05-25;‘I’m never going back’: the high-profile Russian defectors rejecting war;"Gazprombank’s Igor Volobuyev and diplomat Boris Bondarev are among the Russian elite to oppose Putin’s invasion of Ukraine
Igor Volobuyev spent two decades working in the heart of the Russian business establishment
column2: first for Gazprom and then for its affiliate Gazprombank
column3: where until February this year he was vice-president.

column1: Then Vladimir Putin launched his war on Ukraine in late February
column2: and Volobuyev decided he could no longer stand living in Russia. He packed a small rucksack of possessions and a stack of cash
column3: and flew out of the country on 2 March
column4: pretending he was going on holiday.

column1: A few days later
column2: he crossed from Poland into Ukraine
column3: where he spent his childhood years. Now
column4: he spends his days trying to convince officials to provide him with Ukrainian documents and allow him to sign up for military service.

column1: “I want to go to the place where I can defend my homeland with a weapon
column2: I’m trying every day
column3: ” he said
column4: in an interview in the suburbs of the capital
column5: Kyiv. “I am never going back to Russia.”

column1: Hundreds of thousands of Russians are believed to have fled the country since Putin launched the war
column2: and many intellectuals
column3: journalists and activists have voiced their opposition to the conflict. However
column4: among the political and business elites
column5: defections have been extremely rare. Despite reports of widespread dismay over the invasion of Ukraine
column6: only a tiny handful of people have spoken publicly to condemn the war.

column1: On Monday
column2: Boris Bondarev
column3: a career diplomat posted to the Russian mission to the UN in Geneva
column4: became the highest-level Russian diplomat to denounce the war. When he resigned
column5: Bondarev published a scathing letter in which he wrote that he was “ashamed” of his country and called the invasion a “disaster”.

column1: Bondarev said he made his mind up to resign on the day Russia launched its invasion
column2: but it took months to gather the resolve to go public.

column1: Like many fellow diplomats
column2: Bondarev had remained in his post over the past decade
column3: despite Russia’s growing isolation due to a series of crises
column4: including its annexation of Crimea and the shooting down of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in 2014.

column1: “You understand that it is wrong
column2: ” he said in a telephone interview. “That it’s not good. But it doesn’t really touch you
column3: your life. These bad things they happen somewhere far away. It’s not right but that’s how most people think.”

column1: “But now this is totally different: Russia attacked another country. This is Ukraine who we always considered to be our brothers and attacked them in the most brutal manner. Bombing cities. Claiming them to be Nazis and denazified. It’s something ridiculous. It’s something unimaginable.”
Bondarev said he believed many of his fellow diplomats were also opposed to the war
column2: but he never discussed it with them. “It isn’t something you really talked about with other people
column3: it isn’t something you can speak about openly these days
column4: ” Bondarev said. “Everyone is silent.”

column1: Volobuyev said that after 2014
column2: he had started to speak openly about his concerns over Russian politics in the workplace
column3: and while many people were scared of getting involved in a discussion
column4: he felt that most people he knew agreed at least partially.

column1: “In Gazprom there were a few passionate Putinists
column2: but the majority of people understood exactly what kind of country they lived in. A lot of people in Russia are just scared
column3: ” he said.

column1: “You have this internal censorship
column2: that it’s dangerous to say certain things
column3: and you live with this permanently. Ukrainians look at this and they don’t understand it because they are a free people
column4: ” he said.

column1: Volobuyev grew up in the Ukrainian city of Okhtyrka
column2: and left for Moscow in 1989
column3: when he was 18. After spending some time in journalism
column4: he joined Gazprom
column5: where he worked for 15 years before moving to become one of Gazprombank’s vice-presidents in 2015.

column1: As he tells it
column2: he was originally a supporter of Putin
column3: and voted for him in 2012
column4: but his “eyes were opened” by the Maidan revolution in 2014 and subsequent Russia-backed war in Donbas. He wanted to return to Ukraine then
column5: but said he could not
column6: for family reasons
column7: about which he declined to elaborate.

column1: “It was a choice between my homeland and my family
column2: and at that time I chose my family. On 24 February this year
column3: I understood I could not put it off any longer
column4: ” he said.

column1: Volobuyev was a mid-ranking cog in the Gazprom machine; among the higher business echelons few people have dared to break ranks.
Oleg Tinkov
column2: a self-made billionaire who set up one of Russia’s leading banks

column4: Tinkov wrote: “I don’t see ANY beneficiary of this crazy war! Innocent people and soldiers are dying.”

column1: After his statements
column2: Tinkov said he was forced to sell his assets at a knockdown price to an oligarch loyal to the Kremlin. In an interview with the Russian journalist Yury Dud
column3: he said he was sure that the entire business elite backed his statements but were too scared to say the same publicly.

column1: “I have spoken to 12 of the top 20 on the Forbes list personally
column2: and they all support me
column3: there is a full consensus
column4: ” he said.

column1: He said half of those he had spoken to justified their silence by claiming to fear for their tens of thousands of employees
column2: who could be affected if they fell out of favour with the Kremlin.

column1: “The other half say
column2: ‘We’ll make a statement and then lose our business
column3: like you
column4: and then what
column5: what have you achieved?’”

column1: Putin has referred to those who oppose Moscow’s actions as “scum and traitors”
column2: whom the Russian people will “spit out like a fly”. In the current climate it is clear that public opposition to the war makes it dangerous to return to Russia.

column1: Bondarev said he was worried about the response to his statement and said he would “welcome” an offer of asylum in the west. Tinkov has said he has hired bodyguards.
As a Russian citizen of Ukrainian origin
column2: Volobuyev’s position is a little different. His arrival in Ukraine has given him a feeling that he has finally returned home
column3: he said. But he accepts that he has a lot of work to do to persuade Ukrainians of his sincerity.

column1: “All these years
column2: I said I was Ukrainian but I continued to live and work there. I understand that I have to repent
column3: and to prove for many years that I should be allowed to live here and that I can be trusted
column4: ” he said."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/25/death-to-the-enemy-ukraine-news-channels-unite-to-cover-war;2022-05-25;‘Death to the enemy’: Ukraine’s news channels unite to cover war;"State-backed broadcast has strategic and practical justifications but some see it as dangerous monopoly
In an age of social media and satellite television
column2: the singular wartime news bulletin evokes images of families tuning in to the radio during the second world war. But in Ukraine
column3: the state-backed broadcast has remerged
column4: albeit with a 21st-century spin.

column1: Shortly after Russia invaded
column2: the country’s main TV channels started broadcasting the same content 24 hours a day
column3: nicknamed the United News telemarathon. Each channel has a daily slot on the broadcast
column4: which is shown simultaneously on all the channels.

column1: United News was initially aired by five channels owned by various Ukrainian oligarchs as well as the publicly owned channels. It has since been signed into law and now includes all Ukrainian channels that used to show news.
The head of Ukraine’s parliamentary broadcasting committee said he believed the arrangement should continue until the war ends.
While some say there are critical strategic justifications for the telemarathon
column2: others argue that it amounts to a monopoly of the information space by President Volodymyr Zelenskiy’s team and could be exploited for political purposes.

column1: “The telemarathon is the information war equivalent of our anti-aircraft systems and I think it’s the most optimal option for Ukraine right now
column2: ” said Svitlana Ostapa
column3: the deputy head of Detector Media
column4: a media monitoring organisation that tracks propaganda
column5: disinformation and political interference in Ukraine. “It helps protect Ukrainians from Russian fakes and prevents panic among the population.

column2: Russian propagandists and their allies released a barrage of disinformation about the Maidan revolution
column3: Crimea and events in eastern Ukraine that experts said worked to destabilise the country.

column1: There are also more practical reasons for the channels working together. “Most of the journalists left Kyiv and the channels simply could not cope individually
column2: ” Ostapa said. “The top ministers and officials do not have the time to comment to more than half a dozen channels
column3: and this format means they are communicating with the population once a day and not being seen to favour one channel.”

column1: The language used by Ukraine’s TV presenters has changed dramatically
column2: reflecting usage among the wider population. Russian soldiers are often called “occupiers”
column3: “terrorists”
column4: “orcs” and “Rashists” – a combination of the words Russian and fascist.

column1: Guests are welcomed with the greeting “Glory to Ukraine!”
column2: to which they answer “Glory to the heroes!”. The famous words of a Ukrainian soldier tasked with defending Snake Island in the Black Sea
column3: who was recorded over the military radio saying “Russian ship go fuck yourself”
column4: are mentioned without the swearword being censored
column5: and the presenters regularly end their segments with “Death to the enemy!”
column6: a historic Ukrainian wartime slogan.

column1: The 24-hour wartime news focuses on the Ukrainian military’s victories
column2: its defence of Ukraine’s frontlines and Russia’s war crimes. The abrupt collapse of Ukraine’s economy in February means there is almost no advertising. Commercial breaks advertise hotlines for finding missing loved ones and reporting war crimes
column3: as well as videos produced by normal Ukrainians
column4: the Ukrainian army press service and the presidential office about the resistance of Ukrainian soldiers and citizens.

column1: Ostapa said the language and messaging were discussed in editorial meetings between all the channels involved
column2: the culture ministry and the national broadcasting council
column3: and there was now a move to ban slogans containing swearwords. The overarching editorial message of the telemarathon is Ukrainian resistance in the face of Russian brutality
column4: Ostapa wrote in one her analysis pieces.

column1: The TV channel heads have rejected accusations that the authorities dictate the content
column2: saying dialogue with officials includes things such as censoring information that reveals Ukrainian military positions. And since May
column3: Ukrainians looking for an alternative to news can tune in to other channels that show films and cartoons about good winning out against evil.

column1: But some see the unified TV coverage as propagandistic and point to the fact that airtime is now almost exclusively given to people close to the president
column2: including regular comedy sketches by the president’s former comic colleagues.

column1: “The telemarathon is an attempt by the presidential office to gain even greater control over the information space
column2: ” said Aksenyia Kurina
column3: a journalist and campaigner who has spent her career focusing on censorship in Ukraine. “We may soon find ourselves in a heavily censored information space.”

column1: Zelenskiy won the 2019 Ukrainian presidential election with more than 70% of the vote
column2: thanks in large part
column3: said Kurina
column4: to his innovative digital campaign. Zelenskiy’s party also controls Ukraine’s parliament.

column1: Though Ukraine’s media have celebrated a marked change in their president since the invasion
column2: Zelenskiy was on terse terms with some journalists before the war. He was known to publicly display disdain towards journalists who asked critical questions
column3: and his press service ostracised some reporters for critical coverage.

column1: “The telemarathon does not reflect reality
column2: it forms a picture that the authorities would like to see. This is dangerous
column3: because at some point the authorities may begin to believe in their own propaganda
column4: ” said Kurina. “I understand that many journalists are not able to cope with their emotions at the moment
column5: for many this is a personal traumatic experience
column6: but it is important to remember professional ethics and not to allow hate speech.”

column1: Notably
column2: three channels owned by Ukraine’s former president Petro Poroshenko and that are close to his associates have not been given slots and therefore do not contribute to the telemarathon’s content or editorial meetings. Poroshenko was charged with treason after Zelenskiy came to power
column3: a case that the former president says is politically motivated.

column1: At first
column2: Poroshenko’s channels split their coverage 50-50 between the telemarathon and their own content. But since in mid-March all channels – except for those dedicated to light entertainment – are obliged to stream the telemarathon.

column1: The head of one of Poroshenko’s channels has said that despite their appeals to be included
column2: they are still waiting to hear from the authorities."

column2: ” he said.

column1: “The invasion of Ukraine didn’t come out of the blue. The world has been increasingly engaged in a struggle between two systems of governance that are diametrically opposed to each other: open society and closed society.”

The 91-year-old former hedge fund owner said the tide had started to turn against open societies in the aftermath of the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the US in 2001. “Repressive regimes are now in the ascendant and open societies are under siege. Today China and Russia present the greatest threat to open society.”

column1: Soros said Putin had won Xi’s agreement to the Russian invasion at the opening of the Beijing Winter Olympics in early February. But he insisted the Chinese leader was not as strong as he believed.

column1: There was a gruelling artillery duel between Ukrainian and Russian troops

column4: stood Ivan Mishchenko’s farmhouse

column3: ” said Mishchenko
column5: whose farm lies in the countryside around Pochepyn
column6: a small village north of Kyiv.

column1: “They were shooting so hard
column2: as if it was some kind of computer game. The first two days I stayed in the house
column3: but then it was so insufferable that I had to leave. When I returned
column4: I was in shock. My house
column5: the warehouse
column6: the barns ... were all destroyed. I lost everything.”

column1: Mishchenko
column2: who has livestock and grain fields
column3: is one of hundreds of Ukrainian farmers whose businesses were devastated by a war that has unleashed economic devastation in the country and threatened famine elsewhere. And like other farmers in Ukraine
column4: his few hectares of surviving wheat fields cannot be harvested due to the shortage of fuel in the region and after his harvester and other machinery were destroyed by shelling.

column1: Silos and ports across Ukraine are brimming with more than 20 million metric tonnes of grain and corn that has nowhere to go

column1: Ukraine used to export most of its goods through seaports but since Russia invaded the country
column2: it has been forced to export by train or via its small Danube River ports. As a result
column3: global wheat prices leaped by 20% in March
column4: owing to the direct impact of the war on wheat production
column5: with the world facing a worsening state of food insecurity and malnutrition
column6: at a time when 42 million people were already one step away from famine.

column3: which feeds 125 million people and buys 50% of its grain from Ukraine
column4: appealed to the Russian president
column5: Vladimir Putin: “If you have any heart at all
column6: please open these ports.”

column1: “This is not just about Ukraine
column2: ” Beasley said last week. “This is about the poorest of the poor who are on the brink of starvation as we speak.”

column2: ” says Mishchenko. “We already have problems

column4: 15% of its corn

column1: Last year
column2: Ukraine produced about 33m tonnes of wheat

“He volunteered to join the army and was killed defending Marakiv.”

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/24/ukraine-destruction-how-the-guardian-documented-russia-use-of-weapons;2022-05-24;NA;"Cluster bombs
column2: fléchettes and unguided missiles on residential areas: as prosecutors investigate alleged Russian war crimes in Ukraine
column3: our reporters reveal the evidence they discovered on the ground

column1: At about midnight on 1 March 2022
column2: a Russian air force jet dropped a series of 250kg Soviet-era explosives over Borodyanka
column3: north of Kyiv. They were powerful FAB-250 bombs
column4: designed to hit military targets such as enemy fortifications and bunkers. There were no such structures
column5: however
column6: in this quiet town of 13
column7: 000 people.

column1: The bombs fell on at least five residential buildings
column2: splitting them in two. Dozens of bodies were found under the rubble when the Russians withdrew from the Kyiv region in early April
column3: leaving in their path a gigantic crime scene that Ukrainian prosecutors investigating alleged war crimes by Russia and its president
column4: Vladimir Putin
column5: have been working on for weeks.

column1: A war crime is a violation of the laws of war
column2: a component of international law established by the Hague conventions of 1899 and 1907 and further defined by the Geneva conventions of 1949
column3: including the intentional killing of prisoners of war and civilians
column4: torture and the use of illegal weapons. The Guardian has visited the small towns and villages north of Kyiv razed to the ground during the Russian occupation and reviewed evidence found there – as well as other materials from Ukrainian prosecutors – of imprecise munitions such as the FAB-250
column5: metal dart shells and cluster bombs whose use led to the deaths of hundreds of civilians.

column1: The FAB-250s are among the bombs most used by the Russians against Ukrainian towns in the Kyiv oblast
column2: such as Bucha
column3: Hostomel and Borodyanka. According to investigators
column4: at least eight buildings in the towns north of Kyiv were destroyed by these powerful
column5: unguided bombs
column6: causing hundreds of deaths. The FAB-250 is a very inaccurate
column7: airdropped bomb
column8: largely employed by the former Soviet Union in its war in Afghanistan and by Russia in Syria.

column1: The tactics appear to have come directly from the civil war in Syria
column2: which Moscow joined in 2015 to support the Syrian president
column3: Bashar al-Assad. The buildings destroyed in Borodyanka by the FAB-250s exhibit levels of destruction very similar to the razed buildings in Aleppo.

column1: The FAB-250s freefall from bombers and
column2: in their design at least
column3: are intended for use against surface military fortification. Although Russia says it is trying to destroy military targets
column4: evidence collected or reviewed by the Guardian during visits to Bucha
column5: Hostomel and Borodyanka
column6: and independently verified by weapons experts
column7: shows these bombs were dropped on residential buildings and civilian infrastructure.

column1: Pathologists and coroners carrying out postmortems on bodies found in mass graves in the region north of Kyiv have found tiny metal arrows embedded in people’s heads and chests. Independent weapons experts who reviewed pictures of the metal arrows found in the bodies have confirmed that they were fléchettes
column2: an anti-personnel weapon widely used during the first world war.

column1: These small metal darts are contained in field gun shells of a type fired by Russian artillery in the towns of Bucha and Irpin. Each shell can contain up to 8
column2: 000 fléchettes. Once fired
column3: the shells burst when a timed fuse detonates and explodes above the ground. The fléchette darts
column4: typically 3-4cm in length
column5: disperse in a wide conical arch spanning 300 metres by 100 metres.

column1: On impact with a victim’s body
column2: the dart loses rigidity and bends into a hook
column3: while the arrow’s rear
column4: made of four fins
column5: often breaks away and causes a second wound. The munitions are not prohibited under international law
column6: despite human rights groups long seeking a ban on fléchette shells. However
column7: the use of imprecise lethal weapons in densely populated civilian areas is a violation of humanitarian law.

Fléchettes were dropped during the first world war from the then novel aeroplanes to attack infantry and pierce their helmets. They were not widely used during the second world war
column2: but re-emerged in the Vietnam war when the US employed a version of them packed into plastic cups.

column1: The Guardian also found a number of fléchettes in Irpin
column2: where several residents said they had found them nailed on to their cars.

column1: Bellingcat
column2: a nonprofit online journalism collective dedicated to war crime investigations
column3: reviewed some of the pictures collected by the Guardian and confirmed the presence of cluster bombs in towns and villages occupied by the Russians in Ukraine.

column1: Russia’s withdrawal from the Kyiv region in early April has revealed evidence of cluster munitions – shells or bombs that release dozens of smaller munitions – in the wreckage of cars
column2: streets and civilian buildings and in dead bodies. The weapons
column3: banned in more than 100 countries (but not the US
column4: Russia or Ukraine) under a 2008 treaty called the convention on cluster munitions
column5: were unleashed in areas with no military personnel and no military infrastructure. Russia has repeatedly denied targeting civilians and has said Ukrainian allegations of war crimes are concocted.

column1: The submunitions in a cluster bomb are designed to release over a wide area
column2: but they do not always explode
column3: posing a future risk to civilians.

column1: The wrecks of dozens of cars in Bucha and Borodyanka
column2: seen and photographed by the Guardian and reviewed by experts
column3: show the characteristic holes caused by submunitions from cluster bombs used by the Russian military. The use of cluster bombs and cluster munitions has also been widely reported in other areas of Ukraine. When a team from Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) entered an oncology hospital in Mykolaiv
column4: south-east Ukraine
column5: on 4 April
column6: several explosions took place in close proximity to the staff.

column1: The Guardian found a Russian cluster rocket near a farm village in Hostomel and fragments of tail fins from RBK-500 cluster bombs with PTAB-1M submunitions and cluster rockets in other towns north of Kyiv. The impact of cluster bombs in these areas was so large that in some cases they hit and killed numerous animals. A short distance from the cluster bomb found at Hostomel
column2: the carcasses of two horses show clear marks of its submunitions on their bodies.

column1: In Borodyanka
column2: prosecutors have spent days exhuming dozens of victims who were hastily buried in local cemeteries by relatives during the bombing
column3: because
column4: according to the authorities
column5: many of them were killed by cluster bombs. Coroners in areas north of Kyiv confirmed to the Guardian that they had found fragments of cluster munitions embedded in bodies dug out in the area. The findings are being classified by coroners and will be reported to The Hague
column6: where charges of war crimes committed by Russia could be formalised in the coming months."
