This blog is now closed

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/bravo-reopened-kyiv-opera-drowns-out-russian-artillery;2022-05-21;Bravo! Music at reopened Kyiv opera replaces noise of Russian artillery;Three months after the invasion
column2: the capital’s grand old venue stages an emotional comeback

column1: The lights dimmed
column2: a hush came over the auditorium and the orchestra struck up the first notes of the overture. This ritual has taken place thousands of times at Kyiv’s grand opera house over the past century
column3: but the performance on Saturday afternoon was something out of the ordinary.

column1: In a city that over the past three months became used to wailing air-raid sirens and the thuds of artillery from the suburbs
column2: the audience was instead treated to the frothy melodies of Rossini’s The Barber of Seville.

column1: It marked the first performance since the missiles and shells of Vladimir Putin’s invasion rudely interrupted the opera season – and everything else in Ukraine – in the early hours of 24 February.
Now
column2: less than three months later and with fierce battles still raging in the eastern part of the country
column3: the opera is back
column4: although with some changes. Performances will only take place on weekend afternoons
column5: a maximum of 300 tickets are sold
column6: and the audience has to be ready to move quickly to the basement cloakrooms if air-raid sirens sound during a performance.

column1: Saturday’s audience was a mix of couples enjoying their first opportunity for weeks to wear their most elegant outfits
column2: and soldiers in military fatigues taking a break from their army service for some high culture.

column1: Only the stalls were full
column2: with the four tiers of gilded balconies off-limits to ensure an evacuation could take place more quickly if needed.

column1: “I can’t say opera is my usual entertainment
column2: but it is an incredible feeling to hear this music and to be in a different world for a little while
column3: before coming back to our reality
column4: ” said Volodymyr
column5: a soldier who only wanted to give his first name.

column1: Many of the opera troupe are still abroad
column2: and some in the orchestra are fighting on the frontline or serving in the territorial defence forces.

column1: Oleksii Potiomkin
column2: the principal dancer of the ballet
column3: has joined up and is serving in the army
column4: posting daily updates on Instagram.

column1: But enough artists and technical staff are back at work for the company to put on full-scale opera stagings.
Soprano Olha Fomichova
column2: who sang the lead role of Rosina on Saturday
column3: struggled to hold back tears as she spoke of her emotions before going on stage.

column1: “I had the feeling this morning that I was coming to sing a premiere
column2: even though I have been singing this role for years. I feel like I’m coming out on to this stage
column3: which I know so well
column4: for the first time
column5: ” she said.

column1: Fomichova mostly stayed in Kyiv during the invasion but sent her son to safety in Germany. She saw him recently when she travelled there to take part in a charity gala to help Ukraine
column2: and both the family reunion and the concert were emotional
column3: she said.

column1: “When you take a Ukrainian flag on to the stage for the curtain call and you are met with a 10-minute standing ovation
column2: I don’t have words to describe the feeling
column3: ” she said.

column1: Over the past three months
column2: the soloists have kept in touch in a chat group on Viber
column3: swapping stories about how the war was going for them
column4: said Natalia Nykolaishyn
column5: a soprano who has been at the theatre for 20 years.

column1: “We were all very close before
column2: but now we feel like family
column3: ” she said. On Sunday
column4: Nykolaishyn will sing the lead role in the opera  Natalka Poltavka by the Ukrainian composer Mykola Lysenko.

column1: “We wanted to open with symbolic performances: first a European classic and then a Ukrainian classic
column2: ” said culture minister Oleksandr Tkachenko
column3: who attended Saturday’s performance.

column1: Kyiv’s opera house has seen a lot over the years
column2: on and off the stage. Opened in 1901 after a fire destroyed the previous building
column3: a decade later it was the scene of a dramatic assassination.

column1: Prime minister Pyotr Stolypin
column2: attending a Rimsky-Korsakov opera with Tsar Nicholas II
column3: was shot dead during the interval while standing in the front row of the stalls.

column1: The pause in performances during the Russian invasion is only the third lengthy gap in activity over the past century
column2: said the theatre’s archivist Larisa Tarasenko.

column1: The first was between the end of the Nazi occupation and the return of the evacuated Soviet troupe. The second was due to Covid. Otherwise
column2: performances continued even as regimes
column3: empires and ideological slants changed.

column1: Now
column2: with the Russian invasion
column3: the theatre plans to remove all of its Russian repertoire
column4: at least for the time being.

column1: Tkachenko said the culture ministry is actively lobbying opera houses abroad to remove Russian works from their repertoires
column2: an issue which has stirred a debate in many countries over whether Russia’s cultural heritage should be separate from the actions of Putin’s government.

column1: “We’re trying to argue that in a time of war
column2: it is a symbolic move
column3: and we should find ways to celebrate French
column4: Italian and certainly Ukrainian composers
column5: ” said Tkachenko.

column1: Nykolaishyn said she grew up on the Russian classics
column2: and singing Tatyana in Tchaikovsky’s Eugene Onegin was one of her first and favourite soloist roles.

column1: “But right now
column2: this is not the time for anything Russian. Maybe one day it will be possible again
column3: I don’t know
column4: ” she said."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/zelenskiy-signals-readiness-for-new-talks-if-mariupol-troops-are-not-harmed;2022-05-21;Zelenskiy signals readiness for new talks if Mariupol troops are not harmed;"Ukrainian leader tells TV station ‘there are things that can only be reached at the negotiating table’

Ukraine has suggested that it is willing to resume talks with Russia as Moscow claimed to have taken full control of the besieged city of Mariupol – its biggest prize since it invaded Ukraine in February.
Speaking to a television channel on Saturday
column2: Ukraine’s president
column3: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column4: said that “discussions between Ukraine and Russia will undoubtedly take place”.

column1: “Under what format I don’t know – with intermediaries
column2: without them
column3: in a broader group
column4: at the presidential level
column5: ” he added. “But the war will be bloody
column6: there will be fighting and [it] will only definitively end through diplomacy.

column1: “There are things that can only be reached at the negotiating table. We want everything to return [to as it was before] but Russia does not want that.”
The Kremlin’s spokesperson
column2: Dmitry Peskov
column3: responded by blaming Ukraine for stopping the talks. The last discussions between the two sides took place on 22 April
column4: according to Russian news agencies.

column1: During the interview
column2: held with a Ukrainian broadcaster
column3: Zelenskiy spoke of creating a document enshrining security guarantees for his country. Although bilateral discussions would be held with Russia
column4: the document would be signed by “friends and partners of Ukraine
column5: without Moscow”
column6: he added.

column1: However
column2: he warned that the precondition for resuming negotiations was that Moscow did not kill Ukrainian troops who had been defending the Azovstal steelworks in Mariupol. “The most important thing for me is to save the maximum number of people and soldiers
column3: ” he said.

column1: Last week
column2: Russia announced it had taken full control of Mariupol
column3: the first major city to fall. The last group of Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the Azovstal steelworks surrendered on Friday
column4: bringing to an end a months-long siege of the defenders’ last stronghold.

column1: “Underground structures of Azovstal where militants were hiding are now under full control of Russian armed forces
column2: ” Russia’s defence ministry said in a statement
column3: adding that 2
column4: 439 Ukrainian fighters had surrendered.

column1: Hours before the Russian announcement
column2: Zelenskiy said the defenders had been told by commanders that they should leave. In a live video posted on the messaging service Telegram
column3: Denys Prokopenko
column4: commander of the Azov Regiment
column5: which has led the defence of the factory
column6: said only the dead remained.

column1: “The higher military command has given the order to save the lives of the soldiers of our garrison and to stop defending the city
column2: ” he said. “I now hope that soon the families and all of Ukraine will be able to bury their fighters with honours.”

column1: Ukraine hopes to exchange the surrendering Azovstal soldiers for Russian prisoners. But in Donetsk
column2: pro-Kremlin authorities are threatening to put some of them on trial.

column1: The fall of Mariupol – the largest trading port on the Sea of Azov
column2: from which Ukraine exports grain
column3: iron
column4: steel and heavy machinery – is a breakthrough for Russia. Taking control of the city means gaining a land corridor from the Donbas to Crimea.

column1: Fierce fighting continued in the eastern Donbas
column2: where Zelenskiy said Russian troops had “completely ruined” the cities of Rubizhne and Volnovakha
column3: “just as they did Mariupol”
column4: adding that the Russians were “trying to do the same with Severodonetsk and many other cities”.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: on Saturday the Russian energy company Gazprom halted gas exports to neighbouring Finland
column3: the Finnish gas system operator said
column4: after Helsinki angered Moscow by applying for Nato membership last week.

column1: Moscow had warned Finland that any such application would be “a grave mistake with far-reaching consequences”.
The majority of gas used in Finland comes from Russia
column2: but the fuel only accounts for about 5% of the country’s annual energy consumption.

column1: The Finnish president
column2: Sauli Niinistö
column3: said he and the Turkish president
column4: Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
column5: had had “open and direct” talks to discuss the bid for Nato membership
column6: after Erdoğan openly questioned whether Finland and Sweden
column7: which has also applied
column8: should be permitted to join."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/food/2022/may/21/olia-hercules-when-russia-invaded-ukraine-i-couldnt-cook-for-the-first-month#comments;2022-05-21;Olia Hercules: ‘When Russia invaded Ukraine
column2: I couldn’t cook for the first month’;"The chef on supporting her homeland
column3: the power of broth and pining for Ukrainian wine

column1: When Russia invaded Ukraine
column2: I couldn’t eat. And I definitely couldn’t cook for the first month and a half. It was the feeling of guilt. I just felt
column3: “How can I even cook anything when there’s such horror happening everywhere else in Ukraine?” Then
column4: at the first event I did for #CookForUkraine
column5: this woman I’d never met before came up to me and said
column6: “I’ve brought you some broth.” I heated it up at home and had it out of a cup and it was just so life-giving. Then she started sending me a broth every week
column7: and she’s been doing it for two months now. And that’s what I’ve been sustaining myself on.

column1: When I was writing Mamushka
column2: people would say
column3: “Oh
column4: you’re writing a Ukrainian cookbook? Is that about dumplings and potatoes?” I understand it: stereotypes are stereotypes
column5: but hopefully I’ve been able to break some of them. Even when I spoke of Ukraine back then
column6: it was like
column7: “Is that Russia?” No
column8: it’s not fucking Russia! Our culture has for years and years and years been suppressed. Language
column9: food
column10: everything.

column1: I only really realised the scope of my mum and my dad’s skills after I trained to be a chef. Watching Mum make filo pastry
column2: stretching it out with her hands
column3: then spinning it around in the air like a pizzaiolo – it’s like she’s spinning webs. I know loads of professional chefs who would not be able to do that.

column1: Mamushka came out of a big jumble of things that were happening to me in 2014. I lost my job
column2: I was a single mum
column3: my son Sasha was nearly two years old. I was alone in the UK with no job and no prospects. Parallel to that
column4: the Maidan [uprising] happens and the war starts in the Crimea. So it began
column5: actually
column6: as me writing down names of recipes in my notebook as a way of just doing something
column7: and not sitting around and plunging myself into depression. Then I ended up getting this book deal
column8: miraculously
column9: everything came together. I never looked for an agent or to publish
column10: it was just for me.

column1: When I was giving birth to my son
column2: Sasha
column3: my first child
column4: the midwives were like
column5: “Are you OK?” And I was like
column6: “I’m a chef! I’ve done 18-hour shifts at Ottolenghi
column7: I can do this!” And I did. It was a really fast
column8: efficient birth. Working in a busy restaurant kitchen definitely gives you insane stamina
column9: for sure. You learn and your body learns it as well.

column1: The only food I really don’t like is avocado. I don’t get it. I mean
column2: it’s OK in guacamole
column3: when there’s loads of lime juice and flavourings. But avocado on toast? I’d rather eat a shoe.

column1: Coming to the UK to go to university was a shock
column2: to be honest. There had been some attempts at cajoling me into cooking when I was at school by my dad and my mum. But I burned everything. My heart wasn’t in it. Then
column3: because I studied Italian
column4: I did an Erasmus exchange in Italy
column5: and everybody in my halls of residence
column6: especially the boys
column7: weirdly
column8: were incredible cooks. Even if it was very simple
column9: like aglio olio e peperoncino or something
column10: there was just this flair and energy. So I fell in love with the idea of cooking and I just became obsessed.

column1: I’m slowly
column2: slowly getting back into cooking now. I finally convinced my parents to leave the south of Ukraine
column3: which is occupied by Russia. They drove through Europe and eventually ended up in Italy
column4: where my cousin has just recently bought a little house. When they arrived
column5: I made them borscht and handmade Ukrainian-style pasta and a sauce. That was the first time throughout this whole period that I actually enjoyed and was excited about cooking. Yeah
column6: it made me feel good.

column1: FoodMy death-row
column2: apocalypse dish would be my mum’s Ukrainian dumplings called varenyky
column3: which are filled with her homemade cheese that we call syr. It just wires some really crazy things in my brain and makes me release all of the endorphins.

column1: DrinkThe first word that springs to my head is wiiiiine! I really miss Ukrainian wine: natural
column2: low-intervention wine of a kind that is very fashionable now. It would be a dream if I could drink that all summer.

column1: Place to eatFor sure Towpath on the canal in London
column2: also 40 Maltby Street and Rochelle Canteen. You get the gist: restaurants that use really good ingredients and you can feel the skill in cooking
column3: but it’s not fussy.

column1: Dish to makeWorking with really soft
column2: leavened dough is my favourite thing. I find the whole process extremely therapeutic and rewarding
column3: and I love the smell.

column1: Olia Hercules’s new book
column2: Home Food
column3: is published on 7 July (Bloomsbury
column4: £26). #CookForUkraine is at justgiving.com"

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/may/21/canada-announces-sanctions-on-alexander-lebedev-russia-ukraine-report;2022-05-21;UK under pressure over Alexander Lebedev sanctions after Canada move;"Labour says the case for the British government to follow Ottawa’s lead is ‘extremely strong’
The British government is under pressure to impose sanctions on Alexander Lebedev after Canada targeted the former KGB agent in a fresh wave of restrictions against Vladimir Putin’s regime.
The billionaire Russian businessman
column2: who little more than a decade ago bought the UK’s Evening Standard and Independent newspapers
column3: was named in Ottawa’s latest sanctions announced on Friday.

column1: James Emmanuel Wanki
column2: a spokesperson for Global Affairs Canada
column3: confirmed to the Guardian on Saturday that Alexander Yevgenievich Lebedev
column4: born in 1959
column5: is on Canada’s sanctions list against Russia.

column1: The restrictions also included a ban on the import of Russian vodka
column2: diamonds and caviar
column3: according to the Globe and Mail.

column1: A UK government spokesperson said: “This government has been resolute in standing up to Russian aggression. We keep all sanctions under review and they are determined after careful consideration.”
But Labour accused the government of dragging its feet in imposing sanctions on those with links to the Russian president.
The party’s deputy leader
column2: Angela Rayner
column3: said: “Labour has been clear that anyone with links to the KGB must face sanctions. The Conservatives have been so slow and too soft in issuing sanctions to those with links to Putin.

column1: “There is now an extremely strong case for Alexander Lebedev to face sanctions from the UK and the government must now urgently look at the evidence.”
She accused Boris Johnson of having “form when it comes to protecting the Lebedevs”.
“He failed to release critical information relating to the appointment of Alexander Lebedev’s son to the House of Lords
column2: despite concerns from the security services. This is another case of the prime minister bending the rules to protect his friends
column3: ” she said.

column1: Lebedev’s links to Johnson are well documented.
He is also a minority shareholder in the Russian opposition newspaper Novaya Gazeta. His son Evgeny
column2: who owns the Evening Standard and is a minority shareholder in The Independent
column3: was appointed to the House of Lords in 2020 despite concerns raised by MI5.

column1: The government was accused of a cover-up last week after it declined a Commons instruction to release information about the decision to make him a peer
column2: claiming it would undermine the confidentiality of those nominated and could degenerate into political point-scoring.

column1: He published a statement in the Standard in February in which he pleaded with Putin to end the war.
The Canadian government said the ban on trade in luxury goods and the addition of 14 oligarchs and Putin associates was aligned with similar measures imposed by allies such as the US and the EU
column2: and would “help to mitigate the potential for Russian oligarchs to circumvent restrictions in other luxury goods markets”.

column1: The sanctions package
column2: announced by Canada’s foreign minister
column3: Mélanie Joly
column4: covers goods that were worth $75.7m (£47m) in 2021. It also bans the export of jewellery
column5: art and kitchenware to Russia and restricts the export of “goods that could be used in the production and manufacture of weapons”.

column1: “The Putin regime must
column2: and will
column3: answer for their unjustifiable acts
column4: ” Joly said. “Canada
column5: together with our allies
column6: will be relentless in our efforts to maintain pressure on the Russian regime until it is no longer able to wage war. We are unwavering in our support for Ukraine and its people.”

column1: According to the Globe and Mail
column2: other figures Canada has newly subjected to sanctions include Gleb Frank
column3: a leading Russian fishery company owner; his father
column4: Sergei Frank
column5: the former minister of transport and former chief executive of Russian shipping firm Sovcomflot; and Sergei Frank’s wife
column6: Ksenia Frank
column7: the daughter of Gennady Timchenko
column8: an oligarch and an associate of Putin.

column1: David Davidovich
column2: a close associate of Roman Abramovich
column3: who has been forced to sell Chelsea football club after being placed under sanctions in the UK
column4: was also sanctioned.

column1: The fresh wave of sanctions came as talks between G7 countries and Ukraine’s prime minister
column2: Denys Shmyhal
column3: concluded in Germany.

column1: Canada has to date sanctioned more than 1
column2: 000 individuals and entities from Russia
column3: Belarus and Ukraine since the start of Russia’s invasion."

column1: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/apocalypse-now-the-alarming-effects-of-the-global-food-crisis;2022-05-21;Apocalypse now? The alarming effects of the global food crisis;"The Bank of England governor warned last week of ‘apocalyptic’ food price rises. Yet war in Ukraine
column2: climate change and inflation are already taking their toll all over the world

column1: Apocalypse is an alarming idea
column2: commonly taken to denote catastrophic destruction foreshadowing the end of the world. But in the original Greek
column3: apokálypsis means a revelation or an uncovering. One vernacular definition is “to take the lid off something”.

column1: That latter feat is exactly what Andrew Bailey
column2: governor of the Bank of England
column3: achieved last week
column4: possibly inadvertently
column5: when he suggested Britain was facing “apocalyptic” levels of food price inflation. Tory ministers fumed over what they saw as implied criticism of the government’s masterly economic management.

column1: In fact
column2: Bailey was talking as much about the drastic impact of Ukraine-war-related rises in food costs and food shortages on people in poorer countries. “There’s a major worry for the developing world as well ... Sorry for being apocalyptic for a moment
column3: but that is a major concern
column4: ” he said.

column1: With most political and media attention narrowly focused on the emerging UK “cost of living crisis”
column2: Bailey’s high-profile comments were timely – and revelatory. Months of warnings about a global tidal wave of hunger
column3: rendered more urgent by Ukraine
column4: have been largely ignored
column5: not least by Boris Johnson’s aid-cutting government.

column1: The cost of living is a problem in Britain. For UN agencies and humanitarian relief workers around the world
column2: the bigger worry is the cost of dying.

column1: Sounding the alarm again last week
column2: António Guterres
column3: the UN secretary general
column4: said Ukraine-related shortages could help “tip tens of millions of people over the edge into food insecurity”. The result could be “malnutrition
column5: mass hunger and famine in a crisis that could last for years” – and increase the chances of a global recession.

column1: The World Food Programme estimates about 49 million people face emergency levels of hunger. About 811 million go to bed hungry each night. The number of people on the brink of starvation across Africa’s Sahel region
column2: for example
column3: is at least 10 times higher than in pre-Covid 2019.

column1: The adverse impact of Russia’s invasion on the availability and price of staples such as wheat
column2: maize
column3: barley and sunflower oil – Ukraine and Russia normally produce about 30% of global wheat exports – has been huge.

column1: Ukraine’s wheat production this year is likely to be 35% down
column2: and exporting much of it may be impossible due to Russia’s Black Sea blockade. In March
column3: global commodity prices
column4: recorded by the UN’s Food and Agriculture Organisation
column5: hit an all-time high. They remain at record-breaking levels.

column1: Russia’s war has compounded or accelerated pre-existing food deficits and inflationary trends arising from a host of linked factors: the negative economic impact of the pandemic; resulting supply-chain
column2: employment and transport problems; extreme weather and climate-crisis-related falls in output; spiralling energy costs; and numerous other ongoing conflicts worldwide.

column1: Middle-income countries
column2: such as Egypt and Brazil
column3: are exceptionally poorly placed to cope with increased food insecurity
column4: international risk consultants Verisk Maplecroft said in a report last week. Many governments had exhausted their financial and material reserves fighting Covid and incurred large debts.

column1: Now the cupboard is bare. “Unlike low-income countries
column2: they were rich enough to offer social protection during the pandemic
column3: but now struggle to maintain high social spending that is vital to the living standards of large sections of their populations
column4: ” the report said.

column1: Argentina
column2: Tunisia
column3: Pakistan and the Philippines
column4: highly dependent on food and energy imports
column5: were among many other middle- or lower-middle-income countries facing an elevated risk of civil unrest by the end of 2022
column6: it suggested.

column1: As the food “apocalypse” approaches
column2: the poorest peoples will suffer
column3: as they always do
column4: while the wealthiest may be insulated
column5: up to a point. But it is feared that the pain will rapidly move up the global food chain. With it is likely to come a surge in political turbulence
column6: humanitarian crises
column7: instability and geo-strategic rivalries across a hungry world.

column1: Scarce food
column2: combined with price increases
column3: electricity blackouts and shortages of petrol
column4: cooking gas and medicines
column5: provoked a political crisis in Sri Lanka this spring that serves as a discomfiting template for countries facing similar problems.

column1: Months of protests culminated in the resignation of the prime minister
column2: Mahinda Rajapaksa
column3: but even his scalp did not prevent unrest turning violent. Desperate
column4: Sri Lanka has been seeking a bridging loan from the World Bank to help pay for essential imports. On Thursday
column5: it defaulted on its debt for the first time ever.

column1: Double-digit inflation that left many Pakistanis unable to afford basic foodstuffs was also a major contributory factor in the fall from power earlier this year of the prime minister
column2: Imran Khan. His attempt to cling to office created a crisis of democracy with which Pakistan is still grappling.

column1: Longer-term factors – repressive governance
column2: corruption
column3: incompetence
column4: polarisation – fuelled unrest in both countries. But dire food shortages and inflation were the catalyst that rendered the objectionable intolerable. That’s a prospect now facing insecure and unpopular regimes from Peru
column5: the Philippines and Cuba to Lebanon and Tunisia.

column1: Analysts compare what is happening today in the Middle East with the Arab spring revolts. Egypt
column2: whose government was overthrown in 2011
column3: is the world’s largest wheat importer. About 70 million people rely on state-subsidised bread. Russia and Ukraine accounted for 80% of Egypt’s grain imports last year.

column1: Today’s high prices and supply shortfalls
column2: especially if they worsen
column3: could do for Abdel Fatah al-Sisi’s regime what similar grievances did for his deposed presidential predecessor
column4: Hosni Mubarak.

column1: Another country to watch closely is Iran. Violent protests erupted last week in Khuzestan after the government raised the price of bread
column2: cooking oil and dairy products. Iranians’ situation is made worse by tough US sanctions and a tyrannical
column3: corrupt clerical regime. If living standards continue to fall
column4: there could be an explosion similar to the thwarted nationwide uprising of 2017-18.

column1: In many parts of the world
column2: especially Africa
column3: food insecurity is anything but a new phenomenon. Hunger is the norm and the risk of famine is ever-present
column4: often exacerbated by conflict and climate change. That said
column5: the situation
column6: broadly speaking
column7: is deteriorating.

column1: The total number of people facing acute food insecurity and requiring urgent food assistance has nearly doubled since 2016
column2: according to the Global Network Against Food Crises
column3: a joint UN and EU project. And the scale of the challenge is expanding
column4: up by 40 million people
column5: or 20%
column6: last year. The network’s latest report pinpointed countries of particular concern: Ethiopia
column7: South Sudan
column8: southern Madagascar and Yemen
column9: where it said 570
column10: 000 people – up 571% on six years ago – were in the most severe or “catastrophe” phase of food insecurity
column11: threatened by the collapse of livelihoods

column1: Guterres
column2: the UN chief
column3: warned that Vladimir Putin’s war was seriously affecting efforts to fight hunger in Africa. It was imperative
column4: he said
column5: to “bring back the agriculture production of Ukraine and the food and fertiliser production of Russia and Belarus into world markets”. As Russian state media often note
column6: western sanctions have added to global price volatility.

column1: The UN is calling for Ukraine’s blockaded Black Sea and Azov Sea ports to be reopened so that grain exports can resume
column2: not least to African countries. Especially badly affected is the drought-hit Sahel region. “An absolute crisis is unfolding before our eyes
column3: ” the World Food Programme’s director
column4: David Beasley
column5: said following visits to Benin
column6: Niger and Chad. “We’re running out of money
column7: and these people are running out of hope.”

column1: That’s partly because aid now costs more. The UN and international agencies are obliged to pay inflated prices
column2: up about 30% from pre-Covid norms
column3: to secure vital food aid. And it is partly because food is more expensive relative to income. An average UK household spends 10% of its income on food. In Kenya or Pakistan
column4: it is over 40%.

column1: Conflict is the biggest driver of hunger
column2: whether it is the depredations of Islamist jihadists in Mali
column3: Nigeria and the southern Philippines
column4: the crass rivalries of regional powers in Yemen and Libya
column5: or an unpardonable full-scale war
column6: as in Ukraine.

column1: The UN estimates that 60% of the world’s hungry live in conflict zones. Ukraine has shown again how war
column2: by causing shortages of essentials and rendering normal life insupportable
column3: leads to internal displacement
column4: aid dependency
column5: refugee emergencies and mass migration.

column1: Syria’s civil war provides a cautionary example – although there are many others. A relatively prosperous country has been reduced by over a decade of conflict to something approaching a basket case. About 12.4 million people – 60% of the population – suffer food insecurity
column2: a figure that has more than doubled since 2019.

column1: Ethiopia’s disastrous war of choice in Tigray
column2: which was invaded by government troops in 2019
column3: is another case of famine following folly. The UN estimated in January that 2 million people were suffering from an extreme lack of food
column4: and were dependent on aid in a province that was previously mostly self-sufficient.

column1: In contrast
column2: South Sudan has never been fully able to feed itself since independence in 2011. Ethnically rooted rivalries have often combined with competition for land and food resources with catastrophic effects. Cattle rustling is a key source of violence
column3: while drought is another big factor.

column1: Even when a struggling country is in the international spotlight – rarely the case with South Sudan – and the war is supposedly over
column2: its fortunes do not necessarily improve. The plight of many Afghans appears to have gone from bad to worse after the 20-year occupation by US and Nato forces ended last year and the Taliban took charge.

column1: The billions of dollars of aid ploughed into the country since 2001 now count for naught. Save the Children said this month that 9.6 million Afghan children are going hungry due to deepening economic woes
column2: Ukraine
column3: and ongoing drought. It is the country’s worst hunger crisis on record
column4: the charity said.

column1: It is no longer controversial to assert that destroyed crops
column2: lost livelihoods and impoverished communities – key micro-ingredients of mass hunger emergencies – are intimately connected to
column3: and affected by
column4: climate change and extreme weather events. But it is still hard to find concerted
column5: effective international action or public pressure to shift the dynamic.

column1: Horn of Africa countries such as Somalia
column2: for example
column3: are experiencing the worst drought in 40 years amid unprecedentedly high temperatures. As Foreign Policy magazine reported recently
column4: when the rains did come
column5: they were extreme and short-lived
column6: causing flooding and breeding swarms of locusts.

column1: It is claimed that about 3 million livestock have perished in southern Ethiopia and semi-arid parts of Kenya since last year. Pointing to climate change
column2: the UN says 20 million people across the region could go hungry this year. Their plight
column3: too
column4: has been exacerbated by Ukraine.

column1: But when the charity Christian Aid commissioned polling on the Horn of Africa region to find out what the British public thought should be done
column2: only 23% of those questioned were aware there was a problem. In contrast
column3: 91% were aware of Putin’s war.

column1: India recently demonstrated the lack of joined-up international thinking on climate
column2: hunger and war. A record-breaking heatwave in north-west India has damaged this year’s crops. That led the government to suspend wheat exports this month. Global markets had been relying on India
column3: the world’s second-largest producer
column4: to make up the Ukraine shortfall. Instead of helping
column5: Narendra Modi’s government did the opposite.

column1: Critical links between the twin crises of climate and hunger are broadly recognised by governments and analysts
column2: but acting to effect real change is proving harder
column3: as the less-than-stellar outcomes of last year’s Cop26 summit in Glasgow suggest.

column1: In the meantime
column2: the World Bank is throwing money at the problem – at the latest count
column3: $30bn to help low-income countries embroiled in climate and food crises.

column1: When the history of the Ukraine war is written
column2: Russia’s reckless action in weaponising food and deliberately disrupting global supplies
column3: thereby risking the lives of countless millions
column4: may be counted a bigger crime than even its unprovoked attack on its neighbour.

column1: Russia’s role as a key grain and energy exporter is likely to outlive the current regime in Moscow. But its global standing and influence is diminished
column2: probably permanently.

column1: That is largely due to Putin’s personal failure to recognise
column2: or accept
column3: that the era of Soviet exceptionalism is over – and that Russia
column4: like other countries
column5: inhabits a newly interconnected
column6: interdependent
column7: mutually responsible world of rules
column8: rights and laws.

column1: The UN general assembly vote in March
column2: overwhelmingly condemning as illegal Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
column3: brought together many once Moscow-friendly developing countries shocked by Putin’s disregard for national sovereignty and borders – and his apparent indifference to the wellbeing of poorer nations dependent on food and fuel imports. It was a watershed moment.

column1: China’s refusal to condemn the invasion
column2: and its failure to show international leadership in addressing the resulting global hunger and supply crises
column3: may also significantly damage its reputation and

column2: I am a witness to the terrible traumas of war;"We can support those trapped in shelters or struggling with survivor’s guilt. But some emotional damage is irreparable

column1: All four of my grandparents survived the second world war
column2: and all four were scarcely willing to talk about it
column3: having either survived the siege of Leningrad or come back from the frontline wounded. On the rare occasions they did
column4: their memories would leave them devastated.

column1: The lifelong PTSD they experienced was quite possibly one of the reasons I became a psychologist. I wanted to do something to end the vicious circle of trauma
column2: abuse
column3: self-neglect and fear. But during my training
column4: I could never have predicted the way I would be applying my skills a decade later.

column1: On 25 February
column2: the day after the Russian invasion of Ukraine
column3: I volunteered to join several crisis hotlines where psychologists were working to support those affected by the war. I couldn’t stop the war
column4: but at least I might try to lessen the damage. My colleagues come from many different countries – some of the Ukrainian psychologists kept working between bombings
column5: while others had evacuated to a safer place. Quite a few of us
column6: myself included
column7: are living abroad in safety — a privilege too often taken for granted.

column1: During the first weeks of the war
column2: most of the Ukrainian people who texted or called us had either just been evacuated or were still in areas of heavy shelling. Those who managed to escape were suffering from survivor’s guilt
column3: along with shock from the war in general. Those who stayed were experiencing shock in a different way
column4: trying to navigate through their daily spikes of anxiety.

column1: My first client was a person besieged in Ukraine. Their whole family had been hiding in a bomb shelter for days and they were experiencing panic attacks
column2: partly from the sudden responsibility of having to care for elderly relatives and beloved pets. They had to make the kind of decisions no one should have to face.

column1: As the war developed
column2: everyone’s stress tolerance was wearing thinner and thinner. Those who fled Ukraine reported apathy and a loss of the will to live. Old traumas have resurfaced
column3: tightening their grip and making it harder to breathe. Those who were still besieged were getting weaker mentally and physically
column4: and they were finding it harder to cope with the sleep deprivation and constant levels of tension and alertness. In such situations
column5: the main way we can offer support is by validating the person’s feelings; helping them find things they can control; and finding self-regulatory techniques that work
column6: such as body relaxation or breathing techniques.

column1: It became the eerie norm to receive text messages from people who had managed to come online in pauses between hiding in the shelter from bombs. However
column2: none of us could get used to having to guess whether a delay in response meant the person had no network connection
column3: or that they were no longer alive. Messages such as “I feel drained”
column4: “I need an urgent vent call” and “I need to talk to someone
column5: I feel it’s taken a toll on me” started to appear in our internal specialists’ support chats more often.

column1: As a response to this
column2: psychologists who specialise in supervision support started to organise webinars and video conferences in order to help each other work through the tension generated by the sessions. A group of dance movement therapists has recently launched a series of virtual meetups where they show how dance and movement can be used to cope with stress. I find such initiatives very important: if we burn out now
column3: we won’t be able to help.

column1: Messages such as this keep us going: “Thank you for helping me find the strength to let my husband go to war”; “Thank you for this talk
column2: I needed to be heard. I found the courage to try and evacuate
column3: and I’m in a safe place now.”

column1: My grandma – the only grandparent still living – struggles to relive her wartime memories without tears. But she emphasises the importance of truth
column2: especially during the times we’re living in
column3: and of preserving these memories. Lately
column4: my family and I have been spending hours on video calls with her as she shares them with us.

column1: To honour my colleagues’ work I recently started a documentary project
column2: taking their portraits via video calls. It feels important to make a record of this almost invisible part of war. When I publish the project later this year
column3: I hope the war will be over. But a huge volume of trauma repair work is still to be done.

column1: Anna Shilonosova is a documentary photographer and assistant psychologist currently based in the UK

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/children-back-in-school-after-cleanup-in-traumatised-ukrainian-village;2022-05-21;Children back in school after cleanup in traumatised Ukrainian village;"No windows or textbooks but enthusiasm among pupils as classes resume in Novyi Bykiv
A class of children in Novyi Bykiv sat listening to their teacher
column2: his voice competing with the sound of plastic sheets flapping in the window frames. Asked if they were happy to be back in school
column3: the class of fifth-grade students chorused “Yes!” with genuine enthusiasm.

column1: They may not have windows
column2: electricity or textbooks yet
column3: but lessons in this village east of Kyiv have been back under way for two weeks now
column4: after a major cleanup operation following the departure of the Russian army.

column1: Novyi Bykiv was one of a series of settlements occupied by the Russian army for a month as part of Vladimir Putin’s failed drive towards the capital from three directions. For a month the residents lived in terror
column2: with summary executions and widespread looting part of life.

column1: The school was the main Russian base in the village
column2: and when the Guardian visited just after the Russian departure there were clothes
column3: food and broken glass strewn across the floors
column4: graffiti sprayed on the walls and messages left by the Russians on the blackboards.

column1: The Russians launched BUK missiles from just outside the school
column2: drawing Ukrainian artillery fire that blew out the school’s windows
column3: destroyed much of the Russian hardware and eventually led to their retreat in the last days of March.

column1: “It was an unbearable time; you walked along the street and saw people you knew to be well dressed and elegant and they were wearing rags
column2: with red eyes and looking dazed
column3: ” said the headteacher
column4: Natalia Vovk. “Back then I thought that was it
column5: that we’d never been able to work here again
column6: we’d never be able to bring life back to this place
column7: ” she said.

column1: For the children
column2: too
column3: the occupation was a traumatic time
column4: as they saw the adults helpless to protect their homes and loved ones from the Russian onslaught.

column1: The cleanup process was long
column2: tiring and unpleasant. One of the downstairs rooms at the school had been used as a hybrid toilet and barbers
column3: and was littered with clumps of hair and piles of faeces. Everywhere there was shattered glass and other debris. Someone found a hand grenade in the basement.

column1: By the beginning of May
column2: enough had been repaired for lessons to resume. In some parts of Ukraine
column3: schools are using distance learning
column4: but the Russian army looted most of the houses in Novyi Bykiv
column5: meaning neither teachers nor students have computers or tablets.

column1: About 100 of the school’s 188 pupils now attend regularly for short school days. Many of the others are still abroad or in western Ukraine
column2: having fled with their families.

column1: A number of small charitable organisations and individuals contacted the school after reading the Guardian article in April detailing the destruction there
column2: Vovk said. Someone sent six computers
column3: which arrived recently by post and are being stored elsewhere until the school building has windows again to ensure they remain safe. Another donor has offered to pay for replacement textbooks
column4: after the entire stock was destroyed in a fire during the occupation.

column1: Locals have also pitched in. Someone donated a lawnmower to mow the grass in front of the building
column2: as the Russians had looted the school’s mower. The school bus driver and the building manager were working on Thursday afternoon to rig up plastic coverings on more of the windows
column3: until the money comes in for permanent replacements.

column1: The war has disrupted schooling across Ukraine
column2: even in the relatively safe western part of the country. More than 200 schools have been fully destroyed and hundreds more damaged
column3: according to Ukraine’s education ombudsman Sergii Gorbachov. Even in the west
column4: in schools with no bomb shelter the lessons have had to go online.

column1: A recent survey of Ukrainian parents found that 75% said their children had shown signs of increased stress since the war started
column2: with some of the most common symptoms being mood swings
column3: nightmares
column4: anxiety and panic attacks.

column1: “Of course children have really suffered during these last months
column2: and it’s really important to give them proper support
column3: ” said Yulia Serdyuk
column4: a 35-year-old teacher and psychologist from Novyi Bykiv.

column1: Serdyuk said she advised children to spend as much time as possible talking with their parents and with other children. She said it was important for children to be able to discuss what had happened in the past three months rather than bury the experiences
column2: though in some cases extreme care was required.

column1: “If something terrible happened to their parents then you have to approach these cases really delicately
column2: ” she said.

column1: Serdyuk spent three weeks living under occupation in Novyi Bykiv
column2: before deciding to leave with her daughter on 19 March
column3: a terrifying ordeal that involved talking their way through Russian checkpoints and at one point hiding from an incoming artillery strike.

column1: She spent a month in Poland
column2: but as soon as she heard it was safe she returned to Novyi Bykiv. “They took good care of us there but I was so desperate to come back
column3: ” she said.

column1: Ukrainian officials hope that eventually the vast majority of children who fled with their families will return. Authorities are in negotiations to allow those abroad to continue some Ukrainian education through distance learning
column2: as well as attending school in the countries where they are temporarily based.

column1: Another issue is the situation in the areas of Ukraine occupied by Russia
column2: where teachers are undergoing “retraining” programmes and are expected to teach in Russian
column3: using the Russian curriculum.

column1: “We have an enormous amount of testimony from the occupied areas about teachers being forced to change curriculums
column2: and in some cases headteachers being kidnapped
column3: or at the very least replaced with other
column4: less qualified people who are willing to collaborate
column5: ” Gorbachov said.

column1: In Novyi Bykiv the teachers have done everything to remove signs of the Russian occupation
column2: except in one classroom where they have left the messages scrawled on the blackboard untouched
column3: as a reminder of those days.

column1: “Do not bring shame on the memories of your fathers and grandfathers
column2: they fought AGAINST Nazis
column3: ” says one message in chalk
column4: echoing the distorted Russian propaganda narrative that the Russian mission in Ukraine is about “denazification”.

column1: Vovk
column2: whose mother is Russian and moved to Ukraine 40 years ago
column3: said it was hard for her to understand the mentality of those Russians who had come to the village. She has long stopped speaking to her own family members in Russia.

column1: “It’s just unthinkable what happened
column2: how they could do this
column3: ” she said. “We all just hope our victory will come as soon as possible
column4: and that they never come back here again.”"
